rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The Older Americans Act focuses on providing services and support for older adults but does not set architectural standards for facilities.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A patient at an outpatient facility experiences the onset of a grand mal seizure. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action by the therapist?

options.text: Assist the patient to a lying position, move away close furniture, loosen tight clothing, and prop the patient’s mouth open.
Assist the patient to a lying position, move away close furniture, and loosen tight clothing.
Assist the patient to a seated position, move away close furniture, and loosen tight clothing.
Assist the patient to a seated position, move away close furniture, loosen tight clothing, and prop the patient’s mouth open

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The primary goals during a seizure are to protect the person from injury and maintain an open airway. Assisting them to a safe lying position prevents falls. Moving furniture away prevents them from striking objects. Loosening tight clothing around the neck helps ensure breathing is not restricted. Nothing should ever be placed in the mouth.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: It is dangerous and contraindicated to prop or place anything in the patient's mouth during a seizure, as it can cause injury to the teeth, jaw, or the rescuer.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A seated position is less safe than a lying position, as the patient could fall from the chair.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is incorrect due to both the seated position and propping the mouth open.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A therapist is instructing a physical therapy student in writing a SOAP note. The student has misplaced the following phrase: Patient reports a functional goal of returning to playing baseball in 5 weeks. Where should this phrase be placed in a SOAP note?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The 'Subjective' portion of the SOAP note includes anything the patient, their family, or caregiver reports that is relevant to their condition. This statement is a direct report from the patient about their personal goals, and therefore belongs in the Subjective section.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The 'Objective' section contains measurable and observable data collected by the therapist (e.g., ROM, MMT, vital signs).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The 'Assessment' section is the therapist's analysis and interpretation of the S and O data.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The 'Plan' section outlines the future course of treatment.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: An acute-care physical therapist is ordered to examine and treat a patient who has suffered a right hip fracture in a recent fall. During the examination, the family informs the therapist that the patient suffered a stroke approximately 1 week before the fall. The patient’s chart has no record of the recent stroke. What should the therapist do first?

options.text: Immediately call the referring physician and request a magnetic resonance scan.
Examine and treat the patient as ordered.
Examine and treat the patient as ordered and request a computed tomography scan.
Immediately call the referring physician for an occupational therapy referral.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Although a stroke may have occurred, the physical therapist can first examine the patient. Although a stroke may have occurred, the physical therapist can first examine the patient. After the examination has been performed, the therapist will be more informed about the patient’s condition and can then contact the physician if necessary.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A physical therapist cannot order a magnetic resonance imaging scan.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A physical therapist cannot order a computed tomography scan.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: An occupational therapy referral may be necessary, but this does not need to be the first step in this situation.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist in an outpatient clinic is urgently called into a room to assist an infant who is unconscious and not breathing. The therapist opens the airway of the infant and attempts ventilation. The breaths do not make the chest rise. After the infant’s head is repositioned, the breaths still do not cause the chest to move. What should the therapist do next?

options.text: Look into the throat for a foreign body.
Perform a blind finger sweep of the throat.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Back blows should be followed by chest thrusts with complete airway obstruction when CPR is performed on an infant. The therapist then should check for a foreign body in the airway. A blind finger sweep of the throat should not be performed on an infant.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Before attempting to provide back blows, the physical therapist should attempt to reposition the head and check for a foreign body.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Someone should have already been instructed to call 911.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Blind finger sweeps are not appropriate in this situation.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A physical therapist is setting up a portable whirlpool unit in the room of a severely immobile patient. What is the most important task of the physical therapist before the patient is placed in the whirlpool?

options.text: Check for a ground fault circuit interruption outlet.
Check to make sure the water temperature is below 110° F.
Make sure the whirlpool agitator is immersed in the water.
Obtain the appropriate assistance to perform a transfer.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A ground fault interruption outlet is designed to quickly stop the flow of electricity to prevent electrocution. Given the use of an electrical appliance (the whirlpool) in a wet environment, ensuring the outlet is properly protected with a GFCI is the single most important safety check to prevent a life-threatening situation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Water temperature is an important safety consideration to prevent burns, but it is secondary to preventing electrocution.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Proper agitator immersion is important for the function of the whirlpool but not as critical a safety issue as the electrical outlet.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Safe transfers are crucial, but ensuring the electrical safety of the environment must be done first.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A 37-year-old man fell and struck his left temple area on the corner of a mat table. He begins to bleed profusely but remains conscious and alert. Attempts to stop blood flow with direct pressure to the area of the injury are unsuccessful. Of the following, which is an additional area to which pressure should be applied to stop bleeding?

options.text: Left parietal bone one inch posterior to the ear
Left temporal bone just anterior to the ear
Zygomatic arch of the frontal bone
Zygomatic arch superior to the mastoid process

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Pressure on the left temporal bone just anterior to the ear helps to occlude blood flow from the temporal artery.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The parietal bone is not where a major artery is located in relation to the temple.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The zygomatic arch is below the temporal area and not the optimal pressure point.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The mastoid process is posterior to the ear and not on the primary arterial pathway to the temple.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A physical therapist is beginning the examination of a patient with AIDS. The patient was admitted to the acute floor of the hospital on the previous night after receiving a right total hip replacement. The physician has ordered gait training and a dressing change of the surgical site. Of the following precautions, which is the least necessary?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: AIDS is transmitted by blood or bodily fluids. Masks are usually used with airborne precautions. Hand washing should be done between all wound care patients. Gloves are also indicated with all open wounds. Gowns may not be a necessity but should be used if there is a chance of soiling the clothing with infected fluids.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Gloves are necessary due to the potential contact with blood or bodily fluids during dressing changes.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Hand washing is the single most important infection control measure and is always necessary.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A gown may be necessary to protect clothing from contamination during wound care.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist is treating a 17-year-old boy with an incomplete T11 spinal cord injury. The patient was treated for 2 months in the rehabilitation unit of the hospital before beginning outpatient physical therapy. He is currently ambulating with a standard walker with minimal assist of two. The therapist sets an initial long-term goal of “ambulation with a standard walker with minimum assist of 1 for a distance of 50 feet, with no loss of balance, on a level surface—in 8 weeks.” If the patient achieves the long-term goal in 4 weeks, which of the following courses of action should be taken by the therapist?

options.text: Discharge the patient secondary to completion of goals.
Set another long-term goal regarding ambulation and continue treatment.
Return the patient to the rehabilitation unit of the hospital for more intensive treatment.
Call the patient’s physician and ask for further instructions.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because the goals were not completed in a short amount of time, a new long-term goal should be set. Because of the significant progress made in outpatient therapy, there is no need to return to the rehabilitation unit.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Although one goal was met, the patient has not reached their full potential for functional mobility.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Returning the patient to the rehab unit is not necessary as they are making good progress in the outpatient setting.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The physical therapist should be able to set new goals without consulting the physician.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist is ordered to examine a 74-year-old man who has suffered a recent stroke. The therapist performs a chart review before performing the examination. Which of the following is of the least importance to the physical therapist in assessing the patient's chart?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: All of the choices are important, but the dietary assessment contains the least amount of critical information at this stage of the physical therapy examination.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The nursing assessment provides valuable information about the patient's current status, vitals, and care needs.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The physician's orders and notes are critical for understanding the medical plan, diagnosis, and any contraindications or precautions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The respiratory assessment is important as respiratory complications are common after a stroke.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: Each of the following choices consists of a list of two summaries of some of the principles in the code of ethics of the American Physical Therapy Association. Which of the answers below is a false summary?

options.text: (1) Obey regulations governing physical therapists, and (2) maintain high standards when providing therapy.
(1) Respect the rights of patients, and (2) inform people appropriately of the services provided.
(1) Maintain high standards when providing therapy, and (2) provide services for the length of time ordered.
(1) Assist the public when there are public health needs, and (2) accept fair monetary compensation for services.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: While maintaining high standards is a core principle, providing services for the 'length of time ordered' is not an ethical mandate if it conflicts with clinical judgment. A PT must use their professional judgment to determine the appropriate duration of care based on the patient's needs and progress, not simply follow an order blindly.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Both are correct summaries of ethical principles related to legal and professional standards.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Both are correct summaries of ethical principles related to patient autonomy and informed consent.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Both are correct summaries of ethical principles related to social responsibility and just business practices.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist is scheduled to examine the shoulder of a patient with hepatitis B. The therapist notices no open wounds or abrasions and also notices that the patient has good hygiene. The physician has ordered passive range of motion to the right shoulder because of adhesive capsulitis. Which of the following precautions is absolutely necessary to prevent the therapist from being infected?

options.text: The therapist must wear a gown.
The therapist must wear a mask.
There is no need for any personal protective equipment.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The therapist does not need to wear a gown, gloves, or mask. These precautions are necessary only if there is a chance that the therapist and his or her clothing can become contaminated with blood, serum, or feces.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A gown is not necessary as there is no anticipated contact with blood or bodily fluids.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A mask is not necessary as Hepatitis B is not transmitted via the airborne or droplet route.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Gloves are not necessary as there are no open wounds and no direct contact with bodily fluids is anticipated.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A contraindicated activity for a child with osteogenesis imperfecta would be

options.text: Light weights attached close to joints

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A pull-to-sit maneuver would put undue stress on the cervical spine and may result in damage to the spinal cord. Children with osteogenesis imperfecta have fragile bones and this maneuver could cause a fracture.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Spontaneous active movement is encouraged within the child's abilities.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Prone scooter activity can be a safe way to encourage mobility and strengthening.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Light weights, when applied carefully and appropriately, can be used for strengthening.

subject: Paediatrics

question: The best recommendation for strength training in prepubescent children is

options.text: Strength training programs should be the same as adolescents
Strength training should be done only for the lower extremities
Strength training should be closely monitored, correctly taught, and involve low load/high repetition tasks

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Strength training in this group should be closely monitored because of skeletal immaturity. Proper technique should be taught and reinforced.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Strength training is safe and beneficial for children when designed and supervised appropriately.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Children are not miniature adults; their programs must be tailored to their developmental stage and should not be the same as for adolescents.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Strength training can and should involve the entire body, not just the lower extremities.

subject: Paediatrics

question: You are working with a 2-year-old child who has a tumor in the posterior fossa. Which intervention is most likely contraindicated?

options.text: Gentle anterior-posterior glides in the upper cervical region

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: With an ongoing tumor in this area, any passive ROM or mobilization is contraindicated.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Active range of motion within the child's tolerance is generally safe.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A home positioning program is an important part of management.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Strengthening exercises that do not put direct stress on the tumor site would be appropriate.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A patient with an acute infection is admitted to the hospital. A chart review shows that the patient currently has a body temperature of 102.5° F. The physician has ordered for therapy to begin to intervention with this patient immediately. What is the most appropriate course of action by the physical therapist?

options.text: Contact the physician as an acute infection is a contraindication to exercise.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Exercise during acute infections can affect performance and may make the current condition worse. It could also compromise the cardiovascular and immune systems and exacerbate dehydration.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While a brief examination might be possible, initiating an intervention is contraindicated.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Initiating ROM exercises is contraindicated with an active systemic infection and fever.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Initiating ambulation is contraindicated with an active systemic infection and fever.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: During documentation after an intervention a mistake is made in the note. Which of the below is NOT an appropriate step to make in correcting the mistake?

options.text: Strike one line through the error so that it is still legible.
Write your initials in the margin near the mistake.
Write “mistaken entry” or “error” near the mistake.
Use liquid correction fluid or an eraser over the mistake.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Choices A, B, and C should all be performed each time a documentation error is made. One should never use erasers or liquid correction.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This is the correct procedure for indicating an error while maintaining legibility of the original entry.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Initialing the change is required to identify who made the correction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Noting that the entry is a mistake is part of the proper correction procedure.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist has determined that hamstring stretching should be incorporated in the intervention of 75-year-old female with complaints of low back pain. Which of the following conditions is a contraindication to stretching the hamstring muscle group?

options.text: Soreness lasting approximately 2 to 3 hours after therapy
Minimal complaints of pain in the lumbar area

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Although soreness lasting 24 hours or more is a concern, and care should be taken because of the age of the patient, it is not a contraindication to stretching. Excessive complaints of pain should be a contraindication. Hemophiliacs should not be stretched in any joint because of the possibility of effusion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Mild, short-lasting soreness is a normal response to stretching.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Age itself is a precaution, requiring gentle technique, but it is not a contraindication.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Minimal LBP is the reason for treatment and not a contraindication to treating an adjacent area.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is about to begin intervention of a patient with recent total hip replacement using an anterior approach. Which of the following conditions are contraindications of the hip during early rehabilitation?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Hyperextension is contraindicated because of the anterior approach. This motion would put undue stress on the anterior portion of the hip capsule. Choices A, C, and D are all contraindications for the posterior approach.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Hip flexion beyond 90 degrees is a precaution for a posterior approach.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Hip adduction past neutral is a precaution for a posterior approach.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Hip internal rotation is a precaution for a posterior approach.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following conditions would be a contraindication to performing manual lymphatic drainage techniques over the abdomen?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A menstrual cycle is a concern, but not a direct contraindication. The other conditions involve the digestive tract, and could be worsened with any manual therapy technique.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Undiagnosed pain is a significant red flag and contraindication to any manual therapy in that region.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease, and manual pressure could exacerbate the condition.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Diverticulitis is inflammation of pouches in the digestive tract, and manual pressure is contraindicated.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: Which of the following is proper placement of a catheter bag?

options.text: In the patient’s lap while in a wheelchair
On the patient’s stomach while in a supine position on a hospital bed
Hooked onto the therapist’s pocket during ambulation
Below the waist of the patient

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The catheter bag should always be below the level of the waist. This will keep urine in the catheter line from moving back to the patient and can lead to infection, which can result if urine is allowed to reenter the urinary tract.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Placing the bag in the lap is above the level of the bladder, risking backflow.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Placing the bag on the stomach is above the level of the bladder, risking backflow.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Hooking the bag on the therapist's pocket is not secure and does not guarantee it will remain below the bladder level.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: The physical therapist is beginning a program of functional electrical stimulation (FES) for a patient with T4 paraplegia in order to promote cardiovascular fitness. At what systolic blood pressure should the exercise be terminated?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Exercise should be terminated when systolic blood pressure is 180 mm Hg or above because of the risk of autonomic dysreflexia. Systolic blood pressure should be between 180 mm Hg and 80 mm Hg, diastolic between 120 mm Hg and 50 mm Hg, and heart rate between 160 beats/min and 50 beats/min.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: 140 mm Hg is a normal to moderately elevated systolic pressure and not a termination criterion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: 160 mm Hg is elevated but still within a range that may be acceptable during exercise for some individuals; 180 mm Hg is a more standard cut-off indicating a potentially dangerous hypertensive response.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: 220 mm Hg is severely hypertensive and exercise should have been stopped long before this point.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist decides to use cervical traction for a patient with complaints of cervical pain. Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for cervical traction?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Studies have shown that 15% percent of individuals with Down’s syndrome have atlantoaxial (C1-C2) instability. Instability in that region is a contraindication to cervical traction.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Hyperthyroidism is not a contraindication to cervical traction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Hypertension is a precaution, not an absolute contraindication, but blood pressure should be monitored.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Diabetes is not a contraindication to cervical traction.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following positions should be avoided in postpartum patients?

options.text: Supine with a pillow under the knees
Prone with the knees pulled to the chest

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The uterus moves superiorly in this position. This can cause an air embolism to enter the vagina and uterus. Eventually the embolism could enter the circulatory system through the placental wound.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Side-lying is a safe and common position for postpartum patients.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Side-lying is a safe and common position for postpartum patients.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Supine with a pillow under the knees is a comfortable and safe position.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: When disrobing and draping a patient to prepare for intervention, which of the following is the most important advice?

options.text: Avoid wrinkles in the draping garment.
Do not use the patient’s clothing for draping.
Obtain the patient’s consent before disrobing him or her.
Ask for appropriate assistance in situations where the gender of the patient could be concern.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: All of the above are good advice that needs to be followed, but consent to disrobe is the first and most important choice. Wrinkles can cause areas of pressure, and the patient’s clothing could be soiled. Gender situations could obviously be a cause for concern.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Avoiding wrinkles is good practice to prevent pressure points, but obtaining consent is the primary ethical requirement.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Using a proper drape instead of the patient's clothing is professional practice, but it follows after consent is obtained.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Asking for assistance or a chaperone is important if there are gender or other concerns, but this is part of the consent and communication process.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: At which stage of scar tissue formation can maximal load be placed on the scar tissue without risk of failure?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The order of scar tissue formation consists of the following: inflammatory phase, granulation phase, fibroplastic phase, and maturation phase.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The inflammatory phase is the initial phase where the tissue is weakest.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The granulation phase involves new tissue formation but it is still fragile.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The fibroplastic phase involves collagen deposition, but the tissue has not yet reached its maximal tensile strength.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: What motions should not be stretched early in rehabilitation after an open rotator cuff repair?

options.text: Horizontal abduction, extension, and internal rotation
Horizontal adduction, extension, and internal rotation
Horizontal abduction, flexion, and internal rotation
Horizontal abduction, extension, and external rotation

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Horizontal adduction, extension, and internal rotation would stretch the tissues that are early in the healing process. Care must be taken not to damage these structures in the anterior capsule.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This combination includes internal rotation which would stretch some repaired posterior structures.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This combination includes internal rotation which would stretch some repaired posterior structures.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This combination of movements places stress on the anterior capsule, which is often involved in rotator cuff repairs.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A young patient just starting antidepressant medication is telling you that “life is not worth living.” You should tell the patient not to worry since this is

options.text: experienced by most patients at the beginning of drug therapy
only a transient reaction to the medication and of no consequence
a good sign because the medication has a period of up to 4 weeks before it can take effect
passing but inform the psychiatrist immediately about your conversation

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Antidepressants work slowly (it takes about 4 weeks before antidepressant effects become apparent) but can somewhat “energize” patients early on in drug therapy so that they are more likely to commit suicide. Such suicidal ideas must be mentioned to the treating psychiatrist as soon as possible.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While side effects can occur, suicidal ideation is a serious adverse event that must be acted upon, not dismissed as common.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is a serious and consequential statement that cannot be dismissed.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Suicidal ideation is a serious red flag, not a 'good sign'.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A patient who just returned from abroad is being treated for a worm infection. What precautions do you have to take?

options.text: Reschedule appointment until the patient has stopped taking the worm medication.
Wear a mask and change work cloth after therapy.
Disinfect toilet after the patient has used it.
Do not take special precautions because the drug kills the worms and the eggs.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Antihelminthics kill the worms but do not kill the eggs, which can leave the patient and be passed on to others. Disinfection of the toilet and always informing the individual to wash hands thoroughly is recommended.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: There is no need to reschedule if proper hygiene precautions are taken.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A mask is not necessary as worm infections are typically not spread via respiratory droplets.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is incorrect; the medication may not kill the eggs, which can still be transmissible.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: Your patient is on antipsychotic drug therapy. During your therapy session you notice a number of adverse reactions. The most severe one requiring immediate attention by a physician is

options.text: Increased body temperature with some muscle rigidity
Dizziness with almost fainting when getting up quickly
Appearance of a yellow skin and eyes

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This could be the beginning of a malignant hyperthermia, which requires immediate drug treatment since it could be fatal. The other signs and symptoms are of importance but do not require immediate attention.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This describes orthostatic hypotension, a common side effect but not typically a medical emergency.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This could be a transient side effect and is less concerning than malignant hyperthermia.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This suggests jaundice and liver problems, which are serious but develop more slowly than malignant hyperthermia.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A patient on clopidogrel therapy is at increased risk of experiencing
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Clopidogrel (Plavix) is an antiplatelet agent that inhibits platelet aggregation and can lead to bleeding episodes while the other reactions are unlikely.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Fainting is not a primary side effect, although it could occur secondary to significant blood loss.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Orthostatic hypotension is not a typical side effect of clopidogrel.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Tachycardia is not a typical side effect.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: Smoking involves the inhalation of many compounds that can cause all of the following health problems except
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Nicotine can cause increases in blood pressure and gastritis; tar can cause cancers and emphysema; and CO interferes with oxygen transport in the blood, but alcohol abuse can cause the Korsakoff-Wernicke syndrome (psychosis, memory losses).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Smoking is the primary cause of emphysema.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Smoking is a major risk factor for bladder cancer.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Nicotine in cigarettes causes vasoconstriction and increases blood pressure, contributing to hypertension.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A patient receiving drug therapy experiences a slight fever and sore throat with mouth ulcerations. The physician has to be notified since this could present a/an
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Agranulocytosis manifests itself with a slight fever and a sore throat possibly with ulcerations caused by a deficiency of granulocytes. Thrombotic thrombocytic purpura exhibits bizarre behavior, hemolytic anemia (dark urine) and jaundice (yellowing of eyes and skin) caused by microthrombi. Exfoliate dermatitis is characterized by redness, scaling, and shedding of the skin. Churg-Strauss syndrome is manifested by rashes and nodules under the skin, later on damaging internal organs caused by vasculitis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This condition has different primary symptoms related to clotting and red blood cell destruction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Exfoliative dermatitis involves widespread skin peeling, not primarily mouth ulcers and fever.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is a form of vasculitis with a different clinical presentation.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A patient receiving drug therapy experiences a cough, fever, and rash across the face spreading to the body. The physician has to be notified since this could present a
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Stevens-Johnson syndrome starts with a nonspecific upper respiratory infection, cough, aching, headaches, feverishness followed by a red rash across the face and the trunk of the body spreading later to other parts. Finally the top layer of the skin or epidermis starts to peel off. Epidermal necrolysis manifests itself with fever followed by a rash, redness, blisters, pain and the peeling of the skin from the underlying dermis. Lupus syndrome manifests itself as an inflammation of the joints, mostly fingers, hands and wrists, caused by an autoimmune reaction.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A phototoxic reaction is a sun-induced rash and does not typically present with these systemic flu-like symptoms.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Epidermal necrosis is a feature of SJS, but SJS is the specific syndromic diagnosis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Drug-induced lupus typically presents with joint and muscle pain, fatigue, and fever, but the characteristic peeling rash is less common.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A 78-year-old patient with COPD uses oxygen at all times. At rest, the pulse oximeter reads 91%. During a walk with the physical therapist, the pulse oximeter indicates the O2 saturation has dropped to 85%. What is the MOST appropriate immediate action by the therapist?

options.text: Continue walking but at a slower pace.
Have the patient sit down and rest, monitor O2 saturation and symptoms.
Increase the patient's oxygen flow rate by 2 L/min.
Immediately call for emergency medical assistance.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A drop in O2 saturation to 85% during activity for a patient with COPD on continuous oxygen is significant and indicates hypoxemia. The most appropriate immediate action is to stop the activity, have the patient sit and rest to reduce oxygen demand, and closely monitor their saturation and symptoms. Further action (e.g., notifying nursing/physician, adjusting O2 if per protocol) would follow based on their response to rest.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Continuing to walk, even at a slower pace, would maintain an increased oxygen demand and could worsen hypoxemia.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While increasing oxygen might be necessary, it's generally outside the PT's scope to adjust oxygen flow rates independently without a physician's order or specific protocol. The first step is to reduce demand.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While 85% is low, immediately calling EMS before allowing the patient to rest and recover might be premature unless symptoms are severe or saturation does not improve with rest. Monitoring and then escalating care if needed is appropriate.

subject: Cardiorespiratory

question: What is the primary purpose of conducting a literature review for evidence-based practice?

options.text: To find support for the therapist's preferred treatment approach.
To identify the most current and highest-quality evidence to inform clinical decision-making.
To fulfill continuing education requirements for licensure.
To gather a comprehensive list of all articles ever published on a topic.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Evidence-based practice involves integrating the best available research evidence with clinical expertise and patient values. A literature review is crucial for identifying, appraising, and applying the most current and methodologically sound research to guide clinical decisions.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This represents confirmation bias and is contrary to the principles of EBP, which seeks objective evidence.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While reading literature can contribute to learning, the primary purpose of a review for EBP is clinical decision-making, not just fulfilling CEU credits.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The goal is to find the *best available* evidence, not necessarily *all* evidence. This involves critically appraising and selecting high-quality studies.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: In research, what does 'internal validity' refer to?

options.text: The extent to which the results of a study can be generalized to other populations or settings.
The consistency and repeatability of measurements within a study.
The degree to which the observed effects in a study are due to the independent variable and not confounding factors.
The practical significance or clinical meaningfulness of the study findings.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Internal validity is concerned with the integrity of the study's design and execution, specifically whether the changes in the dependent variable can be confidently attributed to the manipulation of the independent variable, rather than to extraneous or confounding variables.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This describes external validity or generalizability.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This describes reliability.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This relates to clinical significance or effect size, which is different from internal validity.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: A physiotherapist is reading a research article that reports a p-value of < 0.01 for the primary outcome. What does this p-value indicate?

options.text: There is a less than 1% chance that the null hypothesis is true.
The effect size of the intervention is very large.
There is a less than 1% probability that the observed results occurred due to chance if the null hypothesis were true.
The study has high statistical power to detect a difference.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The p-value represents the probability of observing the data (or more extreme data) if the null hypothesis (e.g., no difference between groups) is actually true. A p-value < 0.01 means there's a very small probability (less than 1%) that the observed difference happened by random chance alone, assuming no real effect exists.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The p-value does not directly state the probability of the null hypothesis being true or false; it's about the probability of the data given the null hypothesis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A small p-value indicates statistical significance but does not directly measure the effect size (magnitude of the difference). A statistically significant result can have a small effect size.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Statistical power is the probability of detecting an effect if it truly exists. While related, the p-value is a result of the hypothesis test, not a direct measure of power itself.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: Which of the following research designs is considered the gold standard for determining the effectiveness of an intervention?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) are considered the gold standard for evaluating intervention effectiveness because randomization helps minimize bias by distributing known and unknown confounding factors evenly between groups. The control group allows for comparison against the intervention.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Case series are descriptive studies and cannot establish causality or effectiveness due to lack of a control group and potential for bias.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Cohort studies are observational and can identify associations, but are more prone to confounding than RCTs for determining intervention effectiveness.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Cross-sectional studies assess exposure and outcome at a single point in time and are not suitable for determining intervention effectiveness.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: A physiotherapist is reviewing a study that reports a 95% Confidence Interval (CI) for the mean difference in pain scores between an intervention group and a control group as -2.5 to -0.5 points (on a 10-point scale). What is the most appropriate interpretation of this CI?

options.text: There is a 95% probability that the true mean difference lies between -2.5 and -0.5 points.
If the study were repeated many times, 95% of the calculated CIs would contain the true mean difference.
The intervention is definitely effective because the CI does not include zero.
The p-value for this comparison must be greater than 0.05.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The frequentist interpretation of a 95% CI is that if the same study were conducted multiple times, 95% of the confidence intervals generated would capture the true, unknown population parameter (in this case, the true mean difference). Option A is a common misinterpretation (Bayesian interpretation).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This is a common misinterpretation. The CI itself is fixed once calculated; it either contains the true value or it doesn't. The 95% refers to the long-run performance of the method used to construct the interval.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While a CI not including zero suggests statistical significance (at the corresponding alpha level, e.g., 0.05 for a 95% CI), it doesn't mean the intervention is 'definitely' effective. It implies the observed difference is unlikely due to chance. Clinical significance also needs to be considered.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: If the 95% CI for a difference does not include zero, it implies that the p-value is less than 0.05 (assuming a two-tailed test), not greater.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: Which of the following represents the highest level of evidence in the traditional hierarchy of evidence for intervention studies?

options.text: Systematic review of randomized controlled trials

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Systematic reviews of high-quality randomized controlled trials (RCTs), especially meta-analyses, are considered the highest level of evidence because they synthesize findings from multiple RCTs, providing a more robust and precise estimate of the intervention's effect.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Expert opinion is at the bottom of the evidence hierarchy as it is subjective and not based on rigorous research.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Case-control studies are observational and lower in the hierarchy than RCTs for intervention effectiveness.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While a single RCT is strong evidence, a systematic review of multiple RCTs is generally considered stronger due to increased power and generalizability.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: A study aims to investigate the relationship between physical activity levels and the incidence of low back pain in office workers over a 5-year period. Participants are recruited at baseline, their physical activity is assessed, and they are followed annually to record new episodes of low back pain. This study design is best described as a:
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This describes a prospective cohort study. A cohort (office workers) is identified, exposure (physical activity levels) is assessed at baseline, and then the cohort is followed forward in time (prospectively) to observe the occurrence of the outcome (incidence of low back pain).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A cross-sectional study assesses exposure and outcome at a single point in time, not over a follow-up period.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A case-control study starts by identifying individuals with the outcome (cases) and without the outcome (controls) and then looks back in time (retrospectively) to assess exposure.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A randomized controlled trial involves an intervention assigned by the researcher, which is not described here; this is an observational study.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: When appraising a diagnostic accuracy study, sensitivity refers to:

options.text: The ability of a test to correctly identify individuals who do not have the condition.
The proportion of individuals with the condition who test positive.
The probability that an individual with a positive test actually has the condition.
The consistency of the test results when repeated under the same conditions.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Sensitivity (also known as the true positive rate) measures the proportion of individuals who actually have the disease/condition that are correctly identified as having it by the diagnostic test. A highly sensitive test has few false negatives (SnNOut - a highly Sensitive test, when Negative, rules OUT the condition).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This describes specificity (true negative rate).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This describes the positive predictive value (PPV).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This describes reliability.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: In statistics, what does a Type I error (alpha error) represent?

options.text: Failing to reject a false null hypothesis (false negative).
Rejecting a true null hypothesis (false positive).
The probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis.
An error in data collection leading to biased results.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A Type I error occurs when a statistical test incorrectly rejects a null hypothesis that is actually true. In other words, the study concludes there is an effect or difference when, in reality, no such effect or difference exists in the population (a false positive finding). The probability of making a Type I error is denoted by alpha (α), often set at 0.05.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This describes a Type II error (beta error).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This describes statistical power (1 - β).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While data collection errors can lead to bias, a Type I error is specifically related to the decision made in hypothesis testing.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: A physiotherapist wants to compare the effectiveness of two different exercise programs (Program A and Program B) for improving shoulder function in patients with rotator cuff tendinopathy. Patients are randomly assigned to either Program A or Program B. Shoulder function is measured at baseline and after 8 weeks. What is the most appropriate statistical test to compare the change in shoulder function between the two groups?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: An independent samples t-test is used to compare the means of two independent groups on a continuous outcome variable. In this scenario, the two groups (Program A and Program B) are independent because patients are randomly assigned to one or the other. The outcome is the change in shoulder function (a continuous measure). While ANOVA could also be used for two groups, an independent t-test is more direct.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A paired t-test is used to compare means from the same group at two different time points (e.g., pre-test vs. post-test for one group), or for matched pairs. It's not for comparing two independent groups.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A Chi-square test is used to compare proportions or frequencies of categorical data, not continuous outcomes like shoulder function scores.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: ANOVA is used to compare the means of three or more groups, or for more complex designs. While a one-way ANOVA could handle two groups, the independent t-test is the more specific test for this scenario. If the question involved comparing change scores (post-pre for each person) between the two groups, then an independent t-test on these change scores would be appropriate.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: What is 'selection bias' in research?

options.text: Bias introduced when participants selectively recall past exposures differently based on their outcome status.
Systematic differences between baseline characteristics of the groups that are compared.
Bias that occurs when the measurement of an outcome is influenced by knowledge of the participant's exposure status.
The tendency for studies with statistically significant results to be more likely published than those with non-significant results.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Selection bias occurs when the procedures used to select study participants or assign them to groups result in systematic differences between the groups at the outset of the study. These differences can confound the study's results, making it difficult to determine if observed effects are due to the intervention or pre-existing group differences.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This describes recall bias, a type of information bias.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This describes detection bias or ascertainment bias, a type of information bias.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This describes publication bias.

subject: Research & Evidence-Based Practice

question: A physical therapist is treating a 68-year-old female who sustained a Colles' fracture 8 weeks ago. The patient now presents with severe pain in the hand, swelling, trophic skin changes (shiny, thin skin), and significant sensitivity to touch. These signs are MOST indicative of:
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The constellation of symptoms including severe pain disproportionate to the initial injury, swelling, trophic changes (shiny skin, hair loss/growth changes, nail changes), and allodynia (pain from non-painful stimuli) or hyperalgesia following a fracture is highly characteristic of Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS), formerly known as Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy (RSD).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Carpal tunnel syndrome typically involves pain, numbness, and tingling in the median nerve distribution, not usually the severe widespread pain, swelling, and trophic changes described.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Delayed union might cause localized pain and tenderness at the fracture site but wouldn't typically cause the widespread autonomic and trophic changes seen in CRPS.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: De Quervain's tenosynovitis involves pain and tenderness at the radial styloid process, related to the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons, and does not fit this widespread presentation.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following is considered an absolute contraindication for the use of therapeutic ultrasound?

options.text: Over an area of acute inflammation
Over the epiphyseal plates in children
Over a known or suspected malignancy

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Applying therapeutic ultrasound over a known or suspected malignancy is an absolute contraindication because the increased cellular activity and blood flow stimulated by ultrasound could potentially promote tumor growth or metastasis. This is a widely accepted contraindication in physical therapy practice.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Over acute inflammation is generally a precaution, and pulsed ultrasound is often used in such cases. Continuous ultrasound might be contraindicated or used with caution.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Ultrasound over metal implants is generally considered safe as metal reflects ultrasound waves and does not heat up significantly like it might with diathermy. However, caution is advised around cemented implants or plastic components.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Over epiphyseal plates in children is a strong precaution or relative contraindication, as high-intensity ultrasound could potentially affect bone growth. Low-intensity pulsed ultrasound is sometimes used with caution.

subject: Other Systems (e.g., Integumentary, Amputation)

question: A patient recovering from a stroke exhibits right-sided hemiparesis and significant neglect of the right side. During a dressing task, the patient attempts to put both arms into the left sleeve of the shirt. This is MOST indicative of a deficit in:
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Unilateral spatial neglect (also known as hemineglect or unilateral neglect) is a common consequence of right hemisphere strokes, leading to a failure to report, respond, or orient to stimuli presented to the side contralateral to the lesion (in this case, the right side). Attempting to put both arms into one sleeve, especially on the non-neglected side, while ignoring the affected side during a bilateral task like dressing, is a classic manifestation of neglect. The patient is not processing or attending to the right side of their body or the right side of the task space.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Ideomotor apraxia is a difficulty in carrying out purposeful movements on command or imitation, despite intact motor function and understanding of the task. While possible, the specific error points more directly to neglect of the right arm/space.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Somatognosia (or body schema agnosia) is an impairment in the awareness of body structure and the relationship of body parts to oneself or to others. While neglect can involve a disturbed body schema, the action described is more directly a failure to attend to one side of space/body during a task.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Constructional apraxia is the inability to draw or construct simple two- or three-dimensional forms or figures. This is not directly demonstrated by the dressing error.

subject: Neurology

question: You are treating an elderly patient who is about to be discharged from the hospital following a recent stroke. The patient has some residual hemiparesis but he is oriented, communicates appropriately, and follows safety precautions when performing transfers and walking. You tell the patient that you want to arrange for continued therapy at home or on an outpatient basis to help him regain more strength and motor control. The patient agrees to this discharge plan; however, his son is present and tells you that his father has already had plenty of therapy and just needs to go home and rest. Under what circumstances is this patient's son able to act as his father’s surrogate decision maker?

options.text: The son may act as a surrogate decision maker if his father experienced a temporary or permanent loss for consciousness during his hospitalization.
The son may act as his father’s surrogate decision maker if his father has exceeded his Medicare benefits and cannot afford to pay for additional health care services on his own.
The son may act as a surrogate decision maker if his father has been declared legally incompetent and has appointed the son to act on his behalf via a durable power of attorney.
The son may act as a surrogate decision maker if his father is over 65 and has no spouse or advance directives.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: One purpose of The Patient Self-Determination Act of 1990 was to educate patients about their rights to formulate advance directives for their health care. One type of advance directive is a durable power of attorney for health care decisions. This legal document, signed by the patient, designates an agent, or surrogate, of the patient’s choice. The power only becomes operative when the patient is no longer competent to make his or her own decisions (i.e., must be declared legally incompetent in a court of law).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A history of loss of consciousness does not automatically make the son the surrogate. The patient is currently competent.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Financial status does not determine who is the legal decision-maker.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Age and lack of a spouse do not automatically grant decision-making power to a child, especially when the patient is competent.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: According to the Americans with Disabilities Act, what circumstances would legally preclude an employer from having to hire, or provide accommodations for, a disabled worker?

options.text: If the employer suspects that the worker’s disability is not legitimate
If the employer has to spend more than $500 on accommodations
If the worker is not qualified to perform the essential job functions
If the employment setting is privately owned and employs less than 100 people

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The ADA legislation applies to public and private businesses employing 25 or more people on July 26, 1992, or those with 15 or more people on July 26, 1994. Title I of the ADA prohibits employment discrimination of “a qualified individual with a disability,” which means that the job applicant can perform the essential job functions with or without reasonable accommodations. The employer determines what the essential job functions are and the ADA defines what a disability is. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) provides definitions for “reasonable accommodations.”

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Suspicion is not grounds for preclusion; the employer must engage in an interactive process.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: There is no specific dollar amount. The standard is whether the accommodation poses an 'undue hardship' on the employer, which is relative to the employer's size and resources.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The ADA applies to employers with 15 or more employees.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: Your patient presents with dizziness, lip paresthesias, nystagmus, lower extremity paresthesias, and drop attacks. This would be most indicative of
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The cardinal signs in this question are classic signs of vertebral basilar instability. With a labyrinthine involvement you will mostly get dizziness but not all of the cardinal signs. With a carotid artery tear you may lose consciousness because it supplies the higher centers of the brain. A concussion may cause a variety of symptoms to the head but not drop attacks, lip paresthesias, and lower extremity paresthesias.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While a concussion can cause dizziness, this constellation of symptoms, especially drop attacks and bilateral paresthesias, is highly indicative of posterior circulation (vertebrobasilar) issues.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A labyrinthine syndrome (inner ear issue) would primarily cause vertigo and dizziness but not the other neurological signs like paresthesias and drop attacks.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A carotid artery tear would affect the anterior circulation of the brain, leading to different symptoms (e.g., hemiplegia, aphasia).

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist measures the knee range of motion of a patient status after anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction or repair using a goniometer. After completing the measurement, the therapist concludes that the patient lacks 20 degrees of knee extension and can flex the knee to 95 degrees. Knee flexion range of motion should be documented in the patients chart as
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Goniometric texts recommend recording the starting and ending values for passive range of motion. The patient’s starting point and ending points during the examination is most accurately represented by 20 to 95 degrees of flexion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This notation is sometimes used but can be ambiguous. Simply stating the available range from the starting point to the end point is clearer.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Range of motion is documented from the start position (extension) to the end position (flexion).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The negative sign is not standard notation for a flexion contracture in this context.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist has been asked to determine whether a ramp to enter a local shopping mall meets the minimum accessibility standards required by law. The maximum grade for wheelchair ramps is best identified as for every inch of rise there should be ____ inches of length.
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: According to code, 12 inches of length is necessary for each 1 inch of rise when making an area accessible.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A 1:3 slope would be far too steep and unsafe for a wheelchair.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A 1:6 slope would be too steep and not meet accessibility standards.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A 1:9 slope is closer, but the standard is a 1:12 slope for ramps.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist is educating a patient with low back pain about appropriate body mechanics. The symptoms were reproduced with forward bending and sitting. Which instructions below are most appropriate for that patient?

options.text: Use of a lumbar roll will eliminate your risk of aggravating your back pain.
Bend the hips and knees when reaching down, and try to keep the spine neutral to avoid aggravation.
Lifting light weights is not likely to cause any problems, but lifting heavier items should be avoided.
Consider placing items you reach for frequently overhead to reduce forward bending.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Good body mechanics cannot guarantee pain control, but the use of good body mechanics is critical for patients with low back pain. Lifting light versus heavy being lifted. Heavier items should be placed at waist level not below the waist or overhead.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A lumbar roll can help, but it cannot 'eliminate' the risk.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Even light weights can cause problems if lifted with poor mechanics.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Reaching overhead can increase lumbar lordosis and stress on the spine; it is not a recommended strategy to reduce forward bending.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physician orders gait training for a 14-year-old male with recent open reduction internal fixation of the left femur. Which of the following is not the responsibility of the physical therapist?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Weight-bearing status is the physician’s responsibility.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Assessing balance is a key component of the PT's examination for gait training.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Choosing the appropriate assistive device based on the weight-bearing status and patient factors is a core PT skill.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Assessing endurance is part of the PT's evaluation to determine the patient's capacity for ambulation.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A 3-year-old male sustains a femur fracture after falling off his bike. He received an open reduction internal fixation (ORIF) yesterday. The MD writes an order for PT examination and treatment. He is cleared to ambulate non–weight bearing (NWB) on the affected extremity. The patient’s insurance, however, will only authorize one piece of equipment. What is the most appropriate assistive device for this patient?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Due to the patient’s age and diagnosis, he will have difficulty maintaining NWB status. Balancing on a single limb and coordinating with an assistive device safely will be difficult. Therefore, to reduce the risk of falling and re-injuring the affected extremity, a wheelchair is the safest device for mobility for this patient.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A 3-year-old may have difficulty managing a walker while maintaining a strict NWB status.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Axillary crutches require significant coordination and upper body strength, which would be very difficult for a 3-year-old to manage safely.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A posterior walker also requires the child to ambulate and maintain NWB, which is challenging and risky.

subject: Pediatrics

question: You are a physical therapist that is performing an examination on a 10-week-old infant with a brachial plexus injury. The patient cannot flex his elbow and has residual signs of Horner’s syndrome. The appropriate plan of care is

options.text: Begin passive ROM of the upper extremity immediately
Utilize electrical stimulation to regain biceps function
Refer to a brachial plexus specialty center

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: If complete return of biceps function has not returned by 2 months of age, the infant should be referred to a brachial plexus specialty center. More urgent referrals are needed for a patient with Horner’s syndrome and complete paralysis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While PROM is part of the treatment, the presence of Horner's syndrome indicates a more severe injury that warrants a specialist referral.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Electrical stimulation is not the primary intervention for this condition, especially at this early stage.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The PT does not decide on surgical management; this is determined by the specialist.

subject: Neurology

question: An appropriate physical therapy program for a 2-week old infant with a brachial plexus injury would include teaching the parents how to support the arm while dressing and moving the infant to prevent further injury, and

options.text: Daily PROM exercises including full shoulder abduction and elevation
Daily PROM exercises with shoulder abduction and elevation to only 90 degrees

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The physical therapist can teach parents to perform ROM exercises. Passive ROM is initiated around week 1, and no later than 3 weeks of age, when soft tissue swelling subsides. Shoulder abduction and elevation is limited to 90 degrees for the first 3 weeks.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Functional strengthening is not appropriate for a 2-week-old infant.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Full shoulder abduction and elevation is contraindicated in the initial weeks to avoid overstretching the healing nerves.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While sensory awareness is important, specific serial sensory testing is less of a priority than gentle ROM and protective positioning at this early stage.

subject: Pediatrics

question: A 13-year-old male is referred to physical therapy for left knee pain. During the objective examination, the left hip is found to be limited in flexion, abduction, and internal rotation. Observation also reveals that the left hip is positioned in external rotation in supine and in standing positions. The appropriate plan of care is

options.text: Stretching of the hip extensors and external rotators
TENS and cold pack to the knee for pain management
Strengthening of the quadriceps and gluteus medius

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The patient has a suspected left slipped capital femoral epiphysis. The patient typically presents with an antalgic gait and pain in the groin, and often in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh and knee, but may have pain only in the thigh or knee. The involved extremity is usually held in external rotation and is unable to be moved in to full dorsiflexion and internal rotation ROM.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Stretching is contraindicated as it could worsen the slippage of the femoral head.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Treating the knee pain is addressing a symptom, not the underlying cause at the hip. A medical referral is required.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Strengthening is inappropriate until the underlying hip pathology has been diagnosed and managed by a physician.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)

options.text: Can break off and cause a pulmonary embolism (PE)
Usually occurs in people who are highly mobile
Is usually prevented by daily administration of a thrombolytic
Is a clot that develops in a superficial vein

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A DVT is a blood clot in a deep vein. The most serious complication is that a piece of the clot can break off, travel through the bloodstream to the lungs, and cause a life-threatening pulmonary embolism.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: DVT is associated with immobility, not high mobility, as blood stasis is a major risk factor.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Thrombolytics are used to dissolve existing, life-threatening clots. Prevention is typically managed with anticoagulants (e.g., heparin, warfarin), not thrombolytics.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: DVT, by definition, occurs in a deep vein, not a superficial one.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: Which of the following is an incorrect direction for proper inhaler usage?

options.text: Tilt the head back, open the mouth wide, and inhale a puff from the inhaler.
Place the inhaler in the mouth with the lips sealed securely around mouthpiece.
Press down on the inhaler (actuate) and inhale at the same time.
Hold the breath for approximately 10 seconds.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The mouth and lips should close around the inhaler (the mouth should not be open wide).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is a correct step to ensure the medication is properly inhaled.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This is a correct step, coordinating actuation with inhalation is key to medication delivery.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is a correct step, holding the breath allows the medication to settle in the airways.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: Which is NOT a sign of preeclampsia?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Usually occurring later in second and third trimesters, preeclampsia is a dangerous condition that can affect both mother and baby. Preeclampsia is a new onset of hypertension in pregnancy and is characterized by protein in the urine and high blood pressure. Other changes in vision may occur. Sometimes includes headaches, swelling, or changes in vision.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Hypertension (BP > 140/90) is a defining feature of preeclampsia.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Edema, particularly in the hands and face, is a common sign.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Proteinuria (protein in the urine) is a key diagnostic criterion for preeclampsia.

subject: Other

question: A football athlete with an incomplete C7 spinal cord injury seeks the PT’s opinion about the ability to live independently. The BEST response from the PT would be

options.text: “You will be able to live independently with modifications such as adapted devices for activities of daily living (ADLs), a wheelchair, and sliding board.”
“You can live alone most of the time, but will require a caregiver for such tasks as driving, cooking, and ADLs.”
“Persons with this level of spinal cord lesion will require an attendant.”
“Persons with this level of injury can live independently with a manual wheelchair for mobility.”

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Functional outcomes of a C7 spinal cord lesion are independence in transfers with adapted devices or a sliding board, and independence in ADLs with adapted equipment.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This underestimates the potential for independence. With the right equipment and training, a person with a C7 injury can be independent in these areas.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This is incorrect. A person with a C7 SCI has the potential for independent living.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is only partially correct. It mentions independent mobility but omits the crucial aspect of ADL independence with adaptive equipment.

subject: Neurology

question: During an interview with a new patient on the psychiatric unit, the patient asks if they should divorce their spouse. Your best response would be

options.text: “That’s not a decision that I can make. I don’t know what it is like to be in your situation, but we can talk about it and see if it helps you to make a good decision for yourself.”
“Yes. Your spouse seems to be no good from what you have told me. Go ahead and divorce.”
“If it were me, I’d dump your spouse.”

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Giving advice or sending the patient to her doctor to get the decision made is not appropriate therapeutic behavior. The PT’s role is to help the patient to review her options and encourage her to make the best decision she can for herself.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Deferring to the doctor is avoiding the therapeutic conversation and communication that is needed.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Giving direct advice on a personal life decision is inappropriate and outside the PT's scope of practice.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Giving personal advice is unprofessional and inappropriate.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: During the examination of a patient, the patient says that things are hopeless and “I might as well be dead,” In this case you would

options.text: Ask some questions to find out more.
Tell the patient that those thoughts are stupid.
Ignore it and change the subject to something brighter.
Tell the patient that you have thought about suicide too and that it is normal.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This answer is correct because patients need a written home program with diagrams and instructions. One-on-one teaching is also necessary to ensure the patient understands the program. Bringing in another family member is also definitely advisable to assist the patient with the program at home. Although a social services consult maybe necessary in the long run, it will not help the patient to perform the exercises over the next several days.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is dismissive, judgmental, and completely inappropriate.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Ignoring a statement about suicide is negligent and unsafe.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Normalizing suicidal thoughts is inappropriate and minimizes a serious cry for help.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: In an attempt to establish a home exercise program, the therapist gives a patient written exercises. After 1 week, the patient returns and has not performed any of the exercises. After further questioning, the therapist discovers that the patient is illiterate. What is an inappropriate course of action?

options.text: Go over the exercises in a one-on-one review session.
Give the patient a picture of the exercises.
Give a copy of the exercises to a literate family member.
Contact the physician for a social services consult.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This answer is correct because patients need a written home program with diagrams and instructions. One-on-one teaching is also necessary to ensure the patient understands the program. Bringing in another family member is also definitely advisable to assist the patient with the program at home. Although a social services consult maybe necessary in the long run, it will not help the patient to perform the exercises over the next several days.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This is an appropriate action to ensure understanding through verbal and physical demonstration.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Pictures are an excellent way to provide non-written instructions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Involving a family member (with the patient's consent) is a good strategy to support adherence.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A supervisor in a physical therapy clinic observes a new graduate performing incorrect exercises on a patient. The exercises are not life threatening but are incorrect. What is the best way to handle this situation?

options.text: The supervisor should immediately tell the new therapist to stop exercising the patient and instruct the patient and therapist in the correct procedure.
The supervisor should tactfully tell the new therapist to stop his or her office and discuss the situation in private.
The supervisor should put a note on the new therapist's desk to meet with him/her after work.
The supervisor should give the new therapist research articles about the correct options.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The supervisor can best handle this situation by discussing the exercise program away from the patient. Correcting the new graduate in front of the patient probably would decrease the confidence of the patient in the treatment and the therapist.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Correcting the new therapist in front of the patient undermines their authority and can damage the therapeutic relationship.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This delays the feedback, allowing the incorrect exercise to potentially continue.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While providing research is a good educational tool, the immediate need is to correct the performance in a professional and timely manner.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: The therapist has just returned from an in-service training offering new treatment techniques in wound care. The therapist is willing to share the information with interested members of the hospital staff. What is the best way to share this information?

options.text: Prepare a handout on the new treatment techniques and give it to the members of the hospital staff.
Schedule a mandatory in-service training during lunch for the entire hospital staff who participate in some form of wound care.
Post bulletins in view of all hospital staff and send memos to the department heads inviting everyone to attend an in-service training during lunch.
Call each department head and invite him or her and their staff to an in-service training during lunch.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Posting the in-service training date on the bulletin board and sending a memo to the department heads is the most effective way to invite everyone interested. Scheduling during lunch often makes it easier for people to attend.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A handout alone is a passive form of education and less effective than an interactive in-service.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Making the training mandatory may not be feasible or appropriate. Also, a single lunch session might not be sufficient.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Calling each department head individually is inefficient.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A patient is scheduled to undergo extremely risky heart surgery. The patient seems really worried. During the treatment session, the patient and family look to the therapist for comfort. Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the therapist to the patient?

options.text: “Your physician is the best, and he will take care of you.”
“I know it must be upsetting to face such a difficult situation. Your family and friends are here to support you.”
“Try not to worry. Worrying increases your blood pressure and heart rate, which are two factors that need to be stabilized before surgery.”
