question: A patient is using a statin drug. Which of the following drug-induced signs or symptoms should be reported to the treating physician?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: In a small percentage of patients, statin drugs can cause liver damage (liver function tests are required) and muscle pain, which can lead to rhabdomyolysis (dark urine due to muscle breakdown), a potentially life-threatening condition. The other signs/symptoms are usually not drug related.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Irregular heartbeat is not a common side effect of statins.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Diarrhea is not a common side effect of statins.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Cognitive side effects are rare and less acutely dangerous than rhabdomyolysis.

subject: Pharmacology

question: Statin drugs lower cholesterol by

options.text: Binding to cholesterol in the intestines

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Statin drugs inhibit HMG-CoA reductase and lower cholesterol levels most effectively (about 30 % or more), while the other drugs interfere with absorption and lipase activity.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Drugs like ezetimibe work by preventing cholesterol absorption.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Bile acid sequestrants work by binding to bile acids in the intestine.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Fibrates work by activating lipoprotein lipase.

subject: Pharmacology

question: A patient is being treated with an antiarrhythmic drug. The drug might cause all of the following adverse reactions except
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: All of the listed reactions can be observed, with joint and muscle pain being the exception.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Many antiarrhythmics can cause dizziness and fainting due to their effects on blood pressure and heart rhythm.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Some antiarrhythmics are known to cause this severe skin reaction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Paradoxically, antiarrhythmic drugs can sometimes cause new or worsened arrhythmias (proarrhythmia).

subject: Pharmacology

question: An asthmatic patient is to be exercised in a rather cool environment. It is recommended that the patient use the inhaler

options.text: Just at the beginning of exercise
At the first onset of breathing problems during exercise

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: While the use of an inhaler is user specific, it is generally recommended to have the patient inhale about 20 minutes before exercise, particularly in a cool environment, which seems to aggravate existing asthma.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: 1 hour is too long before exercise; the peak effect of a short-acting beta-agonist will have passed.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Using it at the beginning does not allow the medication to take effect before the exercise stress begins.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is using it as a rescue medication, not for prophylaxis (prevention) of exercise-induced bronchospasm, which is the goal.

subject: Pharmacology

question: A patient using a beta blocker is exercised and might experience all of the following except

options.text: A smaller than expected increase in heart rate

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The reactions described in choices A and C can be expected because of blockade of beta receptors in the lungs and heart, and drowsiness is perhaps caused by a central action. No muscle cramps and pain should be expected.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Non-selective beta blockers can cause bronchoconstriction, leading to breathing difficulties, especially in patients with asthma.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Beta blockers blunt the heart rate response to exercise, so a smaller than expected increase is a hallmark effect.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Drowsiness and fatigue are common side effects of beta blockers.

subject: Pharmacology

question: A beta blocker reduces blood pressure by all of the following actions except

options.text: A reduction in central sympathetic outflow

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Beta receptor blockade, both peripherally and perhaps centrally, causes the blood pressure reducing effects, but peripheral resistance is not reduced but rather might be slightly increased (patient might complain about cold extremities).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Beta blockers reduce heart rate and contractility, thereby reducing cardiac output.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Beta blockers can act centrally to reduce sympathetic outflow from the brain.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Beta blockers inhibit the release of renin from the kidneys, which reduces the activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

subject: Pharmacology

question: A patient on calcium channel blocker therapy might complain during therapy sessions about all of the following except
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Calcium channel blockers will cause all of the listed reactions, except tremors, by interfering with calcium fluxes in blood vessels and cardiac muscle.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: By causing vasodilation, calcium channel blockers can lead to a drop in blood pressure, causing lightheadedness and dizziness.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: While less common than with statins, myalgias (muscle pain) can be a side effect.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Peripheral edema, especially in the ankles, is a very common side effect of calcium channel blockers due to vasodilation.

subject: Pharmacology

question: A patient under the influence of local anesthetic therapy might experience all of the following except
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A local anesthetic that might leak into the general blood circulation can affect the cardiac (bradycardia, hypotension) and central nervous systems (restlessness, tremors, seizures) and can interfere with the functions of sensory nerves and motor neurons.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Sensory impairment is the intended effect of a local anesthetic.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: If the anesthetic enters systemic circulation, it can cause CNS excitement, leading to tremors.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Local anesthetics block nerve conduction, which can affect both sensory and motor nerves, leading to motor deficits.

subject: Pharmacology

question: A patient with angina pectoris experiences some pain during exercise therapy and uses three tablets of sublingual nitroglycerin, but the pain does not subside. You should

options.text: Ask the patient to stretch out quietly and breathe deeply
Tell patient to continue the medication until the pain stops
Call 911 since this could signal a true heart attack
Administer two tablets of a non-narcotic analgesic to help reduce the pain

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Nitroglycerin dilates coronary blood vessels and provides more blood and oxygen to the heart and also reduces peripheral resistance, making it easier for the heart to pump. Both actions eliminate the pain. If no relief is obtained, then this could be a true heart attack.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This does not address the potential medical emergency of unstable angina or myocardial infarction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The standard protocol is typically to take up to three tablets, 5 minutes apart. If pain persists after three tablets, it is a medical emergency.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Administering medication is outside the scope of practice, and an analgesic would mask the symptoms of a potential heart attack.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: Your patient is a 48-year-old male who reports to physical therapy with complaints of left shoulder and neck pain. Symptoms began insidiously 3 weeks ago and have been increasing in frequency and duration since that time. He notices the symptoms with lifting heavy objects and shoveling dirt for a garden that he is building. Walking fast elicits symptoms. Symptoms abate after several minutes of rest. He is in relatively good health with the exception of high blood pressure and shortness of breath. What system is most likely affected?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: All of the symptoms could potentially be related to musculoskeletal problems within the shoulder, but several factors make the cardiovascular system the best answer. The symptoms began insidiously, and many musculoskeletal shoulder issues can be traced back to a single incident or repetitive motions that aggravate and result in damage to musculoskeletal tissue. The patient cannot remember any incident that triggered the symptoms. Most of the symptoms that the patient is reporting can be attributed to the cardiovascular system. Lifting heavy objects, shoveling dirt, walking fast, high blood pressure, and shortness of breath are all symptoms indicative of cardiovascular system involvement.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: While shortness of breath is a pulmonary sign, the constellation of symptoms (exertional pain, relief with rest, neck/shoulder pain) is more classic for cardiac ischemia (angina).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While the pain is in a musculoskeletal location, the pattern of onset with exertion and relief with rest is a hallmark of cardiac-related pain, not typical mechanical pain.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Hepatic issues do not typically present with these symptoms.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: Your patient is a 38-year-old male who is a patient that you have been treating for left shoulder pain. He was in a motor vehicle accident since you last treated him 2 days ago. He was the driver and was rear-ended. He hit his left side on the door handle and has been having sharp pain in his ribs. X-rays the day of the accident revealed fractured ribs (ribs 6 and 7 on the left). He has been having difficulty breathing and has been very short of breath. Sharp pain is noted on the left with breathing and coughing. He has also noticed some blood in his sputum. What system is mostly likely the source of the patient’s symptoms?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Although some of the symptoms could be the result of musculoskeletal system involvement (i.e., rib fracture) or the cardiovascular system (left-sided pain), the best answer is the pulmonary system. The blood in the sputum is an indicator that the ribs may have punctured the lungs. This evidence, coupled with the breathing problems, should move the pulmonary system up as your top hypothesis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While there is a musculoskeletal injury (rib fractures), the blood in the sputum (hemoptysis) and shortness of breath point to a more serious underlying pulmonary injury (e.g., pneumothorax or lung contusion).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: These symptoms are not characteristic of a primary cardiovascular event.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The hepatic system is not indicated by these signs and symptoms.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: Aspirin and clopidogrel (Plavix) fall into which class of antithrombotics?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Aspirin and clopidogrel act as an anticlottlng/anticoagulant medications by preventing platelets from clumping together, thereby making it harder to form a clot.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Thrombolytics (or fibrinolytics) are drugs that actively break down existing clots (e.g., tPA).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Anticoagulants (e.g., heparin, warfarin) work by interfering with the clotting cascade factors, not by inhibiting platelet aggregation directly.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Fibrinolytics are the same as thrombolytics.

subject: Pharmacology

question: Which of the following drugs should angina patients always carry with/on them in case of an angina attack?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Sublingual nitroglycerin acts very quickly to relieve anginal pain by relaxing blood vessels to allow more blood to flow to the heart. Nitroglycerin patches are used to prevent an angina attack but sublingual nitroglycerin is most effective once an attack occurs.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Nitroglycerin patches provide slow, continuous release for prevention, not for treating an acute attack.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: ACE inhibitors are used for long-term management of hypertension and heart failure, not for acute angina relief.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Digoxin is used for heart failure and atrial fibrillation; it is not used for acute angina.

subject: Pharmacology

question: The part of the respiratory system that is most effected by asthma is/are the
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The bronchioles are the smallest branches of the airways and are surrounded by smooth muscle. During an asthma attack, inflammation and muscle contraction occur, narrowing these airways and causing asthma symptoms.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The trachea is the main windpipe and is not the primary site of asthmatic inflammation and bronchoconstriction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The nasal cavity is part of the upper respiratory tract and is not the primary site of asthma.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The bronchi are larger airways that are affected, but the smaller bronchioles are where the most significant obstruction occurs.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: Some of the classes of drugs used to treat angina include
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Angina is caused by decreased blood flow to the heart resulting in pain. Nitrates relax blood vessels, allowing more blood to flow to the heart and thereby decreasing pain.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors (statins) are used to lower cholesterol and are for long-term prevention, not treatment of an acute angina attack.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Alpha-blockers are primarily used to treat hypertension.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Diuretics are used to treat hypertension and fluid overload in heart failure.

subject: Pharmacology

question: Beta-blockers that are useful in the treatment of hypertension

options.text: Work by competitively inhibiting beta receptors, thereby decreasing heart rate
Do not cause bronchoconstriction in patients with asthma
Should not be combined with any other type of antihypertensive

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Beta-blockers block beta1-and beta2-receptors, resulting in decreased heart rate and dilation of blood vessels, which helps decrease hypertension. Unfortunately, they could also trigger an asthma attack in susceptible patients by blocking the beta2-receptors in the lungs.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Beta-blockers can be non-selective (blocking beta-1 and beta-2) or cardioselective (primarily blocking beta-1). They are not always selective.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Non-selective beta-blockers can cause bronchoconstriction by blocking beta-2 receptors in the lungs and are used with caution in patients with asthma.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Beta-blockers are frequently combined with other antihypertensive classes (e.g., diuretics, ACE inhibitors) for better blood pressure control.

subject: Pharmacology

question: Which of the following medications should be used to treat an acute asthma attack?

options.text: An oral steroid such as prednisone
A long-acting beta-agonist such as salmeterol
An inhaled steroid such as fluticasone
A short-acting beta-agonist such as albuterol

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Short-acting beta-agonists, also known as “rescue” meds, act very quickly by binding to the beta2-receptors in the bronchioles, causing relaxation of the airways. They are indicated for asthma attacks and are not useful for long-term control of asthma symptoms.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Oral steroids are used to control severe, persistent asthma or acute exacerbations over several days, but they do not provide immediate relief.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Long-acting beta-agonists are used for long-term control, not for acute rescue.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Inhaled steroids are controller medications used daily to reduce inflammation; they do not provide immediate bronchodilation for an acute attack.

subject: Pharmacology

question: In children with osteogenesis imperfecta, fractures heal
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Healing time is unchanged with this patient population.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: While bones are fragile, the healing process itself is not accelerated.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The healing time is generally normal, not delayed.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While medications like bisphosphonates may be used to increase bone density, they do not fundamentally alter the healing time of a fracture.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Components of lower extremity alignment that contribute to toe in include
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Femoral anteversion is the only one that would account for the internal rotation seen in toe in.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Femoral retroversion would cause an out-toeing gait pattern.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Calcaneovalgus involves an everted heel and abducted forefoot, which is associated with out-toeing.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: External tibial torsion would cause an out-toeing gait pattern.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Osteochondritis dissecans occurs most commonly in the
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The medial femoral condyle is the most common area for osteochondritis dissecans, although it can occur in the femoral capital epiphysis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The capitellum of the humerus can be affected (Panner's disease in children), but the medial femoral condyle is the most common site overall.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: While the humerus can be affected, the knee is more common.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The medial femoral condyle is more commonly affected than the lateral femoral condyle.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The joint most frequently involved in pauciarticular juvenile rheumatoid arthritis is the
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The knee is the most common with this diagnosis followed by the ankles and elbows.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While the cervical spine can be involved in JRA, especially polyarticular forms, the knee is the classic joint for pauciarticular JRA.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The lumbar spine is less commonly affected than large peripheral joints.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The wrist is commonly affected, but the knee is the most frequent site in the pauciarticular form.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The most common onset type of juvenile rheumatoid arthritis is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Pauciarticular juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (RA) occurs in 50% to 60% of the cases, followed by polyarticular RA and then systemic RA.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Systemic onset (Still's disease) is the least common type of JRA.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Juvenile ankylosing spondylitis is a separate condition from JRA.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Polyarticular JRA (involving 5 or more joints) is less common than pauciarticular JRA.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Considering an injury to the medial collateral ligament (MCL) of the knee, when does the inflammatory phase of healing begin?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The healing phase of ligaments is divided into the following categories: inflammatory phase (first few days after injury, proliferative phase (1 to 6 weeks after injury), and remodeling phase (begins at 7 weeks postinjury).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This time frame corresponds to the proliferative phase of healing.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This time frame corresponds to the late proliferative or early remodeling phase.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This time frame corresponds to the remodeling phase.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following types of exercise is most likely to intensify delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS)?

options.text: Concentric exercise is most likely to intensify DOMS.
Eccentric exercise is most likely to intensify DOMS.
Isometric exercise is most likely to intensify DOMS.
DOMS will remain constant no matter the type of exercise.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Since eccentric exercise makes the muscle work the hardest, this type of exercise will exacerbate DOMS. DOMS symptoms are alleviated in 2 to 3 days with stretching and ice application.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Concentric (shortening) contractions cause less muscle damage and soreness than eccentric contractions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Isometric (static) contractions cause minimal muscle damage and soreness compared to dynamic contractions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is incorrect; the type of muscle contraction significantly influences the degree of DOMS.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: What is the correct order of the stages of bone healing after a fracture?

options.text: Inflammatory phase, hard callous phase, soft callous phase, remodeling phase
Inflammatory phase, soft callous phase, hard callous phase, remodeling phase
Remodeling phase, soft callous phase, hard callous phase, inflammatory phase
Remodeling phase, hard callous phase, soft callous phase, inflammatory phase

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Healing phases of bone after fracture are divided into the following categories: Inflammatory phase (immediately after injury), soft callous phase (1 to 6 weeks postinjury), hard callous phase (4 to 6 weeks after injury), and remodeling phase (6 weeks to several months postinjury).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Soft callus formation precedes hard callus formation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This sequence is reversed. The inflammatory phase is first.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This sequence is reversed and jumbled.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: During examination of a patient, the therapist observes significant posterior trunk lean at initial contact (heel strike). Which of the following is the most likely muscle that the therapist needs to focus on during the exercise session in order to minimize this gait deviation?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This gait deviation is caused by the patient leaning back to decrease the flexion moment created at the hip at initial contact. The gluteus maximus is most responsible for counteracting this flexion moment.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Weakness of the gluteus medius would cause a lateral trunk lean (Trendelenburg gait), not a posterior lean.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Weakness of the quadriceps would cause knee instability or buckling, often compensated for by a forward trunk lean or by locking the knee in extension.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The hamstrings act as hip extensors but also knee flexors; weakness of the gluteus maximus is the primary cause of a posterior trunk lean at initial contact.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient presents to an outpatient physical therapy clinic with a 140 degrees kyphoscoliotic curve. What is the therapist’s greatest concern?

options.text: The patient’s complaint of low back pain

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A curve greater than 120 degrees is often associated with restrictive lung dysfunction. The other factors listed are not life threatening.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Low back pain is a common symptom but not the greatest concern compared to vital organ function.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Gait deviations are expected but are secondary to the severe spinal deformity and are not the primary life-affecting concern.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Poor posture is the cause of the problem, not the primary concern. The impact on pulmonary function is the most critical issue.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: After performing an examination, a therapist notes the following information: severe spasticity of plantar flexors in the involved lower extremity; complete loss of active dorsiflexion in the involved lower extremity; minimal spasticity between 0 degrees and 5 degrees of dorsiflexion, with increased spasticity when the ankle is taken into more than 5 degrees of dorsiflexion. Which ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) is most likely contraindicated for the patient, an 87-year-old man who had a stroke 4 weeks ago?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Choice A probably would activate increased tone because of the resistance to plantar flexion offered by the spring.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A posterior leaf spring provides dorsiflexion assist but is flexible, which may be appropriate depending on the level of spasticity.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A hinged AFO allows for controlled plantarflexion and dorsiflexion and could be a suitable option.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A spiral AFO provides some dorsiflexion assist and medial-lateral control, and might be an option.

subject: Neurology

question: The therapist is performing an orthopedic test on a 25-year-old man with the chief complaint of low back pain. The patient has a positive Thomas test. With this information, what might the therapist need to include in the treatment plan?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The Thomas test is a screen to determine whether the hip flexors are too tight.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The Thomas test does not assess hip abductor length.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The Thomas test does not assess hip adductor length.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The Thomas test does not assess hip extensor (e.g., hamstring) length.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient is positioned by the therapist with the cervical spine rotated to the right. The patient then extends the neck as the therapist externally rotates and extends the right upper extremity. The patient is then instructed to hold a deep breath. The radial pulse is palpated in the right upper extremity by the therapist. What type of special test is this, and for what condition is it testing?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Adson’s maneuver tests for thoracic outlet syndrome. Lhermitte’s sign tests for dural irritation in the cervical spine.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Adson's maneuver tests for thoracic outlet syndrome, not cervical disc herniation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Lhermitte's sign involves passive neck flexion and tests for dural irritation, not this maneuver.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Lhermitte's sign is not the test being described.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The therapist observes a patient with the latter stages of Parkinson’s disease during ambulation. Which of the following characteristics is the therapist most likely observing?

options.text: Increased cadence especially at the onset of gait

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A shuffling gait and difficulty with initiating gait are typical signs of Parkinson’s disease. This population would also present with a small base of support.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Parkinsonian gait is characterized by a narrow step width, not increased.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Parkinsonian gait is characterized by a narrow base of support.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Cadence may increase as the patient festinates (takes rapid, short steps), but the initial onset is characterized by difficulty initiating movement (akinesia).

subject: Neurology

question: A therapist is examining the gait pattern of a patient and notes that the pelvis drops inferiorly on the right during the midswing phase of the right lower extremity. The patient also leans laterally to the left with the upper trunk during this phase. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this deviation?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The pelvis is dropping on the right side because the left gluteus medius is weak. The patient also may lean toward the left hip joint to move the center of gravity, making it easier to hold up the right side of the pelvis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Weakness of the right gluteus medius would cause the pelvis to drop on the left side during left swing phase.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Weakness of the adductor longus does not cause a pelvic drop.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Weakness of the adductor longus does not cause a pelvic drop.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The therapist is performing an orthopedic test that involves (1) placing the patient in a side-lying position, (2) placing the superior lower extremity in hip extension and hip abduction, (3) placing the knee of the superior lower extremity in 90 degrees of flexion, and (4) allowing the superior lower extremity to drop into adduction. Failure of the superior lower extremity to drop indicates a tight
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This is called Ober’s test, which screens for a tight iliotibial band.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Iliopsoas tightness is assessed with the Thomas test.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Rectus femoris tightness is assessed with the Ely's test or a modified Thomas test.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Hamstring tightness is assessed with the straight leg raise test.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is assessing radial deviation range of motion at the wrist. The correct position of the goniometer should be as follows: the proximal arm is aligned with the forearm and the distal arm is aligned with the third metacarpal. What should be used as the axis point?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The capitate is the axis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The lunate articulates with the radius and is not the central axis for this movement.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The scaphoid is on the radial side of the wrist and is not the central axis of rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The triquetrum is on the ulnar side of the wrist.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The therapist is assessing a patient’s strength in the right shoulder. The patient has 0 degrees of active shoulder abduction in the standing position. In the supine position, the patient has 42 degrees of active shoulder abduction and 175 degrees of pain-free passive shoulder abduction. What is the correct manual muscle testing grade for the patient’s shoulder abduction?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because the patient does not have 50% of normal range of motion in the gravity eliminated position, 2–/5 is the appropriate grade. Some therapists argue that this is an example of a 1+/5 grade. Sources used in preparation of this exam indicate that there is no grade of 1+/5 with manual muscle testing.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A grade of 3 requires the ability to move through full range of motion against gravity.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A grade of 2+ requires the ability to move through the full range of motion in a gravity-eliminated position and take minimal resistance.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A grade of 1 indicates a palpable contraction with no visible movement.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is examining a patient with poor motor coordination. The therapist observes that when the patient is standing erect and still, she does not respond appropriately when correcting a backward sway of the body. With the body in a fully erect position a slight backward sway should be corrected by the body firing specific muscles in a specific order. Which list is the correct firing order?

options.text: Bilateral abdominals, bilateral quadriceps, bilateral tibialis anterior
Bilateral abdominals, bilateral tibialis anterior, bilateral quadriceps
Bilateral tibialis anterior, bilateral abdominals, bilateral quadriceps
Bilateral tibialis anterior, bilateral quadriceps, bilateral abdominals

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This sequence assists in propelling the center of gravity forward to maintain balance after a backward sway.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This order is incorrect. The response starts at the ankle.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This order is incorrect.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This order is incorrect.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist is performing a functional capacity evaluation on a patient with a L4-L5 herniated disc. Part of the evaluation consists of performing floor to waist lifts using 30 pounds as resistance. During the first trial, the physical therapist notices that the patient exhibits decreased anterior pelvic tilt. What should the physical therapist do during the second trial?

options.text: The therapist should correct the deviation verbally before the lift.
The therapist should correct the deviation with manual contact during the lift.
The therapist should correct the deviation both verbally and manually during the lift.
The therapist should not attempt to correct the lift.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: During a functional capacity evaluation, the physical therapist should not correct postural abnormalities. The therapist should only observe and record.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The purpose of an FCE is to assess capacity, not to provide intervention or correction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The purpose of an FCE is to assess capacity, not to provide intervention or correction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The purpose of an FCE is to assess capacity, not to provide intervention or correction.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is examining a patient with muscular dystrophy. The patient seems to “waddle” when she walks. She rolls the right hip forward when advancing the right lower extremity and the left hip forward when advancing the left lower extremity. Which of the following gait patterns is the patient demonstrating?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This is a description of a dystrophic gait pattern, also called penguin gait. Patients with muscular dystrophy commonly demonstrate this gait pattern. A gluteus maximus gait presents with the patient leaning the trunk back while striking the heel on the involved side (or lurching). An arthrogenic gait pattern presents with the patient circumducting and elevating the hip on the involved side. This pattern is present with severe stiffness or a fused joint in the involved lower extremity. An antalgic gait pattern is exhibited when a person has pain with weight bearing on the involved lower extremity.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Gluteus maximus lurch involves a posterior trunk lean at heel strike.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Arthrogenic gait is due to stiffness or deformity of a joint.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Antalgic gait is a limp due to pain.

subject: Neurology

question: A 48-year-old woman is being examined by a physical therapist. Her diagnosis is right rotator cuff tendinitis. She reports right shoulder weakness and pain for the past 2 months. The patient describes “pins and needles” over the lateral right shoulder and upper extremity, extending into the thumb. She also reports no causative trauma. Manual muscle testing in the right upper extremity reveals the following data: flexion = 4/5, extension = 3+/5, abduction = 3+/5, adduction = 4/5, internal rotation = 3+/5, and external rotation = 3+/5. Manual muscle testing in the left upper extremity reveals the following data: flexion = 4+/5, extension = 5/5, abduction = 5/5, adduction = 4+/5, internal rotation = 4+/5, and external rotation = 4+/5. Active and passive shoulder range of motion is within normal limits and equal bilaterally. All thoracic outlet tests are negative. All shoulder special tests are negative. Which of the following steps would most likely assess the source of the patient’s problems?

options.text: Elbow strength and range of motion testing

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The subjective complaints of “pins and needles” suggest that the source of the problem is either vascular or neurologic. Because thoracic outlet syndrome has been cleared, focus should be placed on the cervical spine.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While there may be elbow weakness, the sensory symptoms (pins and needles) in a C5/C6 dermatomal pattern strongly suggest a cervical origin.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Grip strength testing would assess C8/T1 nerve roots, which does not match the sensory distribution.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While scapular muscle weakness may be present, the primary signs point to a neurological issue originating in the cervical spine.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is screening a patient complaining of pain at the anterior left shoulder region. The pain is increased when the examiner instructs the patient to position the left arm by his side with the elbow flexed at 90 degrees and to actively supinate the forearm against resistance (provided by the examiner). What test is being performed?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Yergason’s test detects tendinitis of the long head of the biceps. Froment’s sign is a test to determine adductor pollicis weakness due to ulnar nerve dysfunction. In the Waldron test, the patient performs squats while the therapist assesses the patella region for crepitus or pain. A positive test indicates possible chondromalacia. A positive Wilson test indicates possible osteochondritis dissecans. The test is performed by asking the patient to extend the knee in the seated position with internal rotation and to maintain that position while the therapist resists flexion of the tibia. The test is positive if there is pain with internal rotation and no pain with external rotation of the tibia.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Froment's sign is a test for ulnar nerve palsy, indicated by flexion of the thumb IP joint when pinching.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The Waldron test is for patellofemoral pain syndrome.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The Wilson test is for osteochondritis dissecans of the knee.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is examining a patient with traumatic injury to the left hand. The therapist asks the patient to place the left hand on the examination table with the palm facing upward. The therapist then holds the second, third, and fifth digits in full extension. The patient is then asked to flex the fourth digit. What movement would be expected by a patient with an uninjured hand, and what muscle or muscles is the therapist restricting?

options.text: The fourth finger would flex at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint only, and the muscle being restricted would be the flexor digitorum superficialis.
The fourth finger would flex at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint only, and the muscle being restricted would be the flexor digitorum profundus.
The fourth finger would flex at the DIP joint only, and the muscle being restricted would be the lumbricals.
The fourth finger would flex at the PIP joint only, and the muscles being restricted would be the palmar interosseous.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The flexor digitorum profundus has four tendons, each attaching to the distal phalanx. If the three mentioned on the chart in question are restricted, flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint in the normal hand would not be possible.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Flexor digitorum superficialis flexes the PIP joint, not the DIP joint. Restricting it would affect PIP flexion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The lumbricals flex the MCP joints and extend the IP joints; they are not the primary finger flexors being tested here.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The palmar interossei adduct the fingers and assist in MCP flexion and IP extension.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient is in prone position with his head rotated to the left side. The left upper extremity is placed at his side and fully internally rotated. The left shoulder is then shrugged toward the chin. The therapist then grasps the midshaft of the patient’s left forearm. The patient is then instructed to “try to reach your feet using just your left arm.” This movement is resisted by the therapist. This test is assessing the strength of what muscle?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This test assesses the strength of the latissimus dorsi. One of the functions of the latissimus is to push up from a sitting position. This test simulates that movement.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The upper trapezius is primarily an elevator and upward rotator of the scapula.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The posterior deltoid is a shoulder extensor and external rotator.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The triceps brachii is an elbow extensor.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following is the normal end-feel perceived by an examiner assessing wrist flexion?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A tissue stretch end-feel is also felt with ankle dorsiflexion. An example of a bone-to-bone end-feel is with knee or elbow extension. Knee flexion is an example of soft tissue approximation. In an empty end-feel, a patient stops the movement due to pain.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Bone to bone end-feel is characteristic of elbow extension.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Soft tissue approximation is characteristic of knee or elbow flexion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: An empty end-feel is always pathological and indicates the patient is limiting the movement due to pain.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is beginning an examination of a patient with a diagnosis of “knee strain.” Range of motion limitation does not follow the normal capsular pattern of the knee. Which of the following are possible causes of the restriction in range of motion?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: All of the choices are capable of causing a noncapsular pattern.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Ligamentous adhesions would cause a non-capsular pattern of restriction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Internal derangement (e.g., meniscal tear) would cause a non-capsular pattern.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Extra-articular lesions (e.g., muscle tightness) would cause a non-capsular pattern.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following statements describes lower extremity positioning in standing during the first 2 years of life of a child with no dysfunction?

options.text: Femoral anteversion, femoral external rotation, foot pronation
Femoral anteversion, femoral internal rotation, foot supination
Femoral retroversion, femoral external rotation, foot pronation
Femoral retroversion, femoral internal rotation, foot supination

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: After the first 2 years of life, the femurs rotate to a more neutral position, and the amount of anteversion decreases.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The compensation for femoral anteversion is external, not internal, rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Infants typically have femoral anteversion, not retroversion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Infants typically have femoral anteversion, not retroversion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient with decreased function of the gluteus minimus is referred to physical therapy for gait training. During the examination, the therapist instructs the patient to extend the hip. Knowing that the gluteus minimus is extremely weak, which of the following is most likely to happen?

options.text: The patient will abduct the hip more than usual when attempting to perform hip extension.
The patient will externally rotate the hip excessively when attempting to perform hip extension.
The patient will excessively flex the knee when attempting to perform hip extension.
The patient will not have difficulty performing straight hip extension.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The patient is prone to excessive external rotation when attempting to extend the hip because the gluteus minimus counteracts the lateral rotational force created by the gluteus maximus.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Gluteus minimus is a hip abductor; weakness would lead to less abduction, not more.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Knee flexion is not a primary compensatory motion for gluteus minimus weakness during hip extension.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The patient will have difficulty controlling the rotation of the femur during hip extension due to the unopposed action of the gluteus maximus.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient is placed in supine position with the knee in 90 degrees of flexion. The foot is stabilized by the therapist’s body on the examination table. The therapist then wraps his fingers around the proximal tibia so that the thumbs are resting along the anteromedial and the anterolateral margins. The therapist then applies a force to pull the tibia forward. What special test is being performed?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The tests in Choices A, B, and C assess the integrity of the anterior cruciate ligament. The pivot shift test is performed with the patient in supine position. The therapist applies a valgus stress with the lower leg internally rotated while passively flexing and extending the knee. A positive test is associated with instability with this motion. Lachman’s test is similar to the anterior drawer test, but the knee is in slight flexion. In performing a posterior drawer test, a posterior force is applied to the tibia to assess posterior cruciate ligament integrity. When assessing these tests, the therapist is assessing the end-feel and amount of joint play to determine the integrity of the ligament.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The pivot shift test involves a valgus force and flexion/extension to assess for rotational instability.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Lachman's test is performed with the knee in 20-30 degrees of flexion, not 90 degrees.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The posterior drawer test involves a posterior force on the tibia, not an anterior one.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is examining a patient who complains of frequent foot, ankle, and knee pain. The therapist asks the patient to assume a standing position with the knees slightly flexed. The therapist then demonstrates active bilateral foot pronation to the patient. When asked to perform this task, the patient has difficulty. What is a possible cause of the patient’s difficulty in performing this task?

options.text: Restriction limiting plantar flexion and lateral rotation of the talus
Restriction limiting dorsiflexion and medial rotation of the talus
Restriction limiting eversion of the calcaneus and medial rotation of the talus
Restriction limiting inversion of the calcaneus and lateral rotation of the talus

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: During pronation of the feet, the calcaneus everts, and the talus medially rotates and plantar flexes.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This describes a restriction of supination components.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This describes a restriction of supination components.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This describes a restriction of supination components.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Of the following, which is the earliest period after surgery that an 18-year-old boy who received an uncomplicated partial meniscectomy of the right knee can perform functional testing, such as a one-leg hop test, for distance?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: At 1 to 2 weeks after surgery, the patient has an inflamed knee, and no functional testing can take place. Six weeks is an appropriate amount of time to allow inflammation to decrease enough for functional testing. Patients who have received a partial meniscectomy do not require as much healing time as patients who have received a meniscus repair.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The knee is still in the acute inflammatory phase, and high-impact functional testing is contraindicated.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: It is still too early for high-impact activities like hopping.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: 12 weeks is a reasonable timeframe, but functional testing can typically begin earlier, around 6 weeks, for a partial meniscectomy.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient presents to therapy with an ankle injury. The therapist has determined that the injury is at the junction of the distal tibia and fibula. Which of the following functions the most in preventing excessive external rotation and posterior displacement of the fibula?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This is the primary function of the anterior inferior tibiofibular ligament.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The posterior inferior tibiofibular ligament primarily resists internal rotation of the fibula.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The interosseous membrane connects the shafts of the tibia and fibula and helps prevent them from splaying apart.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The long plantar ligament is in the foot and supports the arches; it is not part of the distal tibiofibular joint.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is examining a patient who complains of posterior ankle pain. The patient is positioned prone with the feet extended over the edge of the mat. The therapist squeezes the involved gastrocnemius over the middle third of the muscle belly. What test is the therapist performing? What indicates a positive test?

options.text: Thompson’s test, plantar flexion of the ankle
Homan’s test, plantar flexion of the ankle

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Thompson’s test checks the integrity of the Achilles’ tendon. When this test is performed on an ankle with no dysfunction, squeezing the gastrocnemius causes passive plantar flexion of the ankle.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Plantar flexion is the normal response in an uninjured ankle. A positive test for rupture is the absence of this movement.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Homan's test is for deep vein thrombosis and involves passive dorsiflexion, not squeezing the calf.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Homan's test is for deep vein thrombosis, and this is not the procedure for that test.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following is the correct method to test for interossei muscular tightness of the hand?

options.text: Passively flex the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints with the metaphalegeal (MP) joints in extension, then passively flex the PIP joints with the MP joints in flexion. Record the difference in PIP joint passive flexion.
Passively extend the PIP joints with the MP joints in extension, then passively extend the PIP joints with the MP joints in flexion. Record the difference in PIP joint passive flexion.
Passively flex the PIP joints with the MP joints in extension, then passively extend the PIP joints with the MP joints in flexion. Record the difference in PIP joint passive flexion.
Passively extend the PIP joints with the MP joints in extension, then passively flex the PIP joints with the MP joints in flexion. Record the difference in PIP joint passive flexion.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because the interossei cross the MP joints and the PIP joints, the PIP joints should be flexed with the MP joints in extension and then flexion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This describes testing with extension, which does not effectively test for interossei tightness.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This mixes flexion and extension in a way that does not correctly isolate and test for interossei tightness.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This also incorrectly mixes flexion and extension in a way that doesn't follow the standard test procedure.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is beginning an examination of a 34-year-old woman with a diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. Part of the evaluation consists of grip strength testing. To accurately test strength of the flexor digitorum profundus, where should the dynamometer’s adjustable handle be placed?

options.text: 1 inch from the dynamometer’s nonadjustable handle
3 inches from the dynamometer’s nonadjustable handle
1.5 inches from the dynamometer’s nonadjustable handle
4 inches from the dynamometer’s nonadjustable handle

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The last position (3 inches) of the grip strength dynamometer tests the extrinsic muscles of the hand (muscles located in the forearm). The closer positions test the intrinsic muscles.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This handle position would bias the intrinsic muscles of the hand, not the extrinsic flexor digitorum profundus.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This handle position would bias the intrinsic muscles.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This handle position is too wide and would not allow for an effective grip to test maximal strength.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is examining a 17-year-old distance runner with complaints of lateral knee pain. During the evaluation, the therapist performs the following test: The patient is placed in supine position with the hip flexed to 45 degrees and the knee to 90 degrees. The therapist then places firm pressure over the lateral femoral epicondyle and extends the patient’s knee. Pain is felt by the patient at the point of palpation when her knee is 30 degrees from full knee extension. The positive result of this test suggests which of the following structures as the source of pain?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The patient has an irritation of the iliotibial band as it passes over the lateral femoral epicondyle. This occurs at approximately 30 degrees from full knee extension.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The biceps femoris is a hamstring muscle and pain would typically be elicited with resisted knee flexion or hamstring stretch.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The quadriceps are on the anterior aspect of the thigh.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The lateral collateral ligament would be stressed with a varus stress test.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: When ambulating on uneven terrain, how should the subtalar joint be positioned to allow forefoot rotational compensation?

options.text: The subtalar joint should be placed in pronation.
The subtalar joint should be placed in supination.
The subtalar joint should be placed in a neutral position.
The position of the subtalar joint does not influence forefoot compensation.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: When the hindfoot is pronated, the forefoot (transverse tarsal joints) can compensate for uneven terrain. If the hindfoot is supinated, the forefoot also is likely to supinate and possibly cause damage to the lateral ankle ligaments.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: In supination, the midtarsal joints are locked, and the foot becomes a rigid lever, unable to adapt to uneven surfaces.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A neutral position provides some adaptability, but pronation 'unlocks' the midfoot to allow for maximal adaptation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The position of the subtalar joint is the primary determinant of midfoot and forefoot mobility and adaptability.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist begins gait training for a patient with bilateral knee flexion contractures at 30 degrees at a long-term care facility. The therapist knows that the patient will have a forward trunk lean during gait because the patient’s line of gravity
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A patient with severe knee flexion contractures has a line of gravity that is anterior to the hip, posterior to the knee, and anterior to the ankle. This causes a flexion moment at the hip, knee, and ankle.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The line of gravity falls posterior to the knee, creating a flexion moment.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The line of gravity falls anterior to the ankle, creating a dorsiflexion moment.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The line of gravity falls anterior to the hip joint.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: What motion takes place at the lumbar spine with right lower extremity single limb support during the gait cycle?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: To maintain balance, the lumbar spine must laterally flex toward the supporting lower extremity during single-limb support.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The spine laterally flexes towards the stance limb, not away from it, to keep the center of mass over the base of support.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Flexion/extension moments occur, but the primary motion in the frontal plane is lateral flexion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Flexion/extension moments occur, but the primary motion in the frontal plane is lateral flexion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: An outpatient physical therapist is gait-training a patient recently discharged from the hospital. The inpatient therapist’s notes describe a decrease in left stride length due to pain with weight bearing on the right lower extremity. The outpatient therapist knows that the patient will have an abnormally short

options.text: Distance from the left heel strike and the successive right heel strike
Amount of time between the left heel strike and the successive right heel strike
Amount of time in stance phase on the left lower extremity
Distance between the left heel strike and the successive left heel strike

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Choice D is the length of stride during one gait cycle. Choice A describes a decreased step length, choice B describes a decrease in step duration, and choice C describes a decrease in single-limb support time.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This describes the right step length, which would be short due to pain on the right.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This describes the right step time, which would be short.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The patient would spend less time in stance on the painful right leg, and more time on the left leg.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: In the terminal swing phase of gait, what muscles of the foot and ankle are active?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus, and extensor hallucis longus contract concentrically to achieve a neutral ankle position before initial contact.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The gastrocnemius is a plantarflexor and is active during stance phase, not terminal swing.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The tibialis posterior is a plantarflexor and invertor, active during stance phase.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The flexor hallucis longus is a plantarflexor, active during late stance/push-off.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is beginning a gait examination. During heel strike to foot flat on the right lower extremity, which of the following does not normally occur?

options.text: The left side of the pelvis initiates movement in the direction of travel.
The left side of the thorax initiates movement in the direction of travel.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The right shoulder and thorax begin to move forward at heel strike (initial contact).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The contralateral pelvic drop and forward rotation is a normal part of the loading response.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The femur medially rotates as the foot pronates during loading response.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The tibia medially rotates along with the femur during loading response.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: When the knee is at its maximal amount of flexion during the gait cycle, which of the following muscles are active concentrically?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The hamstrings bring the knee to approximately 60 degrees of flexion during acceleration. The hip flexors, ankle dorsiflexors, and toe extensors are also active.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The gluteus maximus is a hip extensor, primarily active during stance phase.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The gastrocnemius is a plantarflexor and knee flexor, primarily active during stance phase.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The flexor hallucis longus is active during push-off.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: When comparing the gait cycle of young adults to the gait cycle of older adults, what would a therapist expect to find?

options.text: The younger population has a shorter step length.
The younger population has a shorter stride length.
The younger population has a shorter period of double support.
The younger population has a decrease in speed of ambulation.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The geriatric population would have a longer period of double support in an attempt to maintain balance. They also would have a shorter step and stride length.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Older adults typically have a shorter step length.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Older adults typically have a shorter stride length.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Older adults typically have a decreased speed of ambulation.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is treating a patient with a venous insufficiency ulcer over the medial malleolus. The wound is moist and not infected. The involved lower extremity is swollen, and the patient reports no pain around the wound. The physician has ordered wound care 3 times/week. Which of the following should be used in intervention of this wound?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A warm whirlpool with the lower extremity in a dependent position is likely to increase the edema. The addition of moist heat is contraindicated for the same reason. There is no need for sharp debridement on a clean wound. A compression pump is often used for increased edema in the extremities.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Placing the leg in a dependent position in a warm whirlpool would likely worsen the edema associated with venous insufficiency.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Sharp debridement is not indicated as there is no necrotic tissue described.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Hot packs are contraindicated as they would increase edema.

subject: Integumentary

question: A physical therapy examination of an infant with osteogenesis imperfecta should include all of the following except
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Since pain responses may be unreliable in this population, PROM is contraindicated. AROM may be measured. Functional ROM is the most important measure at this point.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Assessing for pain is a critical part of the examination.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Observing how the caregiver handles the infant is important for education and identifying potential risks.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Assessing active functional movement is the safest way to evaluate the infant's mobility.

subject: Pediatrics

question: During therapy, a patient with Parkinson’s disease on levodopa/carbidopa therapy might experience all of the following except
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: LevoDOPA/carbidopa can cause all of the listed effects except bradycardia. Due to the off-effect, the patient might have to be scheduled at times when he or she is in the on-phase of the drug

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The 'on-off' phenomenon is a well-known complication of long-term levodopa therapy.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Dizziness and orthostatic hypotension are common side effects.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Dyskinesias (involuntary movements) are a common side effect of long-term levodopa therapy.

subject: Pharmacology

question: The alar ligament stress test is considered positive if

options.text: Laxity is felt in both flexion and extension

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The test is only considered positive if it is lax in two or more planes. This is due to the variation of direction of the fibers as they connect to the alar ligament.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Laxity in neutral alone is not sufficient for a positive test; it must be present in multiple planes.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Laxity in extension alone is not sufficient.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Laxity in flexion alone is not sufficient.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A springy block end-feel in a joint is indicative of
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Cyriax’s classical description describes the obvious cause of a springy end-feel as being that of a torn part of a meniscus in the knee engaging between the bone ends, blocking extension.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A springy block is an abnormal end-feel.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: An inflamed capsule would likely present with a painful, empty end-feel or a capsular end-feel that occurs earlier in the range.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: An unstable joint would likely present with excessive range of motion, not a block.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is examining a patient reporting knee pain. The patient is positioned in a prone position, and the physical therapist passively flexes the knee to end range. Based on the examination technique, which of the following structures would not be expected to limit movement?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Passive flexion of the knee would be expected to place stress on the muscles acting to extend the knee and the joint capsule. The only tissue structure that would not be on “slack” would be the sciatic nerve, which runs along the posterior aspect of the femur.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The anterior joint capsule would be stretched and limit end-range knee flexion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The vastus intermedius is part of the quadriceps and would be stretched, limiting end-range knee flexion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The rectus femoris is a two-joint muscle that flexes the hip and extends the knee; it would be stretched during knee flexion, limiting the movement.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is assessing the posture of a 12-year-old female with cystic fibrosis. All of the following are common postural abnormalities except
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Children with cystic fibrosis commonly have cervical lordosis resulting from thoracic kyphosis. This leads to the scapulae and shoulders to be pushed forward and anteriorly.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Increased thoracic kyphosis is common due to breathing patterns and muscle imbalances.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Forward head posture is a common compensation for an increased thoracic kyphosis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: An increased cervical lordosis is also a compensation for the thoracic kyphosis.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A child loses balance and falls down whenever she tries to catch a ball thrown in her direction; otherwise the child can sit, stand, and walk well. The physical therapist would determine that the child has a problem with
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Children with limited anticipatory postural control have difficulty catching, reaching, or throwing in any posture, as a result of a poor feed-forward control. Protective reactions are mainly to protect the infant from a fall. A problem with development of higher-level balance skills is evidenced by inability to stand on one limb, walk on a balance beam, or hop.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Higher-level balance skills relate more to single-leg stance or walking on a beam.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Protective reactions (e.g., extending the arms) are for preventing injury during a fall, not for preventing the fall itself during a predictable perturbation like catching a ball.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Head righting is a more primitive reflex and is not the primary issue here.

subject: Neurology

question: A grasp that is often used to control tools or other objects is the
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The power grasp often is used to control tools or other objects. The hook grasp is used when strength of grasp must be maintained to carry objects. Lateral pinch is used to exert power

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A hook grasp is used for carrying objects like a briefcase.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A lateral pinch (key pinch) is used for fine motor tasks requiring some force, like turning a key.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A tip pinch is used for picking up very small objects.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Nerve conduction velocity/EMG studies of motor nerves are NOT able to differentiate

options.text: Peripheral nerve disease from anterior horn cell disease
The specific location cord, nerve, root, plexus, or peripheral nerve
Neuromuscular junction disease from peripheral nerve disease
The specific cause or nature of the neural lesion

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Nerve conduction/EMG studies are useful for identifying the possible injury site along the lower motor nerve reflex but cannot provide a definitive clinical diagnosis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: NCV/EMG can differentiate these conditions based on patterns of denervation and nerve conduction velocities.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: These studies are specifically used to help localize the lesion along the peripheral nervous system.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Repetitive nerve stimulation, a part of EMG studies, is used to diagnose neuromuscular junction disorders like myasthenia gravis.

subject: Neurology

question: What is the difference in testing motor function when examining for a nerve root deficit versus a peripheral nerve deficit?

options.text: In peripheral nerve deficit, the motor weakness is evident more rapidly when applying resistance compared with nerve root deficit.
In nerve root deficit, the motor weakness is evident more rapidly when applying resistance compared with peripheral nerve deficit.
In peripheral nerve deficit, the motor weakness is only evident without gravity.
In nerve root deficit, the motor weakness is only evident when applying resistance without gravity.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A lesion of a peripheral nerve produces a complete paralysis of the muscles innervated by this nerve. Weakness is immediately apparent when testing for motor function. A lesion of a unique nerve root produces paresis of the myotome (group of muscles innervated by a single nerve root) innervated by this nerve root. Some time is necessary for the weakness to become apparent when testing for motor function. The isometric contraction must be held for a minimum of 5 seconds.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The opposite is true; weakness from a peripheral nerve lesion is typically more immediate and profound than from a single nerve root lesion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This is incorrect; weakness can be present with or without gravity.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is incorrect; weakness can be present with or without gravity.

subject: Neurology

question: Which impairment occurs in carpal tunnel syndrome?

options.text: Paresthesias over the dorsal aspect of the hand

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Atrophy of the hypothenar eminence is a sign of ulnar nerve lesion, while paresthesias over the dorsal aspect of the hand are symptoms of radial nerve lesion. Decreased resisted thumb abduction and forearm pronation are signs of median nerve lesion, but the motor branches of pronator teres and pronator quadratus arise before the median nerve enters the carpal tunnel.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Hypothenar atrophy is associated with ulnar nerve compression, not median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The dorsal aspect of the hand is primarily innervated by the radial and ulnar nerves.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Forearm pronators are innervated by the median nerve, but the nerve branches off proximal to the carpal tunnel.

subject: Neurology

question: The L4 deep tendon reflex is elicited at the
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: According to Hoppenfeld, the patella deep tendon reflex is innervated by the L4 nerve root via the femoral nerve.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The Achilles tendon reflex tests the S1 nerve root.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: There is no standard femoral tendon reflex.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The medial hamstring reflex tests the L5/S1 nerve roots.

subject: Neurology

question: Differential diagnosis in the infant born with severe calcaneovalgus includes
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: In calcaneovalgus, the forefoot is lateral, the hind foot is in valgus, and the foot is in full dorsiflexion. This results simply from a large infant in too small of a space, and the condition improves spontaneously. Calcaneovalgus should not be confused with a vertical talus. A vertical talus is a serious deformity involving malalignment of the talus and navicular. The forefoot is dorsiflexed, the hind foot is plantar flexed, and the foot bends at the instep.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Metatarsus adductus involves adduction of the forefoot.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: An accessory navicular is an extra bone or piece of cartilage located on the inner side of the foot.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Tarsal coalition is an abnormal connection between two or more bones in the foot.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: What clinical examination technique will establish whether an infant’s hip is dislocated but reducible?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Ortolani’s maneuver involves dislocation of the hip in flexion and adduction. Gentle flexion, abduction, and traction reduce the hip. Ortolani’s maneuver indicates a more unstable hip than the Barlow test.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The Barlow test attempts to dislocate an unstable hip; the Ortolani maneuver attempts to reduce a dislocated hip.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Hoffman's test is a neurological test for upper motor neuron signs.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The Galeazzi maneuver (Allis sign) checks for unequal thigh heights, which can suggest dislocation, but it does not test for reducibility.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: All of the following may be part of the clinical picture of a child in the first 48 hours after onset of osteomyelitis EXCEPT

options.text: Radiographs are positive for signs of infection and avascular necrosis.
Needle aspiration may or may not be produce pus.
The child does not appear sick and has no fever.
High fever and refusal to walk.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Osteomyelitis is a rapid infection of the adolescents often in the distal femur or proximal tibia. Radiographic changes are not seen until 7 to 14 days after onset.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Needle aspiration is a diagnostic tool, and its results can vary.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: In the very early stages, systemic signs like fever may not yet be present.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: High fever and refusal to bear weight are classic signs of osteomyelitis in a child.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: In a child, the most common site of transient synovitis, slipped epiphysis and septic arthritis is the
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Although these diagnoses can occur in most joints, the hip is the most common site of occurrence.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The shoulder is a less common site for these conditions in children.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While the knee can be affected, the hip is the most common site for all three listed conditions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The ankle is a less common site for these conditions.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: All of the following are common in children who have slipped capital femoral epiphysis EXCEPT

options.text: Negative findings on a frog lateral radiograph

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Hip pain is common with this diagnosis, as is a traumatic history; However, a slipped capital femoral epiphysis can have a chronic onset as well. Because a standard anterior or posterior view can miss the slip, the frog leg radiograph will need to be viewed to determine the correct diagnosis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Referred pain to the knee is a very common presentation of hip pathology like SCFE.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Obesity is a major risk factor for SCFE.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: SCFE can occur acutely with trauma or chronically without a specific traumatic event.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following conditions are not implicated in overuse injuries in youth?

options.text: Anatomic malalignment of the lower extremity

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Training errors are not taught vigorously. Musculotendinous imbalances can occur if training overemphasizes a certain muscle group over its antagonist. Malalignment of the lower extremities is seen with muscular imbalances over a period of time. Grass or turf has not been shown to increase risk of overuse injury.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Training errors (e.g., too much, too soon) are a primary cause of overuse injuries.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Muscle imbalances in strength and flexibility are a key contributing factor.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Anatomic malalignment can alter biomechanics and increase stress on tissues, leading to overuse injuries.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The signs and symptoms of juvenile rheumatoid arthritis include all of the following except
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Since juvenile rheumatoid arthritis attacks the joint as in adult rheumatoid arthritis, there are no neurologic signs or symptoms.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Joint swelling (synovitis) is a hallmark of JRA.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Joint stiffness, particularly in the morning, is a classic symptom.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Muscle weakness and atrophy around the affected joints are common due to pain and disuse.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following as an absolute contraindication to initiation of an outpatient cardiac rehabilitation program?

options.text: Patient currently on dialysis 3 days a week because of renal failure

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A third-degree heart block can appear as dizziness and fatigue and may require a pacemaker. Patients with asthma and obesity should be monitored closely but should be permitted to exercise. Dialysis should be scheduled on non-dialysis days.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Obesity is an indication for cardiac rehab, not a contraindication.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Patients on dialysis can participate in cardiac rehab; sessions are simply scheduled around their dialysis appointments.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Asthma is a comorbidity to be managed, but it is not a contraindication to cardiac rehab.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: Fourteen weeks after surgical repair of the rotator cuff, a patient presents with significant deltoid weakness. Range of motion (ROM) is within normal limits and equal bilaterally. Internal and external rotation strength is equal bilaterally; flexion and abduction strength is significantly reduced. What is the most likely cause of this dysfunction?

options.text: Poor compliance with a home exercise program
Tightness of the inferior shoulder capsule
Surgical damage to the musculocutaneous nerve
Surgical damage to the axillary nerve

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The axillary nerve is in close proximity to the surgical field in this patient. ROM is normal so choice B is incorrect; poor compliance would lead to a multitude of problems rather than just deltoid weakness. The musculocutaneous nerve is not involved with this procedure, and it innervates muscles involved in elbow flexion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Poor compliance would likely lead to generalized weakness and stiffness, not isolated deltoid weakness with full ROM.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A tight capsule would result in a loss of passive ROM, which is stated to be normal.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The musculocutaneous nerve innervates the biceps and brachialis; damage would cause weak elbow flexion, not deltoid weakness.

subject: Neurology

question: A patient has recently undergone an acromioplasty. What is the most important goal in early rehabilitation?

options.text: Return to activities of daily living (ADLs)
Return of normal range of motion

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The other choices will be important later in the rehabilitation of this diagnosis. ROM is important early to reduce abnormal scar tissue formation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Strengthening is important, but it typically follows the initial phase of restoring ROM and controlling pain/inflammation.
