rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: These fractures have a high risk of non-union and do not heal predictably with rest alone.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Bone stimulation may be used but is not always sufficient; surgical intervention is often required.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Ankle pain anteriorly

options.text: is usually ligament pain following sprain

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Soft tissue ankle impingement is recognized as a common source of anterior ankle pain following injury. It is more common than bone injury.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A bone bruise can cause anterior ankle pain, but soft tissue impingement is more common.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Osteochondritis dissecans of the talus is a cause of ankle pain but is less common than impingement.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Ligament pain from a sprain is typically located over the specific ligament (e.g., lateral malleolus for an ATFL sprain), not diffusely anterior.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Swimmer’s shoulder
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Swimmer’s shoulder is an impingement of the greater tuberosity against the anterior acromial arch and coracoacromial ligament.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Not all swimmers develop this condition.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: While it can lead to a rotator cuff tear, it is fundamentally an impingement syndrome.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: It is often associated with freestyle and butterfly strokes, which involve significant overhead motion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: During manual muscle testing of knee flexion strength, the physical therapist wishes to differentiate between medial and lateral hamstrings. To test medial hamstrings, the therapist positions the patient in hip

options.text: External rotation to test semimembranosis and biceps femoris
Internal rotation to test semimembranosis and semitendinosis
External rotation to test semimembranosis and semitendinosis
Internal rotation to test biceps femoris

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The medial hamstrings (semimembranosus and semitendinosus) are also internal rotators of the tibia. Positioning the hip in internal rotation biases these muscles during a knee flexion MMT. The lateral hamstring (biceps femoris) is an external rotator.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Biceps femoris is the lateral hamstring and is tested in external rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: External rotation tests the lateral hamstring (biceps femoris).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Biceps femoris is the lateral hamstring; internal rotation tests the medial hamstrings.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient is involved in a rear-end motor vehicle accident and now complains of neck pain, muscle spasm, and decreased cervical range of motion. After performing your subjective examination, the next thing you would most appropriately do is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Based on the history of trauma you must first test AROM before you touch the patient. If there happens to be something serious such as a fracture in the upper cervical spine then motion will be restricted. You will need to send the patient back to a physician before risking injury.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Ligamentous testing is a passive test and should only be performed after active ROM has been cleared.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Muscle testing should be performed after AROM.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Passive range of motion should be performed after active range of motion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The piano key sign is a test used to assess the
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The piano key sign is used specifically for testing for an acromioclavicular separation. Pushing down on the distal clavicle that is elevated from injury will cause it to come back up once the force is released.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The glenoid labrum is tested with tests like the O'Brien's test or crank test.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The long head of the biceps is tested with tests like Speed's test or Yergason's test.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Anterior shoulder stability is tested with the apprehension and relocation tests.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Your patient is a 16 year-old-male who injured his left knee playing football. There was an onset of immediate swelling, a locking sensation, and restricted range of motion. You hypothesize the most likely structure involved is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Based on the symptoms, the most likely cause of the injury is a torn meniscus. There is immediate swelling with blood in the joint, and locking of the joint with restricted range. A and B are extraarticular and will not cause bleeding inside the joint. You will not typically find joint locking with this injury. Cruciate ligament injuries do not usually get immediate swelling unless accompanied by a meniscal injury.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A collateral ligament injury is extra-articular and would not cause immediate, significant swelling (hemarthrosis) or true locking.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A retinaculum tear would cause localized pain and possibly instability but not a locked knee.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: An isolated cruciate ligament tear can cause a hemarthrosis, but the locking sensation is more classic for a meniscal tear.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: You suspect that your patient has a torn rotator cuff. Which three tests would best confirm this diagnosis?

options.text: The lift off test, the anterior apprehension test, and Speed’s test
The drop arm test, crank test, load and shift test
The belly press test, drop arm test, and lift off test
Internal rotation lag sign, drop arm test, crank test

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The only correct answer is C. The load and shift test assesses anterior instability. The crank test in answers B and D is a test for stability of the labrum. Speed’s test assesses the long head of the biceps and the anterior apprehension tests for shoulder instability.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The anterior apprehension and Speed's tests are for instability and biceps pathology, respectively, not rotator cuff tears.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The crank test and load and shift test are for labral and instability issues.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The crank test is for the labrum.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A cause of a noncapsular pattern might be which of the following?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A, B, and C will present with the typical capsular patterns in their respective joint. A loose body in the shoulder will inhibit one plane of motion but will not limit any other motions. Hence, it would not be a capsular pattern.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Arthrosis (osteoarthritis) typically leads to a capsular pattern of restriction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Hemarthrosis (blood in the joint) causes a capsulitis, leading to a capsular pattern.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Septic arthritis (joint infection) causes significant inflammation of the capsule, leading to a capsular pattern.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: In the single leg stance, when the contralateral hip drops because of weakness, it is considered
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The only possible correct answer is B. It is the typical pattern one sees with a Trendelenberg gait, where because of weakness of the gluteus medius on the weight-bearing leg, the hip on the contralateral side lowers.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Hip varus is a deformity of the femur and is not a description of this gait pattern.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A compensated Trendelenburg involves a lateral trunk lean over the stance limb to keep the pelvis level; it does not involve a hip drop.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Hip varus is not the correct term for this gait deviation.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Your patient has sustained a fracture of the coronoid process. Which of the following is most true about these fractures?

options.text: It is more commonly an isolated fracture.
It is more often accompanied by avulsion of the biceps.
Fractures of the coronoid process account for better than 50% of elbow fractures.
Fractures of the coronoid process are usually accompanied by a radial head fracture.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Coronoid fractures seldom are isolated fractures. They are usually accompanied by radial head fractures. The brachialis is the muscle usually avulsed. Coronoid fractures only account for 1% to 2% of all elbow fractures.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Coronoid fractures are rarely isolated.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The brachialis muscle inserts on the coronoid process and can be avulsed, not the biceps.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: They are relatively uncommon, accounting for only 1-2% of elbow fractures.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 45-year-old male electrician presents with a gradual onset of left shoulder pain. He notes it is most prominent with overhead activities and throwing. The position that hurts his shoulder the most is 90 degrees of flexion with internal rotation. This most likely indicates
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This is a classic sign of an impingement. The test for this is a Hawkins Kennedy test. A patient with instability will present with a loose joint that feels like it is going to sublux. Patients with SLAP lesions will complain of intermittent painful popping, clunking, or clicking in the shoulder with occasional catches. An impingement will be most painful in certain positions such as extreme overhead reaches and with the test position just described.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A SLAP lesion would more likely present with clicking, popping, or catching sensations.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Anterior instability is typically provoked by abduction and external rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Posterior instability is less common and is provoked by flexion, adduction, and internal rotation.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Your patient presents with pain and tenderness over the distal radial forearm and with resistive thumb extension after using a screwdriver repeatedly for several days. Based on this history, the most likely diagnosis is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This is a classical description of a De Quivrain’s syndrome, which is a tendinitis of the abductor pollicus longus and extensor pollicus brevis. Gout will cause the thumb to be painful, but will not respond to stretch because it affects the joint and not the surrounding musculature. A scaphoid instability will be painful to certain movements accompanied by pops and cracks. It is an inert tissue and will not respond to stretch or resistance. Radial carpal syndrome is an impingement syndrome that takes place at the wrist.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Scaphoid instability would likely present with a click or clunk and pain localized over the scaphoid.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Gout is an inflammatory arthritis and would present with signs of acute inflammation (redness, swelling, severe pain) and is less likely to be caused by this mechanism.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is not a standard clinical diagnosis.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: You find that a patient has a leg length discrepancy. Upon review of their radiographs, you notice that the angle of the neck of the femur to the femoral shaft is less than 120 degrees. You have determined that the apparent leg length difference is due to
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This is classic description of a coxa varum, first described radiographically by Hofmeister in 1894. A coxa valgum has an angle of above 140 degrees. An acetabular tropism describes changes in the acetabular surface. Pelvic obliquity describes angulation of the pelvis from the horizontal in the frontal plane, possibly secondary to a contraction below the pelvis (e.g., of the hip joint).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A pelvic obliquity can cause a functional leg length discrepancy, but it is not defined by the femoral neck angle.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Coxa valga is an angle greater than 135 degrees, which would result in a functionally longer leg.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Acetabular tropism refers to the orientation of the acetabulum, not the femoral angle.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Your patient presents with a non-contact injury from a quick stop. He reports an audible “pop” at the time of injury. He complains of pain on either side of his patella. He now complains of difficulty with cutting and pivoting when running. The patient did not have immediate swelling or joint line tenderness. The structure most likely involved is the
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The anterior cruciate is one of the most commonly injured ligaments without contact. Injuries to the posterior collateral ligament (PCL) do not usually feel the “pop” that the ACL does. They are usually injured from hitting a dash board or falling on a bent knee in which the force is taken by the tibia in a posterior direction. The meniscus injury will present with popping, catching, locking, and immediate joint swelling. The medial collateral ligament usually is exquisitely tender over the ligament and usually is torn with a lateral force.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A meniscal tear often presents with locking, catching, and joint line tenderness, which are absent here.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: An MCL injury is typically caused by a valgus force and would present with tenderness over the medial joint line.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A PCL injury is less common and is usually caused by a direct blow to the anterior tibia or a fall onto a flexed knee.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Your patient has been diagnosed as having pronator syndrome. You have determined that the structure involved is the lacertus fibrosis. The maneuver that would verify this is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: There are four structures that are responsible for the pronator syndrome: the flexor digitorum arcade, the lacertus fibrosis, the pronator teres, and supracondylar process. The lacertus fibrosis is tested by resisted supination.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This position does not specifically stress the structures involved in pronator syndrome.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Resisted supination would not stress the structures causing pronator syndrome.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Resisted long finger flexion would test the flexor digitorum superficialis and profundus, which can be involved, but resisted pronation is the more direct test.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient reports to physical therapy with a referral from his primary care physician that reads “suspected partial biceps tear—evaluate and treat.” The patient sustained the injury 2 days ago during soccer practice. Which of the following objective findings would be most consistent with the patient’s condition during the physical examination?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Resisting forearm supination should place stress on the biceps brachii which functions as both an elbow flexor and forearm supinator. Resisting this action, therefore, which is suspected of a lesion, is one way to implicate or verify involvement of the tissue structure. Any decision is based on the pattern of pain elicited by both active and passive movements. The findings in the clinical case presented in the question begin to implicate or verifies involvement of the biceps.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Passive shoulder abduction would not stress the biceps tendon.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Resisted shoulder extension would test the posterior deltoid and latissimus dorsi.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Resisted elbow extension would test the triceps.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: During ambulation, a physical therapist notices that the patient is exhibiting genu recurvatum during the stance phase of the gait cycle. Of the choices listed below, the MOST LIKELY cause for the observed gait deviation is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Tightness of the gastrocsuleus muscle complex can cause a loss of dorsiflexion at the ankle. Having adequate ankle dorsiflexion throughout the stance phases of gait is important to the kinematics of tibial movement. When there is inadequate ankle dorsiflexion, which can occur due to gastrocsuleus tightness, one common finding is knee hyperextension or genu recurvatum.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Tight gluteus maximus does not directly cause genu recurvatum.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Tight hip flexors can alter pelvic and trunk position but are not a primary cause of genu recurvatum.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Tight dorsiflexors would limit plantar flexion, which is not associated with genu recurvatum during stance.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is performing a manual muscle test on a patient with reported lower extremity weakness. When examining the patient’s ability to plantarflex the foot in a prone position, suspicion arises that the patient is using the tibialis posterior as a substitute for significant gastrocnemius-soleus weakness. The therapist’s hypothesis is based on the following observation

options.text: The foot moves into eversion and plantar flexion
The foot moves into inversion and plantar flexion
The forefoot moves into plantar flex
The toes flex as the foot plantar flexes

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The observed action of the foot would be consistent with motion produced by the tibialis posterior. The tibialis posterior plantar flexes and inverts the foot.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Eversion would be produced by the peroneal muscles, not the tibialis posterior.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This is too general; the specific combination of plantar flexion and inversion is key.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Toe flexion is produced by the flexor digitorum and hallucis longus, which also assist with plantar flexion but are not the primary muscle for inversion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient is reporting hip pain. When measuring with a goniometer, the patient had 0 to 60 degrees of passive hip internal rotation. This finding is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Based on the values provided by the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons, the clinical finding exceeds the expected normal range of motion for hip internal rotation, which is 0 to 45 degrees.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Normal hip internal rotation ROM is approximately 0 to 45 degrees. 60 degrees is excessive.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This indicates hypermobility (excessive motion), not hypomobility (restricted motion).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A capsular pattern of the hip involves greater restriction of flexion, abduction, and internal rotation, not excessive internal rotation.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is treating a patient who has bilaterally “weak” knee and hip extensors. The patient is most likely to have the greatest difficulty performing which of the following functional activities?

options.text: Transferring from a wheelchair to a mat

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Transferring from a sitting to a standing position will pose the greatest challenge because of the need to generate force in the extensor muscles. Going from sitting to standing requires the recruitment of the hip and knee extensors.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While this requires strength, it is often performed as a lateral transfer and may not demand as much concentric extensor power as rising from a chair.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Rolling primarily uses core and rotational muscles, not powerful hip and knee extensors.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Moving from sitting to supine is a controlled eccentric movement and generally requires less force than sit-to-stand.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Your patient is a 21-year-old male who reports to you with ongoing pain and stiffness. This has been going for the past several months. He has been experiencing difficulties breathing and has noticed a difficulty with cervical flexion. The stiffness is most prevalent in the morning with cervical flexion. He has noticed a low grade fever over the past several weeks. What pathology is most likely the source of the patient’s symptoms?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Classic symptoms of anklylosing spondylitis include insidious onset of worsening, dull, lumbosacral back pain; progressive morning stiffness; pain in the sacroiliac region; prolonged stiffness with inactivity; absence of neurologic signs; tenderness at the sacral ligaments; and chest pain with deep breathing.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Rheumatoid arthritis typically affects peripheral joints symmetrically before significant spinal involvement.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Systemic lupus erythematosus can cause arthritis but this specific pattern of spinal stiffness and respiratory involvement is classic for AS.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular junction disorder causing fatigable muscle weakness, not inflammatory spinal stiffness.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: During a home health visit, the physical therapist observed several items that require modification in the home of an elderly patient. In terms of priority, the environmental hazard that needs the most immediate attention is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The presence of a throw rug could result in a fall, which would be far more hazardous to the health of an elderly client than the other objects in the environment. In the elderly, falls are the major cause of fractures.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A cracked toilet seat is a hazard and could cause a skin tear, but it is less likely to cause a major fall compared to a throw rug.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A malfunctioning thermostat affects comfort and could pose a risk, but it is not an immediate fall hazard.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A cluttered kitchen is a fall hazard, but a throw rug is a specific, high-risk item for tripping that requires immediate removal.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist is treating a patient who received an above-elbow amputation 2 years ago. The prosthesis has a split cable that controls the elbow and the terminal device. With this type of prosthesis, the patient must first lock the elbow to allow the cable to activate the terminal device. This is accomplished with what movements?

options.text: Extending the humerus and elevating the scapula
Extending the humerus and retracting the scapula
Extending the humerus and protracting the scapula
Extending the humerus and depressing the scapula

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: To lock the elbow with this type of prosthesis, the patient must extend the humerus and depress the scapula.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Scapular elevation would increase tension on the control cable, which is the opposite of the motion required to engage the lock.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Retracting the scapula is a component of operating the terminal device, not locking the elbow.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Protracting the scapula is not the correct motion for locking the elbow.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is treating a patient with a Colles fracture. The patient’s forearm has been immobilized for 3 weeks and will require 4 additional weeks in the cast before the patient can begin functional tasks. An initial focus of treatment should be

options.text: Placement of the extremity in a sling
Movement of the joints surrounding the fracture
To avoid treatment until the cast is removed

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Fractured sites should remain stable to promote healing and realignment of the bones. However, the PT should encourage the movement of adjacent joints to assist in maintaining muscle strength and lengthening of tendons and muscles.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: PROM of the fractured site itself is contraindicated during immobilization.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A sling may not be necessary and could lead to stiffness at the shoulder and elbow if not used judiciously.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Avoiding all treatment is inappropriate; maintaining mobility in the surrounding joints (fingers, elbow, shoulder) is crucial to prevent secondary complications.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: During a treatment session, the physical therapist observes that the patient can flex the affected shoulder through its full ROM in a side-lying position. The PT should progress to activities that place the extremity in
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: If grading shoulder flexion, the next step after achieving full shoulder flexion in a side-lying position is to begin to work or perform activities against gravity to begin increasing strength. Shoulder flexion against gravity is achieved with the individual in the sitting or standing position.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A gravity-assisted position would be a regression, not a progression.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The patient has already demonstrated full ROM in a gravity-eliminated (side-lying) position, so this would not be a progression.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This is too vague. The next logical step in the strengthening progression is against gravity.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which activity would the PT caution a patient with a recent hip replacement to avoid?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A person with a hip replacement should avoid any activity, such as shoe tying, which could potentially cause hip flexion to 90 degrees or greater. Such a position could actually undo the benefits of the surgical procedure.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Pulling up pants can be done safely while observing hip precautions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Putting on a shirt does not involve the lower body and does not violate hip precautions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Bathing the back does not require excessive hip flexion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: During a treatment session, the PT simulates the need for the client to walk up stairs to a kitchen with a painful/weak left leg. The patient should be instructed to move the

options.text: Left leg up to the next step with the cane
Right leg up to the next step with the cane
Right leg up and then his left leg/cane
Left leg up and then his right leg/cane

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: When ascending or descending stairs, the cane should move with the painful/weak leg. Specifically, when ascending the stairs the leg should move first, allowing the weak leg and cane to bear the weight for only a short amount of time until the strong leg is able to provide the needed stability.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This is incorrect. The strong leg should lead when ascending stairs.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is incorrect. The cane should move with the affected (left) leg.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is incorrect. The strong leg should lead when ascending stairs ('up with the good').

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: You are working with a 53-year-old client who has had a right CVA. The patient is on a therapy mat, and you are performing passive ROM to her left arm. Once you have the patient’s arm in 90 degrees of flexion, the patient complains of some discomfort and pain. The best course of action would be to

options.text: Continue as tolerated, because passive ROM must be maintained
Begin the ROM again and make sure the scapula is gliding
Continue and do not go past the point of pain

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Discomfort and damage can occur if the scapula is not gliding with the humerus during movement. Passive ROM can cause damage if the structures are not moving properly. An orthopedic specialist may be beneficial if therapy interventions have not been successful.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Continuing to push through pain without addressing the cause could lead to injury (e.g., impingement).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While not pushing past pain is correct, it doesn't address the underlying reason for the pain, which is likely poor scapulohumeral rhythm.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Consulting a specialist is premature. The first step is to ensure proper technique is being used.

subject: Neurology

question: The BEST strategy to use with a contracted joint that has a soft end field is to
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The term “soft end field” is a spongy quality at end range of a joint contracture. It usually indicates that the joint has the potential to remodel. A low-load, long duration stretch may yield the best results.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Tendon gliding exercises are specific for improving tendon excursion within its sheath, not for treating a joint contracture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A quick stretch is used to elicit a muscle spindle reflex (stretch reflex) and is not appropriate for stretching a contracture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Active ROM may not be sufficient to provide the prolonged stretch needed to remodel a soft tissue contracture.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following is considered an absolute contraindication to manipulation?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Acute myelopathy is considered an absolute contraindication to manipulation. This may be seen in cervical spondylotic myelopathy. Smoking, hypertension, and use of birth control pills are considered risks for vertebrobasilar insufficiency.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: These are relative precautions or risk factors for vertebral artery issues, not absolute contraindications to all manipulation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A whiplash injury requires careful assessment, but it is not an absolute contraindication to all manipulation, depending on the findings.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: These are relative precautions/risk factors, not absolute contraindications.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following disc herniations would you expect to respond MOST favorably to traction therapy?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: When the disc is in the axilla of the nerve root (medial), axial traction may irritate the problem.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A medial (axillary) herniation can be worsened by traction as the nerve root is pulled taught against the bulge.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Anterior herniations are rare and typically do not cause nerve root compression that would be treated with traction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is too general. The position relative to the nerve root (lateral vs. medial) is the key determinant.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: For the best protection of lumbar mechanics, the driver’s car seat should be positioned

options.text: As far from the steering wheel as possible
With the front of the seat lower than the back of the seat
With the entire seat bottom level with the floor of the car
As close to the steering wheel as practical

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: With the seat close to the pedals, the lumbopelvic region is flexed, separating the posterior facets and disc space at L5-S1. Adding a lumbar pillow supports the lumbar curve at the same time.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Being too far from the wheel encourages reaching and poor posture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This would promote a posterior pelvic tilt and lumbar flexion, increasing disc pressure.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This does not consider the optimal positioning for hip and knee flexion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A pitcher is exercising in a clinic with a sports cord mounted behind and above his head. The pitcher simulates the pitching motion using the sports cord as resistance. Which proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) diagonal is the pitcher using to strengthen the muscles involved in pitching a baseball?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The pitcher is moving into D2 extension with the throwing motion. He is strengthening the muscles involved in shoulder internal rotation, adduction, and forearm pronation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: D1 extension involves shoulder extension, abduction, and internal rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: D1 flexion involves shoulder flexion, adduction, and external rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: D2 flexion involves shoulder flexion, abduction, and external rotation.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is mobilizing a patient’s right shoulder. The movement taking place at the joint capsule is not completely to end range. It is a large-amplitude movement from near the beginning of available range to near the end of available range. What grade mobilization, according to Maitland, is being performed?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Grade I is a small oscillating movement at the beginning of range. Grade III is a large movement up to the end of available range. Grade IV is a small movement at the end of available range.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Grade I is a small amplitude oscillation at the beginning of the range, used for pain.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Grade II is a large amplitude oscillation within the pain-free range, also used for pain.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Grade IV is a small amplitude oscillation at the end of the range, used for stiffness.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 29-year-old woman is referred to a therapist with a diagnosis of recurrent ankle sprains. The patient has a history of several inversion ankle sprains within the past year. No edema or redness is noted at this time. Which of the following is the best treatment plan?

options.text: Gastrocnemius stretching, ankle strengthening, and ice
Rest, ice, compression, elevation, and ankle strengthening
Ankle strengthening and a proprioception program
Rest, ice, compression, elevation, and gastrocnemius stretching

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Patients with recurrent ankle sprains benefit from proprioceptive exercises. Choices B and D are not indicated because of the lack of acute signs and symptoms. Choice A is a good plan, but not the most correct because there is no mention of proprioception.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This plan is incomplete as it lacks proprioceptive/balance training, which is crucial for preventing recurrent sprains.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: RICE protocol is for acute injuries. This patient has a chronic instability problem, not an acute sprain.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: RICE is for acute injuries, and this plan also omits the critical proprioceptive component.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The therapist is treating a male patient for a second-degree acromioclavicular sprain. The patient has just finished the doctor’s prescription of 3 sessions/week for 4 weeks. The therapist is treating the patient with iontophoresis (driving dexamethasone), deltoid-strengthening exercises, pectoral strengthening exercises, and ice. The patient reports no decline in pain level since the initial examination. Which of the following is the best course of action for the therapist?

options.text: Phone the doctor and request continued physical therapy.
Tell the patient to go back to the doctor because he is not making appropriate progress.
Discharge the patient because he will improve on his own.
Take the problem to the supervisor of the facility.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The patient should have made adequate progress in this period with this protocol. Because of the lack of progress, the patient needs further evaluation by the physician.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Requesting more of the same therapy that is not working is not clinically indicated. The patient needs re-evaluation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Discharging a patient who is not progressing is inappropriate. They need a different plan, which starts with re-evaluation by the physician.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While a supervisor could be consulted, the primary responsibility is to ensure the patient gets appropriate medical follow-up due to the lack of progress.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A therapist working in an outpatient therapy clinic examines a patient with a diagnosis of rotator cuff bursitis. The physician’s order is to examine and treat. During the examination the following facts are revealed: Active shoulder flexion = 85 degrees with pain, Passive shoulder flexion = 177 degrees, Active shoulder abduction = 93 degrees with pain, Passive shoulder abduction = 181 degrees, Active external rotation = 13 degrees with pain, Passive external rotation = 87 degrees, Drop arm test = positive, Impingement test = negative, Biceps tendon subluxation test = negative, Sulcus sign = negative. Of the following, which is the best course of action?

options.text: Treat the patient for 1 week with moist heat application, joint mobilization, and strengthening. Then suggest to the patient that he or she return to the physician if there are no positive results.
Treat the patient for 1 week with ultrasound, strengthening, and ice. Then suggest to the patient that he or she return to the physician if there are no positive results.

Treat the patient for 1 week with a home exercise program, strengthening, passive range of motion by the therapist, and ice. Then suggest to the patient that he or she return to the physician if there are no positive results.
Treat the patient for 1 week with a home exercise program, and ice. Then suggest to the patient that he or she return to the physician if there are no positive results.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The patient most likely has a rotator cuff tear. Choices A and B are incorrect because there is no need for heating modalities. Choice C is wrong because the patient has full passive range of motion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Moist heat is generally not indicated for an acute inflammatory condition like a suspected tear. Joint mobilization may be contraindicated.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Ultrasound may not be the most effective treatment. The key findings point away from simple bursitis and towards a tear, warranting a conservative approach and likely physician follow-up.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Passive range of motion is already full, so performing it as a primary treatment is unnecessary.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The therapist is crutch training a 26-year-old man who underwent right knee arthroscopy 10 hours ago. The patient’s weight-bearing status is toe-touch weight-bearing on the right lower extremity. If the patient is going up steps, which of the following is the correct sequence of verbal instructions?

options.text: “Have someone stand below you while going up, bring the left leg up first, then the crutches and the right leg.”
“Have someone stand above you while going up, bring the left leg up first, then the crutches and the right leg.”
“Have someone stand below you while going up, bring the right leg up first, then the crutches and the left leg.”
“Have someone stand above you while going up, bring the right leg up first, then the crutches and the left leg.”

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Choice A is the correct gait sequence for ascending stairs in the given scenario. A caregiver should stand below the patient in the given scenario. The same rule holds true for descending stairs.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The caregiver should stand below the patient for safety when ascending.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The rule is 'up with the good', so the unaffected (left) leg should go first.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The caregiver should stand below, and the good (left) leg should go first.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: What is the best way to first exercise the postural (or extensor) musculature when it is extremely weak to facilitate muscle control?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Isometric exercises in the shortest range of the extensor muscle are used to begin strengthening. In contrast, weak flexor muscles should be strengthened in the middle-to-lengthened range, because they most often work near their end range.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Concentric exercises require moving against gravity, which may be too difficult if the muscle is extremely weak.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Eccentric exercises can generate high forces and may be too demanding for a very weak muscle initially.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Isokinetic exercise requires specialized equipment and is not the first step in activating extremely weak muscles.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 42-year-old receptionist presents to an outpatient physical therapy clinic with low back pain. The therapist decides that postural modification needs to be part of the treatment plan. What is the best position for the lower extremities while the patient is sitting?

options.text: 90 degrees of hip flexion, 90 degrees of knee flexion, and 10 degrees of dorsiflexion
60 degrees of hip flexion, 90 degrees of knee flexion, and 0 degrees of dorsiflexion
110 degrees of hip flexion, 80 degrees of knee flexion, and 10 degrees of dorsiflexion
90 degrees of hip flexion, 90 degrees of knee flexion, and 0 degrees of dorsiflexion

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This position places the least amount of stress on the lumbar spine in the sitting position.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: 10 degrees of dorsiflexion is not necessary for an optimal sitting posture; a neutral ankle is sufficient.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: 60 degrees of hip flexion is too open an angle and may promote a slouched posture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: 110 degrees of hip flexion is excessive and would promote a posterior pelvic tilt and lumbar flexion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 67-year-old woman presents to an outpatient facility with a diagnosis of right adhesive capsulitis. The therapist plans to focus mostly on gaining abduction range of motion. In which direction should the therapist mobilize the shoulder to gain abduction range of motion?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The therapist must stretch the inferior portion of the capsule in an effort to gain abduction of the involved shoulder. This principle is supported by the convex-concave rule.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A posterior glide is used to increase flexion and internal rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: An anterior glide is used to increase extension and external rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A superior glide is not a standard mobilization technique and would likely cause impingement.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient is positioned in the supine position. The involved left upper extremity is positioned in 90 degrees of shoulder flexion. The therapist applies resistance into shoulder flexion, then extension. No movement takes place. The therapist instructs the patient to “hold” when resistance is applied in both directions. Which of the following proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation techniques is being used?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Rhythmic stabilization involves a series of isometric contractions of the agonist then the antagonist.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Repeated contractions involve quick stretches followed by resisted concentric contractions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Hold-relax is a stretching technique involving an isometric contraction of the tight muscle.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Contract-relax is a stretching technique involving a concentric contraction of the tight muscle.

subject: Neurology

question: The therapist is treating a patient who recently received a below-knee amputation. In the patient’s chart a psychiatrist has stated that the patient is in the second stage of the grieving process. Which stage of the grieving process is this patient most likely exhibiting?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The five stages of grieving are (in order from first to last) are denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Denial is the first stage of grief.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Acceptance is the final stage of grief.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Depression is the fourth stage of grief.

subject: Other

question: A patient with a chronic low back pain. The order is to “increase gluteal muscle function by decreasing trigger points in the quadratus lumborum.” The patient and the physician have decided to avoid surgery as long as possible. The therapist provides the patient with a home exercise program and instructions about activities that will be limited secondary to this diagnosis. Which of the following is the best advice?

options.text: The patient should avoid all athletic activity for 1 year.
The patient should avoid all athletic activity until there is a minimum of 20% difference in the bilateral quadriceps muscle as measured isokinetically.
The patient should wear a brace and compete in only light athletic events.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The ACL-deficient patient has a significant rotatory instability. Bracing may prevent some of this instability. Sports that are especially difficult on the knees (e.g., skiing, competitive contact sports) are contraindicated.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is overly restrictive and not evidence-based.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A 20% deficit is a common goal for return to sport *after* reconstruction, not a limitation for a chronically deficient knee.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While bracing may be helpful, the statement implies it allows for competition, but the most important advice relates to avoiding high-risk pivoting sports.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physician has ordered a physical therapist to treat a patient with chronic low back pain. The order is to “increase gluteal muscle function by decreasing trigger points in the quadratus lumborum.” The patient and the physician have decided to avoid surgery as long as possible. What is the first technique that should be used by the physical therapist?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Trigger points are often treated with soft tissue massage. Other techniques include strain/counterstrain, myofascial release, and muscle energy techniques.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Strengthening is important but should follow the release of trigger points that may be inhibiting muscle function.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Postural education is important but does not directly address the trigger points.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Muscle re-education is a broader concept; soft tissue massage is the specific technique to address the identified trigger points.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 60-year-old woman is referred to outpatient physical therapy services for rehabilitation after a left total knee replacement 4 weeks ago. The patient is currently ambulating with a standard walker with a severely antalgic gait pattern. Before the recent surgery the patient was ambulating independently without an assistive device. Left knee flexion was measured in the initial examination and found to be 85 degrees actively and 94 degrees passively. The patient also lacked 10 degrees of full passive extension and 17 degrees of full active extension. Which of the following does the therapist need to first address?

options.text: Lack of passive left knee flexion
Lack of passive left knee extension
Lack of active left knee extension
Ability to ambulate with a lesser assistive device

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Choice B is correct because the patient has to achieve extension. Full active knee extension and full flexion are important and should be a major focus of the patient’s session, but the question asks for the most serious deficit. Ambulating with a lesser assistive device should be the focus at a later time because the patient’s gait is still severely antalgic and obvious instability is still present. Usually a patient is advanced to a lesser assistive device when he or she can ambulate without large gait deviations with the current assistive device.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While improving flexion is important, regaining full extension is critical for a normal gait pattern and preventing long-term complications.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The lack of active extension is secondary to the lack of passive extension and quadriceps weakness. Restoring passive motion is the first step.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Progressing to a lesser assistive device is not possible until the underlying impairments, particularly the lack of extension, are addressed.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A home health physical therapist is sent to examine a 56-year-old man who has suffered a recent stroke. The patient is sitting in a lift chair, accompanied by his 14-year-old nephew. He seems confused several times throughout the examination. The nephew is unable to assist in clarifying much of the subjective history. The patient reports to the therapist that he is independent in ambulation with a standard walker as an assistive device and in all transfers without an assistive device. Based on the above information, which of the following sequence of events, chosen by the therapist, is in the correct order?

options.text: Ambulate with the standard walker with the wheelchair in close proximity; transfer sit to stand in front of the wheelchair; transfer wheelchair to bed; assess range of motion and strength of all extremities in supine position

Ambulate with the standard walker with the wheelchair in close proximity; transfer wheelchair to bed; assess range of motion and strength of all extremities in supine position; transfer sit to stand at bedside

Assess range of motion and strength of all extremities in the lift chair; transfer sit to stand in front of the lift chair; ambulate with the standard walker with the wheelchair in close proximity; transfer wheelchair to bed

Assess range of motion and strength of all extremities in the lift chair; ambulate with the standard walker with the wheelchair in close proximity; transfer sit to stand in front of the wheelchair; transfer wheelchair to bed

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because of the unreliable history obtained in the evaluation, the therapist at least should make a quick assessment of range of motion and strength before the patient attempts to stand. Sit-to-stand transfer should then be assessed in front of the lift chair before the patient attempts to ambulate.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: It is unsafe to begin ambulation without first assessing the patient's strength and ability to transfer.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: It is unsafe to begin ambulation without a baseline assessment.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Ambulation should occur after assessing the ability to stand safely.

subject: Neurology

question: A patient is receiving crutch training 1 day after a right knee arthroscopic surgery. The patient’s weight-bearing status is toe-touch weight-bearing on the right lower extremity. The therapist first chooses to instruct the patient how to perform a correct sit-to-stand transfer. Which of the following is the most correct set of instructions?

options.text: (1) Slide forward to the edge of the chair; (2) put both the crutches in front of you and hold both grips together with the right hand; (3) press on the left arm rest with the left hand and the grips with the right hand; (4) lean forward; (5) stand up, placing your weight on the left lower extremity; (6) place one crutch slowly under the left arm, then under the right arm.

(1) Slide forward; (2) put one crutch in each hand, holding the grips; (3) place crutches in a vertical position; (4) press down on the grips; (5) stand up, placing more weight on the left lower extremity.

(1) Slide forward to the edge of the chair; (2) put both the crutches in front of you and hold both grips together with the left hand; (3) press on the right arm rest with the right hand and the grips with the left hand; (4) lean forward; (5) stand up, placing your weight on the right lower extremity; (6) place one crutch slowly under the right arm, then under the left arm.

(1) Place crutches in close proximity; (2) slide forward; (3) place hands on the arm rests; (4) press down and stand up; (5) place weight on the left lower extremity; (6) reach slowly for the crutches and place under the axilla.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The method used in Choice A is the safest. The method used in Choice C is too unstable.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Attempting to stand up while holding a crutch in each hand is unstable and unsafe.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The patient should place weight on the unaffected (left) leg, not the operative (right) leg, which is toe-touch weight-bearing. Also, the crutches should be held on the unaffected side.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Reaching for the crutches after standing is unstable. The crutches should be controlled throughout the transfer.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 20-year-old man with anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction with allograft presents to an outpatient physical therapy clinic. The patient’s surgery was 5 days ago. The patient is independent in ambulation with crutches. He also currently has 53 degrees of active knee flexion and 67 degrees of passive knee flexion and lacks 10 degrees of full knee extension actively and 5 degrees passively. What is the most significant deficit on which the physical therapist should focus treatment?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Passive extension is the most important motion to gain after an anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction, regardless of the graft type. Active extension can be achieved once passive extension is full (or equal bilaterally).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While active extension (quadriceps lag) is important, it cannot be fully restored until the passive extension deficit is resolved.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While 53 degrees of active flexion is limited, it is expected at this early stage. Restoring full extension is the immediate priority to ensure a normal gait pattern and prevent long-term complications like arthrofibrosis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Lack of passive flexion is also expected and will improve with time. The lack of passive extension is the most functionally significant deficit at this stage.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is ordered to examine and treat in the acute setting a patient who received a left total knee replacement 1 day ago. Before surgery, the patient was independent in all activities of daily living, transfers, and ambulation with an assistive device. The family reports that ambulation was slow and guarded because of knee pain. The physician’s orders are to ambulate with partial weight bearing on the left lower extremity and to increase strength/range of motion. At this point, bed-to-wheelchair transfers, sit-to-stand transfers, and wheelchair-to-toilet transfers require the minimal assistance of one person. The left knee has 63 degrees of active flexion and 77 degrees of passive flexion. The left knee also lacks 7 degrees of full extension actively and 3 degrees passively. Right hip strength is recorded as follows: hip flexion and abduction = 4+/5, hip adduction and extension = 5/5, knee flexion = 4+/5, knee extension = 5/5. Left lower extremity strength is recorded as follows: hip flexion = 3/5, hip abduction and adduction = 3+/5, hip extension = 3/5, knee flexion and extension = 3-/5, ankle dorsiflexion = 3+/5, and plantar flexion = 3+/5. The patient is currently able to ambulate 30 feet × 2 with a standard walker and minimal assistance of one person on level surfaces. She also ambulates with a flexed knee throughout the gait cycle. According to the physician, she most likely will be discharged home (with home health services), where she lives alone, within the next 2 to 3 days. Of the choices below, which is the most important long-term goal in the acute setting?

options.text: In 3 days the patient will be independent in all transfers.
In 3 days the patient will ambulate with a quad cane independently, with no gait deviations, on level surfaces 50 feet × 3.
In 3 days the patient will increase all left lower extremity manual muscle testing grades by one half grade.
In 3 days the patient will have active left knee range of motion from 0 to 90 degrees and passive range of motion from 0 to 95 degrees.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because the patient lives alone, independent transfer is the most important goal listed. Functional ambulation is an important goal, but choice B is an unrealistic goal for the patient to accomplish in a 2- or 3-day period.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is an unrealistic goal for the acute setting. Transitioning to a quad cane and eliminating all gait deviations in 3 days is highly unlikely.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: MMT grades are not functional goals and improving by a half-grade across the board is not a well-formed goal.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While improving ROM is important, achieving full independence in transfers is the most critical goal for a safe discharge home for someone who lives alone.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient presents to therapy with poor motor control of the lower extremities. The therapist determines that to work efficiently toward the goal of returning the patient to his prior level of ambulation, he must work in the following order regarding stages of control

options.text: Skill, controlled stability, controlled mobility, mobility

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This choice lists the stages of control in the correct order.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Stability (the ability to maintain a posture) precedes controlled mobility (movement within a posture).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Mobility (the ability to initiate movement) must be established before stability.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This order is reversed. Skill is the final stage.

subject: Neurology

question: A 23-year-old woman arrives at an outpatient physical therapy clinic with a prescription to examine and treat the right hand. One week earlier the patient underwent surgical repair of the flexor tendons of the right hand at zone 2. She also had her cast removed at the physician’s office a few minutes before coming to physical therapy. What is the best course of treatment for this patient?

options.text: Splinting the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints at neutral
Splinting with the use of rubber bands to passively flex the fingers

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Choice D is the correct treatment. Strengthening is not indicated at this time, and splinting as described in Choice C places too much stretch on the tendons. In addition, static splinting does not allow tendon gliding. Ultrasound is contraindicated over a healing tendon repair.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Ultrasound is contraindicated over a fresh tendon repair.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Grip strengthening is too aggressive at this early stage and could rupture the repair.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Splinting in neutral does not protect the repair and may place undue stress on it.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 67-year-old man with a below-knee amputation was sent to an outpatient clinic. His surgical amputation was 3 weeks ago, and his scars are well healed. Which of the following is incorrect information about stump care?

options.text: Use a light lotion on the stump after bathing each night.
Continue with use of a shrinker 12 hours per day.
Wash the stump with mild soap and water.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The shrinker should be removed only for bathing. Because the surgical scars are healed, the stump can be immersed in water.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Using lotion is important for skin health, provided it is fully absorbed before donning the shrinker or prosthesis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Keeping the stump clean with mild soap and water is a key part of hygiene.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Scar massage is important to prevent adhesions once the incision is fully closed.

subject: Integumentary

question: A physical therapist is teaching a class in geriatric fitness/strengthening. Which of the following is not a general guideline for exercise prescription in this patient population?

options.text: To increase exercise intensity, increase treadmill speed rather than the grade.
Start at a low intensity (2 to 3 METs).
Use machines for strength training rather than free weights.
Set weight resistance so that the patient can perform more than 8 repetitions before fatigue.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because of poor balance, geriatric patients should increase the treadmill grade rather than the speed. Use of machines allows better posture and low intensities and limits the exercise within the patient’s safe range of motion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Starting at a low intensity is a key principle for safety and gradual adaptation in older adults.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Machines can provide more stability and control than free weights, which can be safer for some older adults.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Focusing on higher repetitions with lower weight is a standard guideline for improving muscular endurance in this population.

subject: Other

question: A 76-year-old woman received a cemented right total hip arthroplasty (THA) 24 hours ago. The surgeon documented that he used a posterolateral incision. Which of the following suggestions is inappropriate for the next 24 hours?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Movements that stress the posterolateral hip joint capsule should be avoided. These movements are hip flexion > 90 degrees, hip adduction past midline, and internal rotation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While the formal precaution is to avoid flexion beyond 90 degrees, being extremely cautious in the first 24 hours is reasonable, but abduction is not a restricted motion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is a standard posterolateral hip precaution.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This is a standard posterolateral hip precaution.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The therapist is examining a 38-year-old man who complains of right sacroiliac joint pain. The therapist decides to assess leg length discrepancy in supine versus sitting position. When the patient is in supine position, leg lengths are equal; however, when the patient rises to the sitting position, the right lower extremity appears 2 cm shorter. Which of the following should be a part of the treatment plan?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This patient most likely has a right anterior rotation of the right innominate and thus needs right posterior mobilization of the right innominate.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The test indicates an anterior rotation; therefore, a posterior mobilization is needed to correct it.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The findings are on the right side, so the treatment should be directed to the right innominate.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The findings are on the right side, so the treatment should be directed to the right innominate.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: In taping an athlete’s ankle prophylactically before a football game, in what position should the ankle be slightly positioned before taping to provide the most protection against an ankle sprain?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This position, which limits inversion, plantar flexion, and adduction, is the most common position for ankle sprains.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Inversion is the position of injury for the most common type of ankle sprain.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Plantar flexion is a position of instability for the ankle.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This combination puts the ankle in a position of vulnerability to a lateral ankle sprain.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is treating a 35-year-old man with traumatic injury to the right wrist. The patient has several surgical scars from a tendon repair performed 6 weeks ago. What is the appropriate type of massage for the patient’s scars?

options.text: Massage should be transverse and longitudinal.
Massage should be circular and longitudinal.
Massage should be transverse and circular.
Massage is contraindicated after a tendon repair.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Transverse (perpendicular to the scar) or circular massage assists in mobilization of scar tissue.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Longitudinal massage along the scar is less effective for breaking up adhesions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Longitudinal massage is less effective.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Massage is an important intervention for scar tissue management after the initial healing phase.

subject: Integumentary

question: A patient is being treated in an outpatient facility after receiving a meniscus repair to the right knee 1 week ago. The patient has full passive extension of the involved knee but lacks 4 degrees of full extension when performing a straight leg raise. The patient’s active flexion is 110 degrees and passive flexion is 119 degrees. What is a common term used to describe the patient’s most significant range of motion deficit? What is a possible source of this problem?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The patient has an extension lag, which may be due to any source that has inhibited the quadriceps and results in an inability to fully extend the knee actively.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A flexion contracture would mean a lack of passive extension, but the patient has full passive extension.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The term is extension lag, not flexion lag.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: An extension contracture is not a standard term. Tight hamstrings could limit flexion, not extension.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is attempting to increase a patient’s functional mobility in a seated position. To treat the patient most effectively and efficiently, the following should be performed in what order? 1. Weight shifting of the pelvis, 2. Isometric contractions of the lower extremity, 3. Trunk range of motion exercises, 4. Isotonic resistance to the quadriceps
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The treatment techniques should be performed in the order of mobility, stability, controlled mobility, and skill.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The sequence does not follow the stages of motor control (mobility, stability, controlled mobility, skill).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The sequence does not follow the stages of motor control.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This sequence is reversed.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist is speaking to a group of avid tennis players. The group asks how to prevent tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis). Which of the following is incorrect information?

options.text: Primarily use the wrist and elbow extensors during a backhand stroke.
Begin the backhand stroke in shoulder adduction and internal rotation.
Use a racket that has a large grip.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Tennis elbow results from overuse of the wrist extensors. The shoulder external rotators should be used to power a backhand.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This starting position can help generate power from the larger shoulder and trunk muscles, reducing strain on the wrist extensors.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A larger grip can reduce the amount of force the wrist and finger extensors must generate.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A lighter racket reduces the overall load on the arm.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is fabricating a splint for a patient who received four metacarpophalangeal joint replacements. The surgical joint replacement was necessary because of severe rheumatoid arthritis. Which of the following is the correct placement of the metacarpophalangeal joints in the splint?

options.text: Full flexion and slight radial pull
Full flexion and slight ulnar pull
Full extension and slight radial pull
Full extension and slight ulnar pull

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The radial pull component is designed to allow tightening of the radial side of the capsule.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Flexion would place the extensor mechanism on excessive stretch post-operatively.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Flexion is incorrect, and an ulnar pull would encourage ulnar deviation, which is the deformity one is trying to prevent.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: An ulnar pull would encourage the common ulnar drift deformity seen in RA.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is ordered to fabricate a splint for a 2-month-old infant with congenital hip dislocation. In what position should the hip be placed while in the splint?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This is the most stable position of the hip, which allows for more normal growth.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Adduction is the position of instability and can lead to dislocation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Extension and adduction are positions of instability.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While abduction provides stability, the hip should be flexed, not extended, to seat the femoral head properly in the acetabulum (e.g., in a Pavlik harness).

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is discharging a 32-year-old man from outpatient physical therapy. The patient received therapy for a traumatic ankle injury that occurred several months earlier. The surgery performed on the patient’s ankle required placement of plates and screws, which resulted in a permanent range of motion deficit of 10 degrees of active and passive dorsiflexion. Strength in the ankle is 5/5 with manual muscle testing. Of the following, which is the highest functional outcome that the patient can expect?

options.text: Independent ambulation with no gait deviations
Ambulation with a cane with minimal gait deviations
Ascending or descending stairs with no gait deviations

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Normally, the ankle requires 20 degrees or more of dorsiflexion for a patient to run or ascend/descend stairs properly. Independent ambulation with a normal gait pattern requires 10 degrees of dorsiflexion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: With 5/5 strength and 10 degrees of dorsiflexion, the patient should be able to ambulate without a cane.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Running requires more than 10 degrees of dorsiflexion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Stair negotiation, especially descending, requires more than 10 degrees of dorsiflexion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is performing passive range of motion on the shoulder of a 43-year-old woman who received a rotator cuff repair 5 weeks ago. During passive range of motion, the therapist notes a capsular end feel at 95 degrees of shoulder flexion. What should the therapist do?

options.text: Begin isokinetic exercise at 180 degrees per second.
Schedule the patient an appointment with the physician immediately.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because of the length of the time since the surgical procedure, the patient may have adhesive capsulitis. The capsule should continue to be stretched to increase range of motion. The patient should visit the physician if the range of motion deficits continue. Active exercise may be necessary at this stage of recovery, but it will not help to relieve a capsular dysfunction.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Isokinetic exercise is a strengthening modality and is not appropriate for addressing a capsular restriction. It is also likely too aggressive at 5 weeks post-op.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This is a normal finding at this stage of recovery and does not require immediate physician consultation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Aggressive supraspinatus activity is contraindicated at 5 weeks post-op and would not address the capsular restriction.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: In which of the following situations should the therapist be most concerned about the complications resulting from grade IV joint mobilization techniques?

options.text: A 37-year-old man with a Colles fracture suffered 10 weeks ago
A 23-year-old woman with a boxer’s fracture suffered 10 weeks ago
A 34-year-old man with a scaphoid fracture suffered 12 weeks ago
A 53-year-man with a Bennett’s fracture suffered 12 weeks ago

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because the scaphoid has a poor vascular supply, aggressive therapy should be avoided until the bone is fully healed (12 to 24 weeks). A Colles fracture (fracture of the distal radius with dorsal movement of the fixed segment) should heal in 6 to 8 weeks. A boxer’s fracture (fracture of the fifth metacarpal) requires 4 to 6 weeks. A Bennett’s fracture (fracture of the proximal first metacarpal) usually requires 6 to 8 weeks. The length of time given in the above examples obviously depends on the individual patient and the type of surgical fixation (if any).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A Colles' fracture is typically well-healed by 10 weeks, and mobilization would be appropriate.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A boxer's fracture is typically well-healed by 10 weeks.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A Bennett's fracture is typically well-healed by 12 weeks.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following is an inappropriate exercise for a patient who received an anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction with a patella tendon autograft 2 weeks ago?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Lateral step-ups are probably too difficult for a patient who received an anterior ligament reconstruction with a patella tendon autograft 2 weeks ago.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Heel slides are a gentle active-assisted ROM exercise appropriate for this stage.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Stationary biking with no resistance is often used early in rehab to promote ROM and reduce swelling.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Pool walking is an excellent low-impact exercise for this stage of recovery.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is speaking to a group of receptionists about correct posture. Which of the following is incorrect information?

options.text: Position computer monitors at eye level.
Position seats so that the feet are flat on the floor while sitting.
Position keyboards so that the wrists are in approximately 20 degrees of extension.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The wrists should be in neutral position when the fingers are on the middle row of the keyboard.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Positioning the monitor at eye level helps maintain a neutral cervical spine posture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Having feet flat on the floor provides a stable base of support and promotes good posture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Frequent breaks are important to prevent the negative effects of sustained postures.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is treating an automobile mechanic. The patient asks for tips on preventing upper extremity repetitive motion injuries. Which of the following is incorrect advice?

options.text: Use your entire hand rather than just the fingers when holding an object.
Position tasks so that they are performed below shoulder height.
Use tools with small straight handles when possible.
When performing a forceful task, keep the materials slightly lower than the elbow.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Tools with small handles require more grip strength. Tasks below shoulder height reduce the risk of impingement, and more force can be applied to tasks if they are kept below elbow height.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Using the entire hand distributes the force over a larger area, reducing stress on smaller joints and tendons.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Working below shoulder height reduces the risk of shoulder impingement and rotator cuff injury.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Keeping forceful tasks below elbow height allows for better use of larger muscle groups and improved biomechanics.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient presents to physical therapy with a long-standing diagnosis of bilateral pes planus. The therapist has given the patient custom-fit orthotics. After using the orthotics for 1 week, the patient complains of pain along the first metatarsal. The therapist decides to use joint mobilization techniques to decrease the patient’s pain. In which direction should the therapist mobilize the first metatarsal?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: In response to a pronated subtalar joint, the forefoot undergoes a supination twist and the first ray dorsiflexes. Because the distal first cuneiform is convex and the proximal first metatarsal is concave, inferior mobilization of the first metatarsal is required.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A superior glide would reinforce the dorsiflexed position of the first ray, potentially worsening the problem.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Lateral glides are not the primary mobilization to address plantarflexion/dorsiflexion of the first ray.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Medial glides are not the primary mobilization to address plantarflexion/dorsiflexion of the first ray.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 14-year-old boy with a diagnosis of osteosarcoma of his right distal femur underwent resection of the distal third of his femur and implantation of an expandable endoprosthetic device 2 months ago. He is now referred to outpatient physical therapy with no restrictions except PWB gait with crutches. What impairment would you expect to most interfere with function at the time of the examination?

options.text: Pain at the site of surgical intervention

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The leg length discrepancy would have been resolved by the surgical procedure, and pain at the surgical site will have diminished by 2 months postoperatively. Knee ROM will be more limited than hip because the procedure involved the distal femur.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The expandable prosthesis is designed to address leg length discrepancy as the child grows.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The hip joint itself was not operated on, so ROM should be less affected than the knee.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While some pain may be present, the most significant functional limitation at this stage is typically the profound loss of knee range of motion.

subject: Oncology

question: A 4-year-old-child diagnosed with osteosarcoma of the distal femur is scheduled for resection of the distal third of the femur. Which surgical intervention would provide the best long term functional outcome?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: An endoprosthetic implant is limited in the amount of growth that can be accommodated. Allografts are only appropriate for children nearing skeletal maturity, and a hip disarticulation would not allow for normal active play even with a prosthesis. Rotationplasty is a radical surgery, but it is the best option in this case.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: An allograft (bone from a donor) has risks of non-union and fracture and may not be the best functional option for a young child.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: An endoprosthesis has a limited lifespan and will likely require multiple revision surgeries throughout the patient's life.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A hip disarticulation is a very high-level amputation with significant functional loss.

subject: Oncology

question: A 6-month-old infant with acetabular dysplasia of the right hip diagnosed by radiograph, with a history of a dislocatable hip at birth, would usually be treated with
