The day after the traction treatment, he tells you that his back pain has diminished, but he now has deep aching and numbness down the posterior aspect of his right lower extremity. In addition, you are no longer able to elicit his Achilles tendon reflex. Based on these responses, you should

options.text: Increase the intensity of the traction during the next treatment session
Reduce the intensity of the traction during the next treatment session
Switch from a static to an intermittent mode of traction application

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The patient is experiencing peripheralization of his pain, which indicates that his condition has worsened, so the traction treatment should be stopped.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Increasing the intensity would worsen the condition.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Reducing the intensity might be an option, but given the new neurological signs (numbness, loss of reflex), discontinuing is the safest course of action.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Changing the mode does not address the fact that the patient's condition worsened with traction.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: You administer cervical traction to a patient in your clinic to help stretch the soft tissues along the posterior aspect of her neck. She responds well to the initial treatment so you arrange for her to lease a home cervical traction unit to continue this treatment on a daily basis. In what position would you instruct her to place the traction unit to produce the optimal effect?

options.text: At a downward angle that pulls her neck into slight extension
At an upward angle that slightly flexes her neck
At an upward angle that fully flexes her neck
Lying flat with no angle (no extension or flexion)

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Pulling the cervical spine into slight flexion is the best way to target your stretch to the posterior cervical musculature. It also reduces tension on the facet joint capsules.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Extension would shorten the posterior cervical muscles.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Full flexion may be too aggressive and uncomfortable.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A neutral position does not specifically target the posterior structures as effectively as slight flexion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: When the goal of a lumbar traction treatment is to cause distraction of the vertebrae, the magnitude of the traction force should approximate what percent of the patient’s body weight?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A force that equals up to 50% of the patient’s body weight may be needed to cause distraction of the lumbar vertebrae. Much lower forces (~7%) are needed to distract the cervical vertebrae.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: 10% of body weight is too low to achieve vertebral separation in the lumbar spine.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: 25% of body weight is typically used to overcome friction and stretch soft tissues, but 50% is the general guideline for vertebral distraction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: 75% of body weight is excessive and unsafe.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following is not a physiologic benefit associated with the use of continuous passive motion (CPM)?

options.text: Prevents muscle atrophy by simulating a normal concentric contraction
Prevents adhesions by orienting collagen fibers as they heal
Reduces edema by facilitating the movement of fluid in and out of the joint
Reduces pain via the stimulation of joint mechanoreceptors

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because this is passive movement only, CPM can neither cause a muscle contraction nor prevent atrophy.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: By keeping the joint moving, a CPM can help prevent adhesions from forming.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The gentle pumping action of the movement can assist with fluid exchange and reduce edema.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Movement stimulates mechanoreceptors, which can help modulate pain via the gate control theory.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient with venous insufficiency in his lower extremities is referred for instruction on the use of a pneumatic compression pump at home. What inflation pressure and treatment time will you use to initiate this compression treatment?

options.text: Continuous pressure equal to the patient’s diastolic blood pressure for 20 to 30 minutes
Continuous pressure between 30 and 50 mm Hg for 20 to 30 minutes
Intermittent pressure no higher than 30 mm Hg for one hour
Intermittent pressure between 40 and 80 mm Hg for 2 hours

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The pressure setting should never exceed the patient’s diastolic blood pressure. Because venous pressure is usually higher in the lower extremities than in the upper extremities, guidelines suggest a range of 30 to 60 mm Hg for the upper extremity and 40 to 80 mm Hg for the lower extremity. Intermittent compression is usually tolerated better, and recommended treatment times are 2 to 3 hours a day, depending on the severity of the condition

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Continuous pressure is not typically used, and setting it equal to diastolic pressure is the upper limit, not the starting point.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Continuous pressure is not the standard protocol for these devices.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The pressure is too low to be effective for the lower extremities.

subject: Other

question: Which of the following conditions would contraindicate the use of an intermittent pneumatic compression pump?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Congestive heart failure and pulmonary edema are both contraindications for pneumatic compression because the heart and lungs are already overloaded and compression will just further increase that fluid load. This could result in more breathing difficulties or complete heart failure.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Lymphedema is a primary indication for IPC use.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Post-operative edema after joint arthroplasty is a common indication for IPC.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Edema associated with venous stasis ulcers is a common indication for IPC.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: You are treating a patient with acute bicipital tendinitis, so your goal is to reduce inflammation. Two of your treatment choices are iontophoresis and phonophoresis. Which of the following comparative statements regarding these two modalities is true?

options.text: Both procedures can be performed at home by the patient.
Both procedures require medications to be suspended in a solution.
Iontophoresis can deliver medication to deeper tissues than phonophoresis.
Iontophoresis is more likely to cause skin irritation than phonophoresis.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because iontophoresis is administered with a continuous monophasic (i.e., direct) current, it can cause an acidic or alkaline reaction under the electrode, depending on the polarity used. This can be very irritating to the skin. Home units are available for iontophoresis, but not phonophoresis. Iontophoresis requires medications to be suspended in a solution, whereas phonophoresis requires the medication to be mixed in with a lotion, gel, or cream. Deeper penetration is usually possible with phonophoresis because ultrasound can target tissues several centimeters deep, while iontophoresis only penetrates a few millimeters.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While some home units exist, these are typically clinical procedures requiring professional supervision.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Phonophoresis uses a coupling medium like gel or cream, not a solution.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Phonophoresis (ultrasound) has a greater depth of penetration than iontophoresis (direct current).

subject: Other

question: If you are using iontophoresis to deliver dexamethasone (–) to an inflamed tissue, which of the following would be the most appropriate treatment parameters?

options.text: (+) Active electrode; intensity = 1.5 mAmps; treatment time = 0 min
(–) Active electrode; intensity = 2 mAmps; treatment time = 20 min
(+) Active electrode; intensity = 4 mAmps; treatment time = 10 min
(–) Active electrode; intensity = 8 mAmps; treatment time = 5 min

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The active electrode should be the same polarity as the medication. The optimal current dosage (intensity × treatment time) is 40 to 80 m

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Treatment time of 0 minutes is nonsensical. Also, the active electrode should be negative to repel the negative dexamethasone ion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The active electrode should be negative (-) to repel the negatively charged dexamethasone.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: 8 mAmps is an extremely high and likely unsafe intensity for iontophoresis.

subject: Other

question: If you want move ions into the tissue, as in the application of iontophoresis, what type of electrical current will you need to use?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: In order to move ions continuously into the tissue, a continuous monophasic current (i.e., direct current) is needed.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Biphasic current alternates polarity, so there would be no net movement of ions in one direction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Pulsed current is interrupted, and biphasic current alternates polarity.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Pulsed current is interrupted, which is less efficient for iontophoresis than continuous current.

subject: Other

question: You have a patient with a diabetic ulcer that has not responded well to conventional treatment, so you think he might be a good candidate for electrical stimulation. Which type of electrical current would most likely facilitate wound healing?

options.text: High-volt using a pulsed monophasic waveform
Iontophoresis using a continuous monophasic waveform
TENS using a pulsed biphasic waveform

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: High-volt stimulation would be the best option because it has a monophasic waveform and can produce polarity effects. These polarity effects have been shown to stimulate tissue repair and destroy bacteria that may contaminate the wound. Iontophoresis also produces polarity effects but cannot be applied to an open wound because the continuous current will irritate the tissue too much.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Interferential current uses a biphasic waveform and is primarily for pain modulation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Iontophoresis is used to deliver medication and is not applied directly over an open wound.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: TENS is primarily used for pain modulation, not wound healing.

subject: Integumentary

question: You are treating a patient who is recovering from a muscle strain and you want to help increase the blood flow to that muscle as well as enhance its extensibility. Which thermal agent is most likely to produce these effects in muscle tissue?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Shortwave diathermy produces deep heat and is best absorbed by muscle tissue. Hot packs and infrared radiation are too superficial to adequately heat the target tissue. Pulsed ultrasound produces little or no thermal effect.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A hot pack is a superficial heating modality and will not effectively heat deep muscle tissue.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Infrared radiation is a superficial heating modality.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Pulsed ultrasound produces primarily non-thermal effects and would not be used to increase tissue temperature.

subject: Other

question: You are treating an athlete who strained his hamstring muscle. Which of the following modalities would be contraindicated if this patient had a cardiac pacemaker?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Diathermy is always contraindicated in patients with pacemakers. Ultrasound is only contraindicated when used to treat a body part in close proximity to the pacemaker. In this case, the patient’s thigh is sufficiently distant from the pacemaker.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Ice massage has no electrical component and is safe.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Hydrotherapy is safe, provided any agitators are properly grounded.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Ultrasound is safe as long as it is applied to the hamstring, far away from the pacemaker located in the chest.

subject: Other

question: You decide to use sensory-level (i.e., conventional) TENS to provide some relief for incisional pain in your patient who underwent recent knee surgery. The physiological mechanism by which this form of TENS is thought to provide immediate pain relief is known as
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Sensory-level TENS is believed to selectively activate the large-diameter A-beta fibers that (i.e., “close the gait”) the slower conduction nociceptive fibers in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord before these neurons can synapse with the second-order neurons in the spinal cord. Thus, this mechanism is referred to as presynaptic inhibition.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Autogenic inhibition is the relaxation of a muscle in response to high tension, mediated by the Golgi tendon organs.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Descending inhibition is the mechanism for opioid-based analgesia (e.g., low-frequency TENS), involving pathways from the brainstem.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Reciprocal inhibition is the relaxation of a muscle when its antagonist is contracted.

subject: Other

question: You have placed equal-sized electrodes over the dorsal aspect of a patient’s proximal and distal forearm as shown in Figure 5-1 in order to stimulate his wrist and finger extensor muscles. However, when you first turn the electrical stimulator on, the response you are getting is finger flexion, rather than extension. How would you correct this problem to get the desired motor response?

options.text: Increase the pulse duration to maximize the intensity
Move the electrodes closer together over the muscle belly
Switch from a biphasic current to a monophasic current
Use a smaller electrode over the distal forearm

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The illustration shows that these electrodes are spaced pretty far apart. The further apart two electrodes are, the deeper the current will run. Thus, the current is probably running too deep and actually stimulating the flexors, instead of the extensors. Moving both electrodes over the muscle belly should remedy this problem.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Increasing pulse duration or intensity would likely just increase the unwanted flexion contraction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Changing the waveform does not address the issue of stimulating the wrong muscle group due to electrode placement.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Using a smaller electrode would increase current density but wouldn't solve the problem of stimulating the deeper flexor muscles.

subject: Other

question: You are using electrical stimulation to facilitate the contraction of a muscle that is recovering from a peripheral nerve injury. Because the patient only shows signs of partial innervation at this time, any electrical stimulation will require the use of a stimulator that can produce a

options.text: High amplitude and long pulse duration
Very low intensity in the microamperage range

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A partially innervated muscle is much higher than it is for a normal, innervated muscle. The stimulus threshold is reached through a combination of increasing pulse amplitude and duration. Most small stimulators have limited amplitude range and a fixed pulse duration of 150-300 microseconds. This may not be sufficient to reach the stimulus threshold for this patient’s muscle.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: High frequency is not the key parameter; long pulse duration is needed to stimulate a denervated muscle fiber directly.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While a monophasic waveform might be used, the critical parameters are amplitude and duration, not just polarity.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Very low intensity (microcurrent) is used for tissue healing, not for motor stimulation of a denervated muscle.

subject: Neurology

question: You are treating a patient with adhesive capsulitis of the glenohumeral joint. You decide to administer some ultrasound in order to increase the extensibility of the patient’s joint capsule before you begin joint mobilization procedures. Which ultrasound parameters are most likely to produce the desired results in this particular tissue?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: To increase the extensibility of collagen tissue, you want some thermal effects from the ultrasound treatment; thus, you need to use the continuous mode. To penetrate to the depth of the shoulder joint capsule, you should use the 1 MHz frequency because ultrasound delivered with higher frequencies tends to be absorbed more in the superficial tissues.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Pulsed ultrasound produces non-thermal effects and would not be effective for heating the joint capsule.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: 3 MHz frequency is absorbed more superficially and would not effectively heat the deep glenohumeral joint capsule.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This combines a superficial frequency with a non-thermal mode, making it ineffective for this goal.

subject: Other

question: Which of the following patient conditions would contraindicate the use of most thermal, mechanical, and electrical modalities?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Most heating, compression, and electrical modalities cause some increase in circulation, which can aggravate a metastatic condition. In addition, the presence of an active cancer in local tissue such as bone can weaken the tissue and cause injury, so traction would also be contraindicated. All of the other conditions are either indications or potential precautions for the use of these modalities.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Diabetic neuropathy is often a precaution due to sensory loss, but many modalities can be used with care.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Hypertension is a precaution for some modalities, but not an absolute contraindication for most.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Urinary incontinence is an indication for certain types of electrical stimulation.

subject: Oncology

question: Which of the following patients would not be an appropriate candidate for EMG biofeedback training?

options.text: Poststroke patient who needs balance training
Quadriplegic patient who has had a recent tendon transfer

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: EMG biofeedback requires the patient to consciously attend and respond to a visual or auditory stimulus in order to have a learning effect. An individual with dementia is unlikely to have the attention focus or retention needed to benefit from this type of intervention. All of the other conditions are indications for either facilitating strength or relaxation of the targeted muscle groups.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Biofeedback is commonly used for relaxation training of the upper trapezius and temporalis muscles in patients with tension headaches.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Biofeedback can be an effective tool for neuromuscular re-education of paretic muscles to improve balance after a stroke.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Biofeedback is used for muscle re-education following a tendon transfer.

subject: Neurology

question: Which of the following physiologic changes would not be associated with the application of superficial heat?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Heat tends to cause local vasodilation, so it is more likely to increase the accumulation of fluid in the interstitial spaces than decrease it.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Heat can help modulate pain through the gate control mechanism and by reducing muscle spasm.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Heating collagenous tissue before stretching increases its extensibility.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Heat increases the local metabolic rate of the tissues.

subject: Other

question: You are preparing to apply cryotherapy to a patient who has never had it before. In your history, which question would help you determine whether your patient might be hypersensitive to cold?

options.text: Do your fingers ever go numb when exposed to cold, damp weather?
Have you ever had an allergic response to a cold stimulus (i.e., itchy rash or hives)?
How often do you wear gloves when you are outside in cold weather?

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: An allergic response to cold is most likely to present itself as a skin reaction in the form of itching, rash, or hives. Choice A relates to the occurrence of Raynaud’s phenomenon. The other two choices are irrelevant.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This question screens for Raynaud's phenomenon, which is a precaution/contraindication, but B screens for a true cold allergy (cold urticaria).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A history of frostbite is a precaution but does not indicate hypersensitivity.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is a general question about behavior and does not screen for a medical condition.

subject: Other

question: Which of the following modalities produces its thermal effects via evaporation?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Vapocoolant sprays cause a surface cooling when the liquid spray evaporates.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Hot packs transfer heat via conduction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Ice massage transfers heat via conduction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Paraffin wax transfers heat via conduction.

subject: Other

question: If you apply a cold pack or ice massage over a patient’s biceps muscle for 5 to 10 minutes before a session of resistive exercise, what change would you expect to see in that muscle?

options.text: An immediate decrease in muscle tone and tendon reflex
Elimination of any exercise-induced muscle soreness
Faster recruitment of type II muscle fibers

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Studies have shown an increase in muscle strength following a 5-minute application of a cold modality. Long-term cooling may reduce muscle strength as well as muscle tone. Although cold therapy may reduce the amount of delayed onset muscle soreness, the modality would need to be applied immediately after the exercise session, not before it.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A decrease in muscle tone and reflexes occurs with more prolonged cooling, not brief cooling.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Cryotherapy may reduce DOMS if applied after exercise, but it will not eliminate it, especially when applied before.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Cooling does not facilitate faster recruitment of type II fibers.

subject: Other

question: Heat modalities are generally contraindicated in the presence of an infectious lesion because they may

options.text: Increase circulation, which can spread the organism to other parts of the body
Increase the rate of cellular mitosis and cause the organism to mutate
Mask the pain associated with the lesion, which may cause further tissue damage
Reduce the effectiveness of the body’s immune system

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because heat tends to increase circulation, the greatest danger is that heat applied over an infectious lesion will cause the organism to spread to adjacent tissues or get into the central circulation where it can cause a systemic infection.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Heat does not cause organisms to mutate.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While it might mask pain, the primary danger is the spread of infection.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Heat does not reduce the effectiveness of the immune system; in fact, localized heating is part of the normal inflammatory response.

subject: Other

question: In most cases, it is considered safe to apply ultrasound over or near
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Cement and plastic are rapidly heated by ultrasound, so it should be avoided over tissues with these types of implants. Ultrasound can interfere with a cardiac pacemaker when applied over the chest or upper back. The effects of ultrasound on reproductive organs is not known; thus, it should be avoided over these anatomic areas. Metal tends to reflect ultrasound, so metal implants are not a contraindication.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Cemented implants are a contraindication due to the risk of overheating the cement.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A pacemaker is an absolute contraindication for ultrasound in its vicinity.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Reproductive organs are a contraindication for thermal ultrasound.

subject: Other

question: When examining an ultrasound machine, you note that it operates at a frequency of 1 MHz and has a Beam Nonuniformity Ratio (BNR) of 8:1. Which of the following statements regarding this machine is true?

options.text: Most energy will be absorbed in superficial tissues, and it may produce uneven heating.
Most energy will be absorbed in superficial tissues, and it should produce even heating.
Most energy will be absorbed in deep tissues, and it may produce uneven heating.
Most energy will be absorbed in deep tissues, and it should produce even heating.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A 1MHz ultrasound unit is a relatively low frequency that allows the sound waves to be absorbed deeper into the tissue (higher frequency energy is absorbed more superficially). BNR is the ratio between the spatial peak intensity and the spatial average intensity of the ultrasound beam. The higher the BNR, the less uniform the heating effect will be and the more likely to produce “hot spots” during the treatment. Most units produce a BNR of 5:1 or 6:1 and some are as low as 2:1.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: 1 MHz frequency penetrates deeply, not superficially. A high BNR of 8:1 indicates uneven heating.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: 1 MHz is for deep tissues, and a BNR of 8:1 indicates uneven heating.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While the energy is absorbed deeply, a BNR of 8:1 is high and indicates a significant risk of uneven heating and 'hot spots'.

subject: Other

question: The most common clinical use of phonophoresis is to

options.text: Apply an anti-inflammatory medication to a localized musculoskeletal tissue
Deliver antibiotics to an infected wound
Provide a mechanical stimulus to accelerate repair in bone and cartilage
Slow the conduction velocity of sensory nerves to relieve pain

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Phonophoresis is most commonly used to deliver anti-inflammatory medication to soft tissues such as muscles, tendons, and joint capsules.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Phonophoresis is not used to deliver antibiotics into an open wound.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While ultrasound can have mechanical effects that promote healing, phonophoresis specifically refers to the delivery of medication.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This describes the analgesic effect of cryotherapy, not phonophoresis.

subject: Other

question: You are administering ultrasound to a localized area of a patient’s patellar tendon when she begins to complain of intense pain over her tibial tuberosity. What is the most likely cause of this response?

options.text: You are using an ineffective or insufficient amount of coupling medium.
There is a very low attenuation of ultrasound in bony tissue.
You are using an ultrasound unit with a high BNR and/or are moving it too slowly.
The crystal in the soundhead has been damaged.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Bony tissue has a high attenuation for ultrasound due to both absorption and reflection. Thus, if you are moving the soundhead too slowly or using a unit with a high BNR, the heating effect may be more concentrated over the bone tissue and cause discomfort (i.e., deep aching).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Insufficient coupling medium would cause the transducer to heat up, but not necessarily cause deep periosteal pain.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Bone has high attenuation (absorption) of ultrasound, not low.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A damaged crystal would result in a less effective or ineffective treatment, not intense pain.

subject: Other

question: A patient with diabetes is admitted for care of a venous stasis ulcer on the medial aspect of his ankle. You decide to include pulsed ultrasound as part of your treatment plan to take advantage of its nonthermal effects on wound healing. Which of the following is an example of a nonthermal effect produced by ultrasound?

options.text: Decreased cell membrane permeability, which reduces edema
Decreased histamine release and macrophage activity
Destruction of surface bacteria and stimulation of antibodies in the wound bed
Increased intracellular calcium and protein synthesis

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Nonthermal effects of ultrasound include an increase in intracellular calcium levels, skin and cell membrane permeability, histamine release, rate of protein synthesis, rate of mast cell degeneration, and nitric oxide synthesis, all of which promote wound healing.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Ultrasound increases, not decreases, cell membrane permeability.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Ultrasound increases, not decreases, histamine release and macrophage activity.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Ultrasound does not directly destroy bacteria or stimulate antibodies.

subject: Integumentary

question: When you apply cryotherapy to a patient, you can expect to __________ that patient’s sensory and motor nerve conduction velocity.
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The application of cold modalities has been shown to decrease nerve conduction velocity.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Heat increases nerve conduction velocity; cold decreases it.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: There is no initial increase; the effect is a progressive decrease with cooling.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Cryotherapy has a significant and direct effect on nerve conduction velocity.

subject: Other

question: You want to use neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) to facilitate active range of motion in a patient who is recovering from a fractured wrist. The patient has bony union but is limited by soft tissue tightness in her wrist flexors and extensors because of her immobilization. Which of the following stimulation parameters would you recommend?

options.text: Reciprocal stimulation mode using a frequency of 40 Hz and high enough intensity to elicit a full muscle contraction
Reciprocal stimulation mode using a frequency of 2 Hz and high enough intensity to elicit an observable muscle twitch
Synchronous stimulation mode using a frequency of 100 Hz with high enough intensity to elicit a comfortable sensory response
Synchronous stimulation mode using a frequency of Hz with intensity as high as the patient can tolerate

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A reciprocal mode is used because you want to provide contraction and elongation to both muscle groups (flexors and extensors). In order to simulate a functional muscle contraction, you need to use a frequency in the tetanizing range and enough amplitude to produce a strong muscle contraction that can overcome the force of gravity and move the joint through its full range of motion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A frequency of 2 Hz will produce a muscle twitch, not a tetanic contraction needed for functional movement.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A synchronous mode would co-contract the flexors and extensors, preventing movement. A sensory-level response is not the goal.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The question is missing the frequency, but synchronous mode is incorrect for this goal.

subject: Other

question: You have a patient with subacute rheumatoid arthritis in her hands who also has a history of Raynaud’s disease. Which of the following modalities would be contraindicated for this patient?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A patient’s disease or phenomenon is induced by exposure to a cold stimulus, so the cold pack would be contraindicated.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Fluidotherapy is a form of superficial heat and would be appropriate.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A paraffin wax bath is a form of superficial heat and would be appropriate.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Ultraviolet light is used for skin conditions and is not contraindicated by Raynaud's, though precautions for RA would apply.

subject: Other

question: You plan to administer a combination of ultrasound and electrical stimulation to a patient who is experiencing muscle spasm in her upper trapezius and posterior neck muscles following a recent whiplash injury. To perform this type of treatment, what type of electrode setup would you use?

options.text: Bipolar technique using a dispersive pad that is equal to the size of the soundhead
Monopolar technique using a dispersive pad that is much larger than the soundhead
Monopolar technique using a dispersive pad that is much smaller than the soundhead
Quadripolar technique using 2 soundheads and 2 equal-sized dispersive pads

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because the soundhead is the active electrode in a combination treatment such as this, you want the dispersive pad to be relatively inactive. Thus, a monopolar technique in which a larger dispersive pad is attached adjacent to the targeted treatment area would be most appropriate.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A bipolar technique uses two electrodes of equal size over the target area. This describes a monopolar setup.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: In a monopolar setup, the dispersive pad must be larger than the active electrode (the soundhead) to decrease current density and avoid skin irritation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Quadripolar technique is used for interferential current and does not involve an ultrasound soundhead.

subject: Other

question: You are treating a 12-year-old patient with Osgood Schlatter’s disease and want to apply a modality treatment over his tibial tuberosity to help relieve his pain. Which of the following modalities should you probably avoid using in a patient this age?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Although no evidence has supported prior concerns that ultrasound may damage a growing epiphysis, treating over these bony sites with ultrasound is still not generally recommended, particularly when other treatment options exist.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Ice massage is a common and safe treatment for pain and inflammation in Osgood-Schlatter's.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Iontophoresis can be used with caution, but ultrasound over an active growth plate is the primary concern.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: TENS is a safe modality for pain relief in this condition.

subject: Other

question: You have an older patient with balance problems who you think would benefit from walking in a therapeutic pool. However, this patient also has some lower extremity edema associated with venous insufficiency. What effect might the pool therapy have on her edema?

options.text: The hydrostatic pressure exerted by the water should reduce her edema.
The relaxing effect of the water is likely to slow her circulation and diminish her edema.
Her edema will probably worsen because therapeutic pools are usually heated to at least 100° F.
It should have no effect on her edema because walking in water is not that strenuous.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The hydrostatic pressure exerted by the water (near this patient’s legs and feet) will help push fluid up and out of the lower extremities and back into the central circulation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: While relaxation may occur, the primary mechanism for edema reduction is hydrostatic pressure.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While warm water can cause some vasodilation, the effect of hydrostatic pressure is typically stronger and will help reduce edema.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The hydrostatic pressure of the water will have a significant effect on edema, independent of the exercise intensity.

subject: Other

question: The use of birth control pills does not contraindicate or add precautions to the use of short wave diathermy, so it is an unnecessary question. All of the other questions may have some relevance to the use of this modality over this particular part of the body.

options.text: Do you know if you have a urinary infection or a pelvic tumor?
Do you take birth control pills?

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The use of birth control pills does not contraindicate or add precautions to the use of short wave diathermy, so it is an unnecessary question. All of the other questions may have some relevance to the use of this modality over this particular part of the body.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Menstruation is a precaution for diathermy over the low back/pelvis due to potential increased bleeding.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Pregnancy is an absolute contraindication for diathermy over the low back/pelvis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Active infection or a tumor (malignancy) are absolute contraindications for diathermy.

subject: Other

question: A college student injures his ankle in an intramural volleyball game. X-rays reveal no evidence of fracture, so he is referred to PT for treatment of an acute ankle sprain. Which of the following modalities would be most appropriate to apply at this time?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The combination of cryotherapy and compression is best for reducing edema because the cold will cause vasoconstriction and the compression will prevent the build-up of fluid in the interstitial spaces. The other choices are all heat modalities, which can aggravate the edema formation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Heat is contraindicated in an acute injury as it would increase swelling and inflammation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Fluidotherapy is a form of superficial heat and is contraindicated in the acute phase.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Short wave diathermy is a deep heating modality and is contraindicated in the acute phase.

subject: Other

question: You receive a referral to treat a decubitus ulcer over a patient’s sacrum. Following hydrotherapy to clean and debride the ulcer, you decide to irradiate the wound with ultraviolet light. Before administering a UV treatment, you need to ask your patient if he/she

options.text: Is currently taking any medications that cause sensitivity to sunlight

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The use of photosensitive medications can affect the choice of treatment intensity when using ultraviolet treatment. The rest of the questions are not particularly relevant to the use of this modality in terms of precautions or treatment parameters.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A cardiac pacemaker is not a contraindication for UV light therapy.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Food allergies are not relevant to UV light therapy.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A history of sunburn is a general precaution but less critical than current photosensitizing medication use.

subject: Other

question: The intensity of an infrared or ultraviolet lamp is greatest when the lamp is

options.text: Positioned closer to the patient at a 45 degree angle
Positioned closer to the patient at a 90 degree angle (perpendicular to skin)
Positioned further from the patient at a 90 degree angle (perpendicular to skin)
Radiating the skin through a sheet or thin towel

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: According to the Inverse Square and Cosine Laws, the intensity of the radiation will be most intense when the light source is positioned closer to the object and perpendicular to its surface.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A 45-degree angle is less efficient for energy transfer than a 90-degree angle (Cosine Law).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Moving further from the patient decreases intensity (Inverse Square Law).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Radiating through a towel would block or scatter the radiation, decreasing the intensity delivered to the skin.

subject: Other

question: How does low-powered (“cold”) laser light differ from other types of phototherapy?

options.text: Laser light has greater divergence from its source.
Laser light is monochromatic (i.e., one wavelength).
Light waves from lasers are transmitted in an asynchronous, noncoherent manner.
Laser light is classified as a form of ionizing radiation.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: By definition, a laser emits light of a specific wavelength; thus, it is monochromatic. Cluster diodes used in newer therapeutic lasers usually contain several lasers of differing wavelengths. The other unique characteristics of laser light are that it does not diverge much from its source (i.e., less “scatter” of the light), and the waves travel in a synchronous pattern. Low-powered lasers are nondestructive because they are not in the ionizing range of the electromagnetic spectrum.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Laser light is highly collimated, meaning it has very little divergence.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Laser light is coherent, meaning the light waves travel in phase with each other.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Low-level laser therapy uses non-ionizing radiation.

subject: Other

question: A young woman is referred to you with severe muscle spasm in her back that began shortly after she started working as a ticket agent at the local airport. You think that some deep heat will really help calm down her spasm. When you ask about her past history of back problems she tells you that she had scoliosis as a child but underwent a surgical fusion (with metal rods) to stop the progression of her curve. She thinks her limited spinal mobility may have been what triggered her spasm. Based on this history, which thermal modality would you choose?

options.text: Diathermy because it selectively heats muscle tissue the best
Ultrasound because diathermy is contraindicated in this patient
Hot pack because both diathermy and ultrasound are contraindicated
None of the above because heat will only make her muscle spasm worse

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Heat should help reduce this patient’s muscle spasm. However, the target tissue in this case is too deep to be effectively heated with superficial modalities such as hot packs. Because she had metal rods in her back, diathermy is contraindicated even though it tends to heat muscle tissue better than ultrasound.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Diathermy is contraindicated in patients with metal implants.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Ultrasound over metal implants is not contraindicated. A hot pack would be too superficial to reach the deep back muscles.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Heat is an appropriate modality for reducing muscle spasm; the choice is a matter of selecting the safest and most effective method.

subject: Other

question: Why must a patient’s skin be cleaned and debrided before applying electrodes?

options.text: To determine whether his or her sensation is intact
To reduce current density at the electrode-tissue interface

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Rubbing the skin surface with soap or alcohol will remove any dirt, lotions, or skin oils that may create impedance to the electrical current and ensure better conductivity using the least amount of intensity.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While it helps keep electrodes clean, the primary reason is electrical, not hygienic.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Cleaning the skin does not test sensation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Current density is determined by the electrode size and current intensity, not by cleaning the skin.

subject: Other

question: In Figure 5-2, which stimulation parameter is being modulated?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: In the illustration provided, the height of each pulse (i.e., amplitude) progressively increases then decreases again. The shape of the pulses, width (i.e., duration) of the pulses, and the space between pulses remain the same.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The width of the pulses on the x-axis remains constant.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The number of pulses per unit of time remains constant.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The shape of the waveform is consistent; only its amplitude is changing.

subject: Other

question: Which of the following patient conditions would electrotherapy be an inappropriate treatment modality?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Electrotherapy may be used to treat all infected wounds, spasticity, and urinary incontinence (via strengthening of the pelvic floor muscles). However, it is contraindicated in patients with a history of seizures because of the possibility that the stimulus might provoke a seizure.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: High-volt pulsed current is often used to facilitate healing of infected wounds.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Electrical stimulation can be used to manage spasticity by stimulating the antagonist muscle or fatiguing the spastic muscle.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Electrical stimulation is a common treatment for strengthening the pelvic floor muscles to treat urinary incontinence.

subject: Other

question: A high frequency sinusoidal (i.e., biphasic) waveform that is typically delivered in bursts of approximately 50 per second and used for muscle strengthening is usually referred to as
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This type of current is known as Russian current. The other currents listed have different waveforms and are usually intended for other clinical indications besides muscle strengthening.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: High-volt uses a pulsed monophasic current.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Interferential current involves the interference of two medium-frequency currents.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Microcurrent uses a very low amperage and is used for tissue healing.

subject: Other

question: Why do most neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) protocols recommend frequency settings between 30 and 50 pulses per second?

options.text: Frequencies lower than this range cannot produce a muscle contraction.
Higher frequencies usually stimulate the nociceptors and make the patient uncomfortable.
It produces a smooth, tetanic muscle contraction without excessive fatigue.
Most muscle stimulators cannot produce frequencies above or below this range.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Muscle tetany is usually achieved at a pulse rate between 30 and 50 pulses per second (Hz). Because a smooth contraction is desired for muscle strengthening or range of motion, most NMES protocols include frequency settings in this range. A contraction can be elicited at lower frequency settings (will present as a twitch response), and higher frequency settings may be used, particularly with a goal to fatigue a muscle that is in spasm.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Lower frequencies will produce a muscle twitch, just not a smooth, fused (tetanic) contraction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: While higher frequencies can be more uncomfortable, the primary reason for this range is to achieve tetany without rapid fatigue.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Most stimulators can produce a wider range of frequencies.

subject: Other

question: In which of the following situations would it be appropriate to use a low frequency (i.e., 1 to 5 Hz) to stimulate a muscle?

options.text: When a muscle is very weak or partially innervated and very weak
When stimulating the intrinsic muscles of the hand or foot
When you are trying to relax a muscle that is in spasm
When you are trying to stretch a joint contracture

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A very weak or partially innervated muscle is easily prone to fatigue, so a lower frequency setting is indicated for these patients.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The muscle size does not dictate the frequency; the goal of the contraction does.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: To fatigue a muscle in spasm, a higher frequency might be used to induce tetany and subsequent fatigue.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This requires a prolonged, strong contraction, which is best achieved with a tetanizing frequency (30-50 Hz).

subject: Other

question: When using NMES, when would you want to use a long rise/ramp time (i.e., 2 to 3 seconds)?

options.text: When stimulating a completely denervated muscle
When stimulating a hypotonic (i.e., flaccid) muscle
When stimulating a hypertonic (i.e., spastic) muscle
When stimulating the antagonist of a hypertonic (i.e., spastic) muscle

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: When using electrical stimulation to help reduce spasticity, many protocols stimulate the antagonist of the spastic muscle because it is usually in a weakened state. However, if the stimulus is brought on too quickly by using a fast rise/ramp time, it may cause a quick stretch to the spastic muscle, thus exacerbating the problem.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Ramp time is not the primary concern for a denervated muscle; long pulse duration is.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A flaccid muscle does not require a long ramp time; the goal is simply to achieve a contraction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Stimulating a spastic muscle directly would increase its spasticity.

subject: Neurology

question: Which muscles would you stimulate if you were using NMES to help correct a subluxed glenohumeral joint in a patient who has had a stroke?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because the subluxed humerus is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly, the supraspinatus and posterior deltoid muscles are usually stimulated simultaneously to help reverse the subluxed position.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Stimulating the anterior deltoid could worsen an anterior subluxation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: These are scapular stabilizers; while important, they do not directly re-seat the humeral head.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The latissimus dorsi and teres major are internal rotators and would not help correct the typical subluxation pattern.

subject: Neurology

question: The concept of current dosage in iontophoresis refers to the

options.text: Current amplitude (intensity) multiplied by treatment time
Current density as determined by the size of the delivery electrode
Current polarity in relation to the medication’s polarity
Difference between the phase charge and the treatment time

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: An important aspect of iontophoresis is to deliver a sufficient amount of medication to the tissues. Thus, it takes a combination of current intensity and treatment time to achieve the desired results. A current dosage of 40 m

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Current density is a related but separate concept that influences comfort and safety.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Polarity determines which electrode to use for a given drug but does not define the dosage.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is not a standard term or concept in iontophoresis.

subject: Other

question: If you are using electrical stimulation to limit edema formation in an acutely injured joint, the amplitude should be adjusted to produce a
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: When the injury is acute and edema is still forming, stimulation should be kept at the sensory level to avoid further injury to the tissues. Sensory-level stimulation is all that is needed to effect the cell permeability changes that help reduce the edema formation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A muscle contraction in an acute injury could be painful and exacerbate the inflammation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A strong muscle contraction is contraindicated in the acute phase of injury.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A subsensory response (microcurrent) is a different type of stimulation; for edema control with conventional ESTIM, a sensory-level response is typically used.

subject: Other

question: Why is a modulated current recommended when using conventional TENS for pain control?

options.text: It provides combined effects of sensory and motor level TENS.
It reduces the placebo effect of TENS.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: With sensory-level TENS, the body can quickly adapt, or habituate, to the sensation which diminishes its effects. By modulating the pulse amplitude, frequency, and/or duration, the body does not have the opportunity to get used to the sensation and should continue to respond to it.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Modulation refers to varying the parameters, not combining sensory and motor effects.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: It does not reduce the placebo effect.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While conventional TENS does activate A-beta fibers, modulation is specifically to prevent adaptation to that stimulation.

subject: Other

question: Nerves cannot achieve a continuous state of excitation due to
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Refractory period is the amount of time it takes for an excitable membrane to be ready for a second stimulus once it returns to its resting state following excitation. In the generation of an action potential, the membrane potential is increased, both the sodium and potassium ion channels begin to open. This increases both the inward sodium current (which is called depolarization) and the balancing outward potassium current (which is called repolarization). Threshold is the amount of current required for voltage to increase past a critical limit, typically 15 mV higher than the resting value. This results in initiating a process whereby the positive feedback from the sodium current activates even more sodium channels, and this eventually leads to the generation of an action potential.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Threshold is the level that must be reached to initiate an action potential.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Depolarization is the phase of the action potential where the nerve is actively firing.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Repolarization is the phase where the nerve returns to its resting state.

subject: Neurology

question: When utilizing electrical stimulation, what is the pulse frequency range for tetany?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Pulse frequency determines the rate of action potential activation. Frequency influences the strength and motor response of a single motor unit. Increasing frequency changes muscle response from twitch to tetany. Tetanic range in most muscles. Anything less will result in twitch muscle responses. Increases in frequency past 50 pps deplete neurotransmitter supply in neuromuscular junction and depletes muscles energy supplies (ATP).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This range will produce individual muscle twitches.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This range will produce individual muscle twitches.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This range will produce a tetanic contraction but may also lead to more rapid fatigue than the 25-50 pps range.

subject: Other

question: What is the duty cycle for an electrical stimulation program with 6 seconds on time and 18 seconds off time?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Duty cycle is the percentage of time that stimulation is on or active. Duty cycle = {on time/(on + off time)} × 100%. In this case, 6 sec on/(6 on + 18 sec off) = 25% duty cycle (1:3 ratio).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is incorrect. 6 / (6+18) = 6/24 = 0.25 or 25%.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This would correspond to a 1:2 ratio (e.g., 6s on / 12s off).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This would correspond to a 1:1 ratio (e.g., 6s on / 6s off).

subject: Other

question: When stimulating the wrist extensors, the best current type/electrode configuration is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Electrode placement or electrode configuration is dependent on several factors, including the size of electrodes, distance between the electrodes, distance from motor points, polarity of electrodes, and type of waveform utilized. A monopolar electrode configuration occurs when one electrode is located over target tissue (active) and a second electrode over a distant site (inactive). A bipolar configuration occurs when both electrodes are over the target area and both electrodes are usually active. Monopolar configurations are often used when current must be kept in a small area. Bipolar is utilized when current is desired in a larger target area. Asymmetrical or monophase configurations refer to a type of electrical waveform. It is utilized when current is desired in greater dosages at a specific electrode site. One active electrode is placed close to the motor point while the other electrode is placed at another point to disperse current. Symmetric or biphasic waveforms are utilized when both electrodes need to be equally active. This is utilized in muscles that are larger or require more current. Wrist extensors are a small muscle mass that requires specific current to a small region. The asymmetric biphasic waveform with monopolar electrode configuration will provide the configuration for this muscle mass.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Symmetric biphasic is better for larger muscles. A monopolar setup is appropriate here.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Symmetric biphasic is for larger muscles, and a bipolar setup might be too diffuse for targeting the small wrist extensors.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A bipolar setup is less ideal than monopolar for targeting a specific small muscle group.

subject: Other

question: When utilizing electrical stimulation, the key element of pulsed current is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: There are three classes of electrical current. Direct current (DC) is characterized by a continuous or uninterrupted unidirectional flow of charged particles. Alternating current (AC) refers to a continuous or uninterrupted bidirectional flow of charged particles. Pulsed current is a unidirectional or bidirectional flow of charged particles that periodically ceases for a finite period of time. A period of electrical silence is a hallmark characteristic of pulsed current.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Duration is a parameter of the pulse, but the defining characteristic is the interruption of flow.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Frequency is a parameter, not the defining element.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Amplitude is a parameter, not the defining element.

subject: Other

question: A 29-year-old woman fractured her right midtibia in a skiing accident 3 months ago. After cast removal, a severe foot drop was noted. The patient wants to try electrical stimulation orthotic substitution. You would set up the functional electrical stimulation to contract the appropriate muscles during
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: While foot drop itself can be the result of numerous pathologies (both neurologic and orthopedic), weakness of the tibialis anterior muscle results in an impaired ability to dorsiflex the foot. This deficit is most apparent during the swing phase of gait in which the foot is required to dorsiflex in order to clear the toes as the foot progresses forward in the air.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: At toe-off, the plantarflexors are active, not the dorsiflexors.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Push-off is primarily a function of the plantarflexors.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Foot flat is the period when the foot is on the ground; stimulation is needed during swing to clear the foot.

subject: Neurology

question: A patient has been referred to you following a fracture of the femur six months ago. The cast was removed, but the patient was unable to volitionally contract the quadriceps. You decide to apply electrical stimulation to the quadriceps muscle. Your choice of electrode placement and electrical stimulation duty cycle (on/off) would consist of
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Large electrodes should be utilized because the quadriceps are a large muscle group and a wider electrical field will allow for the recruitment of a greater number of motor units. Widely spaced electrodes are needed because electricity will travel the path of least resistance. If the electrodes are placed closely, that pathway will be superficial. By spreading the electrodes out wider, the current will flow deeper to the muscles motor points. The 10:30 duty cycle will provide the muscle with adequate recovery time between contractions as opposed to the 10 second rest cycle of the 10:10 duty cycle.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A 10:10 (1:1) duty cycle is too short for a strengthening protocol and will cause rapid fatigue. Electrodes should be widely spaced for deep penetration.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Small electrodes are not ideal for stimulating a large muscle group like the quadriceps.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This option uses both small electrodes and an inappropriate duty cycle.

subject: Other

question: A 31-year-old patient complains of patellar tendonitis as a result of a mountain climbing accident 3 weeks ago. The patient complains of pain with resisted knee extension, stair climbing, and sit-to-stand movements. You choose to apply iontophoresis using a pain medication with a positive charge. The correct type, polarity, and active electrode placement is

options.text: Monophasic current with anode placed on the tendon
Monophasic current with cathode placed on the tendon
Biphasic current with the cathode placed proximal on the tendon
Low-volt, continuous current with the anode placed distal on the tendon

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: When ionizable substances such as acids, basis, salts or alkaloids are dissolved in water, the substances dissolve and dissociate into their polar components (ionization). Resulting solutions (electrolytes) can carry an electrical current by virtue of the migration of the associated ions. When a direct current (DC) is passed between two electrodes in an electrolytic solution, positive ions will be repelled from the anode (+) and negative ions repelled from the cathode (–). The anode will repel the positively charged ion from the electrode and into the body. Electrostatic repulsion of like charges is the driving force for iontophoresis. Direct current is the continuous or uninterrupted unidirectional flow of charged particles. It allows for continuous transmission of the medication and assures maximum ion transfer per unit of applied current. Pulsed, AC, and interferential currents are less effective in meeting the need of causing a local medication effect.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The cathode (negative electrode) would be used to repel a negatively charged medication.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Biphasic current alternates polarity and cannot drive ions in one direction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While the current is continuous, the key elements are the monophasic nature and correct polarity (anode for a positive drug).

subject: Other

vignetteText: A 3-month-old baby boy who has been diagnosed with congenital muscular torticollis is brought by his parents to physiotherapy in an out-patient department. On palpation, the physiotherapist finds tightness on the left sternocleidomastoid muscle.
question: In which of the following positions would the baby most likely maintain his head?

options.text: Right lateral flexion and rotation to the right.
Right lateral flexion and rotation to the left.
Left lateral flexion and rotation to the left.
Left lateral flexion and rotation to the right.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle's primary actions are ipsilateral lateral flexion and contralateral rotation. A tight or shortened left SCM will therefore pull the baby's head into left lateral flexion (tilting the head to the left) and rotation to the right.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This position would be caused by a tight right SCM, not a left SCM.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This describes right lateral flexion (right SCM) and left rotation (right SCM), which is inconsistent with a tight left SCM.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Left rotation is caused by the right SCM. A tight left SCM causes right rotation.

subject: Musculoskeletal

vignetteText: A 3-month-old baby boy who has been diagnosed with congenital muscular torticollis is brought by his parents to physiotherapy in an out-patient department. On palpation, the physiotherapist finds tightness on the left sternocleidomastoid muscle.
question: The physiotherapist teaches a home program to the baby's parents. Which of the following instructions should the physiotherapist emphasize?

options.text: Incorporating the exercises into the baby's daily routine.
Pursuing the exercises intensively at frequent intervals during the day.
Carrying out the exercises only when the baby is awake and can participate.
Doing the exercises only when the baby is asleep.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Integrating exercises into daily routines, such as during feeding, play time, and diaper changes, is the most effective strategy. This approach improves adherence and consistency by making the program a natural part of the day rather than a separate, stressful event.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Intensive exercises at frequent intervals can be distressing for the infant and overwhelming for the parents, leading to poor compliance and a negative association with handling.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This is too restrictive. Passive stretching and positioning can be effectively performed when the baby is calm or even lightly asleep.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is also too restrictive and misses many opportunities for active and passive movements during the baby's awake periods.

subject: Musculoskeletal

vignetteText: A 3-month-old baby boy who has been diagnosed with congenital muscular torticollis is brought by his parents to physiotherapy in an out-patient department. On palpation, the physiotherapist finds tightness on the left sternocleidomastoid muscle. The baby's torticollis improves with physiotherapy treatment. However, during a follow-up assessment at eight months, the physiotherapist identifies a motor delay.
question: Which of the following assessment tools should the physiotherapist use to determine the child's motor performance in relation to his peers?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The Alberta Infant Motor Scale (AIMS) is a norm-referenced tool used to assess the gross motor development of infants from birth to 18 months. It is designed to compare an infant's performance to that of a normative peer group, making it the ideal choice for identifying a motor delay.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The Gross Motor Function Measure (GMFM) is a criterion-referenced tool designed to measure changes in motor function over time, primarily in children with cerebral palsy. It does not compare performance to peers.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The Ashworth Scale is used to assess muscle tone and spasticity, not motor performance or developmental milestones.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The Functional Independence Measure (FIM) is an assessment tool that measures the level of a person's disability and indicates the burden of care. It is typically used with an adult population.

subject: Neurology

vignetteText: A 50-year-old man sustained full thickness burns to his face, upper body, and arms at work. He is admitted to an acute care facility. He has also been diagnosed with a restrictive pulmonary complication secondary to the burn.
question: Which of the following findings would the physiotherapist expect to find on assessment with respect to the client's restrictive pulmonary complication?

options.text: Decreased vital capacity and increased pulmonary resistance.
Decreased vital capacity and decreased pulmonary resistance.
Increased vital capacity and increased pulmonary resistance.
Increased vital capacity and decreased pulmonary resistance.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Restrictive pulmonary conditions, such as those caused by extensive torso burns leading to eschar formation, limit lung expansion. This restriction results in a decreased vital capacity (the maximum amount of air that can be exhaled). The stiffening of the chest wall also increases the resistance the respiratory system must overcome to inflate, thus increasing pulmonary resistance.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: While vital capacity is decreased, pulmonary resistance would be increased, not decreased, due to the stiff, non-compliant chest wall.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Vital capacity would be decreased, not increased, as lung expansion is physically restricted.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Vital capacity would be decreased, and pulmonary resistance would be increased. This option has both incorrect.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

vignetteText: A 50-year-old man sustained full thickness burns to his face, upper body, and arms at work. He is admitted to an acute care facility. He has also been diagnosed with a restrictive pulmonary complication secondary to the burn. The physiotherapist's caseload has doubled today due to an illness of a colleague.
question: Which of the following would be the best approach for the physiotherapist to manage the increased caseload?

options.text: Complete full treatments for all clients before leaving work.
Shorten all treatments in order to see all clients within work hours.
Provide treatment only to clients who were not seen yesterday.
Prioritize clients who would deteriorate without treatment.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: In a situation with a suddenly increased caseload, the primary professional responsibility is to use clinical reasoning to triage patients based on urgency. The physiotherapist must prioritize those who are at the greatest risk of deteriorating or suffering adverse outcomes if they do not receive treatment, ensuring patient safety is maintained.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This is likely unrealistic and may lead to physiotherapist burnout and compromised quality of care due to rushing.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Shortening all treatments equally may mean that critically ill patients do not receive adequate care, while stable patients may not have needed a full session. This lacks clinical prioritization.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This approach is arbitrary and not based on clinical need. A patient seen yesterday could have deteriorated and now be a high priority, while a patient not seen might be stable.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

vignetteText: A 60-year-old man with post-polio syndrome is experiencing a deterioration of his physical status. He is attending out-patient physiotherapy at a rehabilitation centre.
question: During assessment, the physiotherapist notes weakness of the erector spinae muscle group. Which of the following postures is the physiotherapist likely to observe?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Weakness of the erector spinae muscles, which are primary extensors of the spine, leads to a reduced ability to maintain an upright, extended posture. This results in a slouched or flexed posture, characterized by a flattening or decrease in the natural lumbar lordosis, often accompanied by an increase in thoracic kyphosis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Weakness of the erector spinae would likely lead to an increased, not decreased, thoracic kyphosis (a 'slumped' posture).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: An increased lumbar lordosis (swayback) is typically associated with tightness of the erector spinae and hip flexors, and weakness of the abdominals and gluteals, not weakness of the erector spinae.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Thoracic scoliosis is a lateral curvature of the spine and, while it can involve muscle imbalances, it is not the direct and primary postural deviation expected from bilateral erector spinae weakness.

subject: Musculoskeletal

vignetteText: A 60-year-old man with post-polio syndrome is experiencing a deterioration of his physical status. He is attending out-patient physiotherapy at a rehabilitation centre. The client has greater paralysis on his left lower extremity, which may be contributing to right knee and ankle pain due to overuse.
question: Which of the following supportive devices should the physiotherapist recommend for the left lower extremity?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Post-polio syndrome often results in significant, flaccid paralysis. To support a lower extremity with extensive paralysis affecting muscles around the knee and ankle, a Knee-Ankle-Foot Orthosis (KAFO) is required. A KAFO provides stability to both the knee and ankle joints, preventing buckling and controlling foot position during gait.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A neoprene sleeve provides compression and proprioceptive feedback but offers no structural support for a paralyzed limb.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: An ankle splint would only support the ankle, leaving the knee unstable due to the paralysis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A hinged knee brace would support the knee but would not address the paralysis affecting the ankle and foot.

subject: Neurology

vignetteText: A 60-year-old man with post-polio syndrome is experiencing a deterioration of his physical status. He is attending out-patient physiotherapy at a rehabilitation centre. The client has used crutches for eight years. He states that his walking has slowed, and longer distances are more fatiguing.
question: Which of the following aids should the physiotherapist recommend for longer distances in the community?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The client reports significant fatigue with walking longer distances, indicating a decline in endurance secondary to post-polio syndrome. For community mobility over long distances, a powered scooter is the most appropriate recommendation. It conserves energy, allows for independent community access, and addresses the issue of fatigue that limits his walking.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A four-wheeled walker still requires the user to ambulate, which is the fatiguing activity. It would not sufficiently address the endurance issue for long distances.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A two-wheeled walker is even less efficient for ambulation than a four-wheeled one and would not be an appropriate progression.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A manual wheelchair requires significant upper body strength and endurance, which may also be affected by post-polio syndrome and could be fatiguing over long distances.

subject: Neurology

vignetteText: A 29-year-old man attends physiotherapy at a rehabilitation centre. He fell onto his right elbow four weeks ago. The client reports pain and numbness in the ring finger and little finger and difficulty using the right hand.
question: When assessing the right upper extremity, which of the following sustained movements would the physiotherapist expect to exacerbate the client's symptoms?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The symptoms described (numbness in the ring and little finger) are characteristic of ulnar nerve compression or irritation, often at the cubital tunnel of the elbow. Sustained elbow flexion places the ulnar nerve on stretch and decreases the volume of the cubital tunnel, which would be expected to exacerbate symptoms of nerve compression.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Elbow extension typically reduces tension on the ulnar nerve at the cubital tunnel and would be more likely to relieve than exacerbate the symptoms.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While wrist flexion can be part of an ulnar nerve tension test, sustained elbow flexion is the most direct and common provocative position for cubital tunnel syndrome.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Forearm supination is not a primary movement that places significant stress on the ulnar nerve at the elbow.

subject: Musculoskeletal

vignetteText: A 29-year-old man attends physiotherapy at a rehabilitation centre. He fell onto his right elbow four weeks ago. The client reports pain and numbness in the ring finger and little finger and difficulty using the right hand.
question: The physiotherapist performs the Tinel's test on the client. In which of the following areas would the physiotherapist most likely expect a positive test result?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The client's symptoms are in the ulnar nerve distribution. Tinel's test involves tapping over a nerve to elicit a tingling sensation in its distribution, indicating irritation. The most likely site of irritation given the mechanism and symptoms is the ulnar nerve as it passes through the cubital tunnel at the medial aspect of the elbow.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Tapping at the carpal tunnel would test for median nerve compression, which would cause symptoms in the thumb, index, and middle fingers.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The lateral epicondyle is the site of the common extensor tendon origin; tapping here is not a standard Tinel's test and would not provoke ulnar nerve symptoms.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The cubital fossa is on the anterior aspect of the elbow and contains the brachial artery, biceps tendon, and median nerve, but not the ulnar nerve.

subject: Musculoskeletal

vignetteText: A 54-year-old woman fell on an outstretched right hand while at work. She experienced immediate hand and wrist pain. A Colles’ fracture was confirmed on x-ray. After six weeks in a cast, the client’s x-rays show poor callus formation, and she is reporting right shoulder and elbow pain. She is re-casted and referred to a private physiotherapy clinic.
question: Before initiating treatment, the physiotherapist describes the proposed treatment and possible outcomes to the client. Why should the physiotherapist do this?

options.text: To allow the client to make an informed decision about her treatment.
To allow the physiotherapist to justify the treatment intervention.
To prevent the client from asking too many questions during treatment.
To allow the physiotherapist to avoid litigation.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This action is the cornerstone of obtaining informed consent. Providing the client with information about the proposed treatment, its risks, benefits, alternatives, and likely outcomes empowers them to be an active participant in their care and make an autonomous, informed decision that aligns with their goals and values.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: While the discussion may inherently justify the treatment, its primary purpose is client-centered (informed decision-making) rather than therapist-centered (justification).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The goal is to encourage questions, not prevent them, to ensure the client fully understands the proposed care.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While obtaining informed consent is a critical risk management strategy that helps avoid litigation, its primary ethical purpose is to respect client autonomy, not simply to protect the physiotherapist.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

vignetteText: A 54-year-old woman fell on an outstretched right hand while at work. She experienced immediate hand and wrist pain. A Colles’ fracture was confirmed on x-ray. After six weeks in a cast, the client’s x-rays show poor callus formation, and she is reporting right shoulder and elbow pain. She is re-casted and referred to a private physiotherapy clinic. During assessment, the client is found to have pain from the shoulder to the elbow, muscle guarding in the shoulder, and limited elbow extension. The pain is disturbing the client’s sleep. The physiotherapist is concerned that the client may be developing adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder.
question: Which pattern of limitation would indicate that the client has a capsular pattern of restriction in the shoulder?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The classic capsular pattern of restriction for the glenohumeral joint (shoulder) is characterized by the greatest limitation in external rotation, followed by abduction, and then internal rotation.
