rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Objective would include the specific interventions performed before the session was stopped.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Plan would outline what will happen at the next session.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist employs a neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) strengthening program of a patient with quadriceps atrophy. Which characteristic of a NMES strengthening program is not accurate?

options.text: frequency of stimulation: 30-75 bursts per second
on/off times: 10-15 seconds on, 50-120 seconds off
frequency of sessions: three times per week

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A typical NMES strengthening protocol involves 10-15 contractions per session. 20-30 contractions would be excessive, especially with the long off-times required, leading to a very lengthy and fatiguing session.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: A frequency of 30-75 bps (or Hz) is the standard range to produce a tetanic muscle contraction for strengthening.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: A long off-time (e.g., 50-120 seconds) relative to the on-time (10-15 seconds) is crucial to allow for muscle recovery and prevent fatigue.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: A frequency of three times per week is a common and effective schedule for NMES strengthening.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist makes a conscious effort to demonstrate particular kinds of behavior that are significant and attainable for an eight-year-old patient. This type of behavior therapy is termed
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Modeling is a form of learning where individuals learn behaviors by observing others. By demonstrating the desired behavior, the therapist is providing a model for the child to imitate.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Flooding is a form of behavior therapy used to treat phobias by exposing the individual to the feared stimulus.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Operant conditioning involves learning through reinforcement and punishment.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Role playing involves acting out a scenario, which is a different technique than demonstrating a specific behavior.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist employed in a rehabilitation hospital reviews the medical record of a 26-year-old patient recently admitted to the facility. The medical record indicates that the patient sustained a spinal cord injury four weeks ago in a diving accident. Which medical diagnosis would result in the patient being most susceptible to autonomic dysreflexia?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency that occurs in patients with spinal cord injuries at or above the T6 level. It is a massive sympathetic nervous system response to a noxious stimulus below the level of the lesion. A T4 level injury is above T6, making this patient highly susceptible.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: A T12 level injury is below T6, so autonomic dysreflexia would not occur.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Cauda equina injury is a lower motor neuron lesion and does not result in autonomic dysreflexia.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Posterior cord syndrome is an incomplete SCI that does not typically cause this condition.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist employed in an acute care hospital reviews a patient's medical information prior to initiating an exercise program. Which condition would not be considered a contraindication for exercise?

options.text: systolic blood pressure drop of 25 mmHg
resting systolic blood pressure of 170 mmHg

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A resting systolic blood pressure of 170 mmHg is considered Stage 2 hypertension. While it requires caution and monitoring, it is a relative contraindication, not an absolute one. Exercise is often indicated for managing hypertension. Absolute contraindications are typically a resting SBP > 200 mmHg or DBP > 110 mmHg.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: An acute systemic illness with fever is an absolute contraindication to exercise.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: A significant drop in systolic blood pressure during exercise is an absolute indication to terminate the session.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Active pericarditis (inflammation of the sac around the heart) is an absolute contraindication to exercise due to the risk of cardiac complications.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A patient rehabilitating from knee surgery exhibits significant weakness in the involved extremity. During the most recent therapy session the patient was able to complete and independent straight leg raise. What muscle is emphasized in the exercise?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A straight leg raise involves active hip flexion with the knee held in extension. The rectus femoris is the only muscle of the quadriceps group that crosses both the hip and knee joints, making it a hip flexor as well as a knee extensor. It is therefore a prime mover in this exercise.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: The vastus medialis is a single-joint knee extensor and is not a hip flexor.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: The vastus lateralis is a single-joint knee extensor and is not a hip flexor.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: The sartorius is a hip flexor, but it also abducts and externally rotates the hip and flexes the knee; it is not the primary muscle emphasized in a straight leg raise.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist establishes goals for a patient following total hip replacement surgery. Which of the following goals is the most clearly defined?

options.text: patient will increase lower extremity strength through the use of ankle cuff weights within three weeks
patient will understand the importance of surgical precautions at all times
patient will perform an independent transfer
patient will demonstrate a three-point gait pattern using axillary crutches within one week

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A well-written goal is specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART). This goal clearly defines the Audience (patient), Behavior (demonstrate a three-point gait pattern), Condition (using axillary crutches), and Degree/Time (within one week).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: This goal is not measurable; it does not specify which muscles or by how much strength will increase.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Understanding is not a measurable behavior for a physical therapy goal.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: This goal is not specific enough; it does not state the type of transfer (e.g., bed to chair, sit to stand).

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A patient coverage form indicates selective debridement is to be performed on a patient rehabilitating from a lower extremity burn. Based on the coverage form, the most likely intervention would be
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Selective debridement refers to the removal of only non-viable tissue. Enzymatic debridement uses topical agents with enzymes that break down necrotic tissue without harming viable tissue, making it a form of selective debridement.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Whirlpool is a form of mechanical, non-selective debridement as it can damage healthy tissue along with removing necrotic tissue.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Wet-to-dry dressings are a form of mechanical, non-selective debridement.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Wound irrigation is a form of non-selective debridement used to cleanse the wound.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist treats a patient with chronic back pain using transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation. When administering sensory level stimulation, which statement most accurately describes the desired amplitude?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Sensory-level stimulation, also known as conventional TENS, is intended to stimulate the large-diameter sensory afferent nerves to achieve pain relief via the gate control theory. The amplitude should be increased until the patient reports a strong but comfortable tingling or buzzing sensation, without a muscle contraction.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: If the stimulation is non-perceptible, it is sub-sensory and will not be effective.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: A visible muscle contraction indicates motor-level stimulation, which is a different type of TENS application.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Noxious stimuli are used for brief-intense TENS to activate descending pain inhibition pathways, not for conventional sensory-level TENS.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist designs an aerobic exercise program for a 54-year-old male rehabilitating from a Colles' fracture. The patient is otherwise healthy and has previously participated in a formal exercise program. Which of the following values would fall within the patient's age-adjusted target heart rate?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: First, calculate the age-predicted max heart rate (APMHR): 220 - 54 = 166 bpm. A typical moderate intensity target heart rate range is 60-90% of max HR. Lower end: 166 * 0.60 = 99.6 bpm. Upper end: 166 * 0.90 = 149.4 bpm. The value of 127 bpm falls comfortably within this range.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: 89 bpm is below the typical target range for a moderate intensity workout for this individual.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: 166 bpm is the patient's predicted maximum heart rate and would not be a target for a sustained aerobic exercise program.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: 187 bpm is above the patient's predicted maximum heart rate.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A physical therapist examines the workstation of a patient with a cumulative trauma disorder. When seated at a video display terminal, how far should the screen be positioned from the patient?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Standard ergonomic guidelines recommend that a computer monitor be positioned approximately an arm's length away from the user. For most adults, this corresponds to a distance of about 20-24 inches, which allows for clear viewing without causing eye strain or encouraging poor posture.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: 6 inches is far too close and would cause significant eye strain and poor neck posture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: 10 inches is also too close for comfortable viewing.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: 32 inches is likely too far away for most users to read the screen clearly without leaning forward.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist entering the hospital physical therapy clinic at 8:00 am finds the waiting room bustling with activity. Which of the following items should be given the highest priority?

options.text: a patient 15 minutes early for a scheduled appointment
a durable medical equipment vendor promoting a new sales line
a young man scheduled to job shadow
a patient seated in a chair crying

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A crying patient indicates emotional or physical distress and is a clear sign that immediate attention is needed. The therapist's primary responsibility is to the well-being and dignity of their patients. Addressing the crying patient takes priority over routine scheduling and non-patient-related activities.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: An early patient can wait until their scheduled time.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: A sales vendor is a low priority and should not take precedence over patient care.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: A job shadower can be addressed after any immediate patient needs are met.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist is responsible for supervising a physical therapist assistant at an off site location. Which of the following would not necessitate a supervisory visit by the physical therapist?

options.text: a change in the patient's medical status
a modification in the treatment plan of care
a request by the physical therapist assistant
an alteration in the patient's level of motivation

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A PTA is qualified to manage fluctuations in a patient's motivation or performance within the established plan of care (e.g., by providing encouragement or modifying exercise parameters). This does not require a formal supervisory visit from the PT.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: A change in medical status requires the clinical judgment of the PT to reassess the patient and determine if the plan of care is still appropriate, necessitating a visit.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Any modification to the overall plan of care or goals must be made by the supervising PT.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: If a PTA requests a supervisory visit, the PT should make one to provide support and ensure proper care.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist prepares the proximal radioulnar joint for mobilization by placing it in the loose packed position. This position is best described as
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The loose-packed (or open-packed) position of a joint is the position where the joint capsule is most relaxed and there is the greatest amount of joint play. For the proximal radioulnar joint, this position is 70 degrees of elbow flexion and 35 degrees of forearm supination.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: This is not the loose-packed position.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: This is not the loose-packed position.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: This is not the loose-packed position.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist employed in an outpatient private practice receives a referral for a patient diagnosed with spondylolisthesis. Which of the following scenarios would be most consistent with the medical diagnosis?

options.text: a 13-year-old female gymnast with no significant medical history
a 17-year-old female tennis player with a 15 degree lateral curvature of the spine
a 28-year-old male machinist with a history of recurrent low back pain
a 67-year-old male with a previous diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Isthmic spondylolisthesis, caused by a fracture of the pars interarticularis, is most common in adolescents involved in sports that require repetitive lumbar hyperextension, such as gymnastics, diving, and football (linemen). A 13-year-old female gymnast fits this classic demographic and risk profile.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: A lateral curvature of the spine is scoliosis, not spondylolisthesis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: While recurrent low back pain is a symptom, the age and occupation are less specific than the young gymnast profile.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Ankylosing spondylitis is a systemic inflammatory condition and is distinct from spondylolisthesis.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist completes a ventral glide of the distal tibiofibular articulation. This type of mobilization technique would be most beneficial to improve
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: For the talocrural joint to dorsiflex, the ankle mortise (formed by the tibia and fibula) must widen slightly. Mobilizing the distal tibiofibular joint, specifically with ventral (anterior) and dorsal (posterior) glides of the fibula on the tibia, increases the mobility of the mortise, which can facilitate improved ankle dorsiflexion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Plantarflexion is not limited by the distal tibiofibular joint in the same way as dorsiflexion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Subtalar inversion is a motion of the subtalar joint, not the distal tibiofibular joint.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Subtalar eversion is a motion of the subtalar joint, not the distal tibiofibular joint.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physician instructs a 26-year-old male to utilize a knee derotation brace for all athletic activities. Which condition would most warrant the use of the derotation brace?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Derotation braces are designed to control rotational forces and anterior tibial translation at the knee. They are most effective and most commonly prescribed for patients with a known ACL insufficiency (a torn ACL that has not been surgically repaired) to provide stability and allow for a safer return to activity.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: A meniscus repair may require bracing, but a derotation brace is specific to cruciate ligament instability.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Bracing following ACL reconstruction is controversial, and many protocols do not use them. The most clear indication is for an *unrepaired*, insufficient ACL.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: A PCL brace is designed differently to prevent posterior tibial translation.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist obtains a gross measurement of hamstrings length by passively extending the lower extremity of a patient in short sitting. The most common substitution to exaggerate hamstrings length is

options.text: weight shift to the contralateral side

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: When testing hamstring length by extending the knee in a sitting position, a patient with tight hamstrings will compensate by posteriorly rotating their pelvis and flexing their lumbar spine. This decreases the stretch on the hamstrings and gives the illusion of greater knee extension range of motion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: A contralateral weight shift does not directly affect the hamstring length measurement.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Anterior pelvic rotation would increase the stretch on the hamstrings and reveal tightness, not exaggerate length.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Hip hiking is not a common substitution for this specific test.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist positions a patient in sidelying in preparation for postural drainage activities. Which lung segment would be indicated based on the patient's position?

options.text: posterior basal segment of the lower lobes
apical segment of the upper lobes
lateral basal segment of the lower lobes
anterior segment of the upper lobes

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The lateral basal segment of the lower lobe is drained by placing the patient in sidelying with the foot of the bed elevated. The patient should be lying on the opposite side of the segment being drained.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Posterior basal segments are drained in a prone position with the foot of the bed elevated.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Apical segments are drained in a sitting, leaning forward position.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Anterior segments are drained in a supine position.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A patient with acute back pain is given a transcutaneous electrical neuromuscular stimulation unit to use at home. The physical therapist provides detailed instructions on the care and use of the unit. Which of the following activities is not the responsibility of the patient?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Pulse rate (frequency) and pulse width (duration) are parameters that are set by the physical therapist based on the desired physiological effect. The patient should only be instructed to adjust the intensity (amplitude) to a comfortable level. Altering other parameters is outside the patient's responsibility and could lead to ineffective or unsafe treatment.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: The patient is always responsible for modulating the intensity to a level that is strong but comfortable.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: The patient must be taught how to apply and change the electrodes.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: The patient is responsible for basic maintenance like changing the battery.

subject: Other

question: A patient with chronic pulmonary dysfunction is placed on a corticosteroid medication to reduce mucosal edema and inflammation. The most common side effect of corticosteroids is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Systemic corticosteroids have a wide range of side effects. One of the most common cardiovascular side effects is an increase in blood pressure (hypertension) due to fluid and sodium retention. Other common side effects include hyperglycemia, osteoporosis, and muscle wasting.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Palpitations are not a primary side effect of corticosteroids.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Arrhythmias are not a common side effect.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Tachycardia is not a primary side effect.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A physical therapist inspects a wound that has large quantities of exudate and therefore requires frequent dressing changes. If the therapist applies a dressing that cannot handle the quantity of exudate present, the most likely outcome is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Maceration is the softening and breakdown of skin resulting from prolonged exposure to moisture. If a dressing cannot absorb the wound exudate, the excess moisture will sit on the surrounding skin, leading to maceration and preventing wound healing.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Granulation is the formation of healthy new tissue and would be inhibited, not caused, by excessive moisture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Epithelialization is the final stage of wound closure and cannot occur in a macerated wound bed.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: While a macerated wound is more susceptible to infection, maceration itself is the most direct and likely outcome of an inappropriate dressing.

subject: Other

question: A patient ambulating in the physical therapy gym suddenly grabs his therapist's arm and indicates that he feels faint. The most appropriate immediate action is

options.text: ask the patient if he has ever previously fainted
assist the patient to a sitting position

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Patient safety is the absolute first priority. When a patient feels faint (presyncope), the most immediate action is to get them into a safe position to prevent a fall and potential injury. Assisting them to a sitting or lying position is the most critical first step.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Assessing pulse rate is an important secondary step, but it should be done only after the patient is in a safe position.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Asking about their history is secondary to ensuring their immediate safety.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Loosening clothing is a helpful measure but is secondary to preventing a fall.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A male physical therapist provides exercise instructions to a female of Portuguese descent. During the treatment session, the patient does not make eye contact with the therapist. The most appropriate action is to

options.text: tell the patient to pay attention
ask the patient if she would prefer a female therapist

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: In many cultures, including some Portuguese communities, avoiding direct eye contact can be a sign of respect, particularly towards a person in a position of authority or of the opposite gender. The therapist should recognize this as a potential cultural difference and continue with the treatment, not misinterpreting it as inattention or disrespect.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: This is a demanding and culturally insensitive response.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: This assumes the issue is gender-related, which may not be the case. The first assumption should be a potential cultural difference.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Discontinuing the instructions is inappropriate and assumes the patient is not paying attention.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist employed in a rehabilitation hospital creates a professional development plan as part of his annual performance appraisal. Which of the following would be the most appropriate plan to facilitate the therapist's development?

options.text: attend continuing education courses approved by the American Physical Therapy Association
attend continuing education courses featuring nationally recognized experts.
attend a minimum of two continuing education courses annually
attending continuing education courses related to primary patient care responsibilities

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The most effective professional development is directly relevant to the therapist's current or desired area of practice. Choosing continuing education courses that enhance skills and knowledge for the specific patient populations the therapist serves is the most logical and beneficial approach.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: While APTA approval is good, it does not guarantee relevance to the therapist's specific needs.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: The reputation of the expert does not guarantee the relevance of the course content.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: This sets a quantity goal but does not address the quality or relevance of the courses.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A patient has difficulty accepting the reality of his condition following lower extremity amputation. Which physical therapist action would not be helpful to promote acceptance?

options.text: refer the patient to a peer support group
avoid treating the patient in a busy areas such as the physical therapy gym
allow the patient to observe sports programs for the physically challenged
offer the patient the opportunity to express feelings of grief and anxiety.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Isolating the patient from others can increase feelings of loneliness and prevent them from seeing other individuals with similar conditions who are successfully engaging in rehabilitation. Treating them in the gym allows for social support from staff and other patients, which is crucial for psychological adjustment.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Peer support groups are an excellent resource for helping patients adjust to a new condition like amputation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Observing adaptive sports can be highly motivating and can help the patient see the potential for a full and active life after amputation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Providing a safe space for the patient to express their feelings is a key component of building a therapeutic alliance and assisting with psychological adjustment.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist reviews the results of an arterial blood gas analysis for a 28-year-old male. Which value would be considered within normal limits for oxygen saturation?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Normal oxygen saturation (SaO2 or SpO2) values for a healthy individual range from 95% to 100%. A value of 97% falls squarely within this normal range.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: 84% indicates severe hypoxia and is a medical emergency.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: 88% indicates moderate hypoxia. Exercise is typically stopped if saturation falls below 88-90%.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: 92% is low and may warrant investigation or supplemental oxygen, especially during activity. It is not considered normal.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A physical therapist conducts an upper quarter screening examination on a patient diagnosed with rotator cuff tendonitis. With the patient in sitting, the most appropriate action to facilitate palpation of the rotator cuff is

options.text: active medial and lateral rotation of the humerus
active extension and flexion of the elbow

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Passively extending the patient's shoulder moves the greater tuberosity of the humerus (the insertion site for most of the rotator cuff tendons) out from under the acromion process. This makes the tendons, particularly the supraspinatus, more accessible to palpation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Passive abduction would cause the greater tuberosity to move under the acromion, making palpation more difficult.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Active rotation engages the muscles, which can make it harder to palpate the specific tendinous insertions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Elbow motion does not affect the position of the rotator cuff tendons relative to the acromion.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient sustains a burst fracture of a thoracic vertebra secondary to a hyperflexion injury. The physician's note indicates the fracture is stable. Which of the following would not be considered appropriate immediate physical therapy management?

options.text: active spinal range of motion exercises
instruction in donning and doffing a spinal brace

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: For a recent, albeit stable, vertebral fracture, active spinal range of motion exercises (especially into flexion) are contraindicated in the immediate phase. The priority is to protect the fracture site and allow for healing. Other activities can be performed while maintaining spinal precautions.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Bed mobility training using spinal precautions (e.g., log rolling) is appropriate and necessary.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Postural education is important to teach the patient how to maintain a safe spinal alignment.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: If a spinal brace has been prescribed, instruction in its use is a key part of immediate management.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist assesses a patient's heart rate by measuring the time necessary for 30 beats. Assuming the therapist measures this value as 22 seconds, the patient's heart rate should be recorded as
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: To calculate the heart rate in beats per minute, you can set up a proportion: (30 beats / 22 seconds) = (x beats / 60 seconds). Solving for x: x = (30 * 60) / 22 = 1800 / 22 = 81.8. The closest value is 82 bpm.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: This calculation is incorrect.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: This calculation is incorrect.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: This calculation is incorrect.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A physical therapist treats a patient following a lower extremity amputation. The patient is currently one-week post amputation and has a post-operative rigid dressing. Which of the following is not a benefit of the rigid dressing?

options.text: limits the development of post-operative edema in the residual limb
allows for earlier ambulation with the attachment of a pylon and foot
allows for earlier fitting of a definitive prosthesis
allows for daily wound inspection and dressing changes

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A rigid dressing (or cast) is not removable. Its primary disadvantage is that it does not allow for daily visual inspection of the wound or dressing changes. This is a trade-off for its benefits in edema control and protection.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Excellent edema control is a primary benefit of a rigid dressing.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: A pylon and foot can be attached to the rigid dressing to create an immediate post-operative prosthesis (IPOP), allowing for very early ambulation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: By controlling edema and shaping the limb, a rigid dressing can lead to an earlier fitting for the definitive prosthesis.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist prepares to formally assess the balance of a patient with a neurological disorder. The most appropriate method to assess the vestibular component of balance would be

options.text: apply a perturbation to alter the body's center of mass
examine proprioception in a weight bearing posture
quantify visual acuity and depth perception

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Applying an external perturbation (e.g., a push or pull) tests the patient's reactive postural control. The vestibular system is a key component of this system, as it senses head motion and acceleration to help generate an appropriate, automatic response to restore balance.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Cutaneous sensation is part of the somatosensory system, not the vestibular system.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Proprioception is part of the somatosensory system.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Visual acuity and depth perception are part of the visual system.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist inspects the skin of a child recently admitted to the hospital after sustaining a scald burn from hot water on his torso. The burn is moist and red with several areas of blister formation. The burn covers an area approximately 8 cm² and blanches with direct pressure. The most likely burn classification is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The key characteristics described—redness, moistness, blister formation, and blanching with pressure—are the classic signs of a superficial partial-thickness burn. This type of burn involves the epidermis and the upper layer of the dermis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: A superficial burn (like a sunburn) is red and painful but does not have blisters.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: A deep partial-thickness burn is more mottled (red and white), may not have blisters, and may not blanch.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: A full-thickness burn is white, leathery, or charred and is insensate; it does not blanch.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist prepares to examine a patient's triceps using a reflex hammer. The most appropriate positioning of the patient's arm during the testing procedure is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: To test a deep tendon reflex, the tendon must be on a slight stretch. For the triceps reflex, this is achieved by passively placing the shoulder into some extension and abduction and allowing the elbow to hang in flexion. This position places the triceps tendon on a gentle stretch, ready to be struck by the reflex hammer.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Elbow extension would place the triceps muscle on slack, making it impossible to elicit a stretch reflex.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Elbow extension would place the triceps on slack.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: This position does not optimally position the triceps tendon for a reflex test.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist measures the blood pressure of a one-month old infant. Which of the following measurements would be the most typical based on the infant's chronological age?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Normal blood pressure in a newborn or one-month-old infant is significantly lower than in an adult. A typical range is 70-90 mmHg systolic and 45-65 mmHg diastolic. The value of 85/60 mmHg falls within this expected range.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: This value is too low, even for an infant.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: This value is on the very low end of the normal range.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: 120/80 mmHg is the normal value for an adult, not an infant.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A physical therapist instructs a patient in an upper extremity proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation pattern by telling the patient to begin by grasping an imaginary sword positioned in a scabbard on their left hip using their right hand. This type of command would be most appropriate to initiate
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The D2 flexion pattern for the upper extremity is a diagonal motion of flexion, abduction, and external rotation. The verbal cue of 'drawing a sword' from the opposite hip accurately describes this motion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: D1 extension is a pattern of extension, abduction, and internal rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: D1 flexion is a pattern of flexion, adduction, and external rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: D2 extension is the opposite of D2 flexion: extension, adduction, and internal rotation (like putting the sword back in the scabbard).

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient status post mastectomy has had difficulty attending physical therapist sessions since being diagnosed with lymphoma. The patient has had an unremarkable recovery, however, has diminished strength and trace edema. After missing an appointment the patient telephoned the physical therapist and explained that he is not able to focus on therapy and needed to cancel two remaining appointments. The most appropriate therapist action is

options.text: explain to the patient the consequences of discontinuing physical therapy
reduce the frequency of physical therapy visits
attempt to convince the patient to continue physical therapy
discharge the patient from physical therapy

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The patient is expressing a clear desire to stop therapy due to their inability to focus, which is understandable given their recent lymphoma diagnosis. Since the recovery has been unremarkable and the impairments are minor, the most appropriate, patient-centered action is to respect their decision and discharge them, likely with a home exercise program.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: This can come across as coercive and does not respect the patient's stated reason for stopping.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: The patient wants to cancel all remaining appointments, not just reduce the frequency.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Attempting to convince the patient ignores their autonomy and the significant emotional burden they are facing.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physician examines a 36-year-old male with shoulder pain. As part of the examination the physician orders x-rays. Which medical condition could be confirmed using this type of diagnostic imaging?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: An x-ray is an imaging modality that is excellent for visualizing dense structures like bone and calcium deposits. Calcific tendonitis, which is the formation of calcium deposits within a tendon, would be visible on an x-ray, whereas soft tissue inflammation would not.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Tendonitis is soft tissue inflammation and is not visible on a standard x-ray.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Impingement is a clinical diagnosis involving soft tissues and cannot be confirmed by x-ray, although bony morphology contributing to impingement (e.g., acromial spurs) can be seen.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Bursitis is soft tissue inflammation and is not visible on an x-ray.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist designs a research study that will examine the effect of high voltage galvanic electrical stimulation on edema following arthroscopic knee surgery. The most appropriate method to collect data is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Circumferential measurements using a flexible tape measure are a simple, reliable, and common method for quantifying edema in a limb like the knee. Taking measurements at standardized points above and below the joint line allows for tracking changes in swelling over time.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Anthropometric measurements is a very general term; circumferential measurement is a specific type.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Goniometric measurements assess range of motion, not edema.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Volumetric measurements (water displacement) are a valid way to measure edema in the hand or foot, but they are not practical for the knee.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A male physical therapist employed in an outpatient orthopedic clinic examines a patient diagnosed with cerebral palsy. The therapist has limited experience with cerebral palsy and is concerned about his ability to provide appropriate treatment. The most appropriate therapist action is

options.text: inform the patient of your area of expertise
co-treat the patient with another more experienced therapist

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Recognizing the limits of one's own expertise is a key professional responsibility. When a therapist is concerned about their ability to provide the best care, co-treating with a more experienced colleague is an excellent solution. It ensures the patient receives high-quality care while also providing a valuable learning opportunity for the therapist.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Informing the patient of your lack of expertise without offering a solution can undermine their confidence and is not helpful.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Treating the patient despite being concerned about your ability to do so appropriately may not provide the best standard of care.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Refusing to treat the patient is a form of patient abandonment. The professional responsibility is to find a way to ensure the patient gets the care they need.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A patient with a 40-degree limitation in right shoulder flexion and a 35-degree limitation in lateral rotation is unable to perform a number of activities of daily living. Which activity would be the most difficult for the patient using the right upper extremity?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Combing hair requires a combination of significant shoulder flexion, abduction, and lateral (external) rotation to bring the hand to the head. Given the patient's specific limitations in flexion and lateral rotation, this activity would be the most difficult to perform.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Tucking in a shirt primarily requires shoulder extension and internal rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Eating requires some shoulder flexion but typically not to the end range, and it does not require significant rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Washing the left shoulder requires shoulder flexion and horizontal adduction, but less lateral rotation than combing hair.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient status post Achilles tendon repair is examined in physical therapy. The physician referral includes a very specific post-operative protocol. If the therapist plans on deviating from the established protocol, the most appropriate action is to
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A post-operative protocol is a direct order from the surgeon. A physical therapist cannot unilaterally decide to deviate from it. If the therapist believes a modification is warranted based on their examination, they must first contact the referring physician to discuss their rationale and receive approval before making any changes.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: The surgical report provides useful information but does not give the therapist permission to alter the protocol.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: A thorough examination is what might lead the therapist to consider a deviation, but it does not authorize one.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Documentation is essential, but it must occur *after* the physician has approved the deviation. Documenting an unauthorized deviation does not make it appropriate.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist develops a plan of care for a patient status post knee surgery. As part of the plan of care the therapist elects to utilize a continuous passive motion machine. Which treatment objective would not be addressed using this intervention?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A continuous passive motion (CPM) machine moves the joint through a set range of motion without any patient effort. Because it is a passive intervention, it does not require muscle contraction. Therefore, it cannot prevent disuse muscle atrophy.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: The gentle, repetitive movement can help to improve circulation and reduce edema.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: The primary purpose of a CPM is to maintain joint mobility and prevent the formation of adhesions and contractures.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: The gentle movement can help to decrease pain by stimulating joint mechanoreceptors (gate control theory) and reducing joint stiffness.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: As a component of a cognitive assessment, a physical therapist asks a patient to count from one to twenty-five by increments of three. Which cognitive function does this task most accurately assess?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This task, often called 'serial threes', requires the patient to hold a set of rules in their head while performing a repetitive mental task. It is a classic test of attention and concentration, as any distraction will cause the patient to lose their place.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Constructional ability is the ability to draw or construct objects and is typically tested by asking a patient to copy a figure.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Abstract ability involves interpreting proverbs or explaining similarities between objects.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Judgment is assessed by posing hypothetical situations and asking the patient what they would do.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist using ultraviolet light determines a patient's minimal erythemal dose using a four-windowed shield. If measured appropriately, reddening of the skin caused by ultraviolet exposure for the minimal erythemal dose should disappear within
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The minimal erythemal dose (MED) is defined as the smallest dose of ultraviolet radiation that produces a faint reddening of the skin that appears within eight hours of exposure and disappears within 24 hours.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: If the redness disappears within 12 hours, the dose was sub-erythemal.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Redness lasting 48 hours would be classified as a first-degree erythemal dose.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Redness lasting up to 72-96 hours would be a second-degree erythemal dose.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist completes an accessibility analysis at a local business. In order to meet minimum accessibility standards, the bathroom sink should have a knee clearance height of at least
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: According to the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) accessibility guidelines, the apron of a bathroom sink must be at least 29 inches from the floor to provide adequate knee clearance for a wheelchair user to approach the sink.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: 23 inches would be too low and would not provide sufficient knee clearance.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: 35 inches is higher than the minimum requirement. The maximum height of the sink counter is typically 34 inches.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: 39 inches is too high.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapy manager randomly selects patient medical records and examines the physical therapy notes. The therapist concludes that several of the notes are incomplete and use unacceptable medical abbreviations. The most appropriate action is to

options.text: post a summary of documentation standards in the physical therapy gym
continue to randomly monitor physical therapy notes
reprimand therapists whose notes were identified as unsatisfactory

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Implementing a peer review system is a structured, professional, and effective method for improving the quality of documentation. It provides an opportunity for therapists to learn from each other, identify areas for improvement in a non-punitive way, and establish consistent departmental standards.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Posting a summary is a passive approach that is less likely to be effective than an active review process.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Continuing to monitor without taking corrective action will not solve the problem.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Reprimanding therapists is a punitive approach that can damage morale. A supportive, educational approach like peer review is more effective.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: An 86-year-old female is partial weight bearing on the left lower extremity after a total hip replacement. Her upper extremity strength is 3+/5 and she resides alone. Which assistive device would be the most appropriate for the patient?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: An elderly patient with upper extremity weakness who lives alone requires a highly stable assistive device. A walker provides the most stability and does not require significant upper extremity strength for support, making it the safest and most appropriate choice.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Lofstrand crutches require good upper extremity strength and trunk control, which this patient lacks.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Axillary crutches require significant upper extremity strength and are often difficult for elderly patients to manage safely.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: A quad cane provides less stability than a walker and may not be sufficient for a patient with a partial weight-bearing status.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient refuses physical therapy services after being transported to the gym. The physical therapist explains the potential consequences of refusing treatment, however, the patient does not reconsider. The most appropriate initial therapist action is

options.text: convince the patient to have therapy
document the incident in the medical record

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A competent patient has the right to refuse treatment at any time. After ensuring the patient is making an informed refusal (by explaining the consequences), the therapist must respect their decision. The essential next step is to document the refusal and the conversation in the medical record.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Treating the patient against their wishes would be battery.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Attempting to convince the patient after they have already made an informed decision undermines their autonomy.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Contacting the physician is a secondary step; the primary responsibility is to respect the patient's decision and document it.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A patient with suspected scaphoid fracture is referred to physical therapy. Which clinical sign is most indicative of a scaphoid fracture?

options.text: localized edema along the dorsum of the hand
crepitus with active range of motion
localized bony tenderness in the anatomic snuff box

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The most indicative clinical sign of a scaphoid fracture is localized tenderness to palpation within the anatomical snuffbox. The floor of the snuffbox is formed by the scaphoid bone, making this the key diagnostic finding.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Edema can be present with any wrist injury and is not specific to a scaphoid fracture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Crepitus is not a typical sign of a scaphoid fracture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Pain with resisted wrist extension is more indicative of wrist extensor tendinopathy.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient in traction for six weeks following a femur fracture is referred to physical therapy. The patient presents with limited range of motion and diminished lower extremity strength. The most appropriate treatment option is

options.text: hot packs and proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: After prolonged immobilization, a patient will have both stiffness and weakness. Using hot packs can help to increase tissue extensibility and reduce pain, preparing the area for stretching. Proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) techniques can then be used to effectively address both the range of motion and strength deficits simultaneously.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Cryotherapy is typically used for acute inflammation, which is not the primary issue after six weeks of immobilization. A CPM machine is used in the immediate post-operative phase.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: While estim and isometrics can address strength, they do not address the range of motion limitation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Ultrasound may be used, but isokinetic exercises require specialized equipment and may be too aggressive at this stage.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient on prolonged bed rest attempts to get out of bed. Upon attaining a standing position the patient complains of lightheadedness and blurred vision. The most appropriate explanation is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Lightheadedness and blurred vision upon standing after prolonged bed rest are classic symptoms of orthostatic (postural) hypotension. This is a condition where blood pressure drops significantly due to the cardiovascular system's inability to adequately compensate for the change in position against gravity.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Respiratory rate is not the primary cause of these symptoms.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: An increase in pulse rate is a compensatory response to the drop in blood pressure, not the cause of the symptoms.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: While an adverse drug reaction is possible, orthostatic hypotension is the most direct and common explanation for these specific symptoms in this context.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A patient's job requires him to move boxes weighing 35 pounds from a transport cart to an elevated conveyor belt. The patient can complete the activity, however, is unable to prevent hyperextension of the spine. The most appropriate physical therapist action is

options.text: use an elevated platform when placing boxes on the belt

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The most direct and effective solution is to modify the workstation to eliminate the need for the problematic movement. Using an elevated platform to raise the height of the boxes would reduce the vertical distance the patient needs to lift, thereby decreasing the need to hyperextend the spine to complete the task.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: While stabilization exercises may be helpful, they do not address the ergonomic cause of the problem.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Abdominal strengthening is a good long-term strategy, but modifying the task provides an immediate solution.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Reviewing body mechanics is appropriate, but the task itself may be ergonomically flawed, making proper mechanics difficult to maintain.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist completes an examination on a 36-year-old female diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. After completing the examination, the therapist should first

options.text: justify the need for physical therapy services

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The clinical reasoning process following an examination involves synthesizing the subjective and objective data to create a problem list. This list of identified impairments and functional limitations forms the basis for all subsequent steps, including goal setting, planning interventions, and justifying the need for therapy.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Goals are developed based on the problems identified in the problem list.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Goals are developed based on the problems identified in the problem list.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Justification for services is derived from the problem list and the goals established to address those problems.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A 21-year-old male patient informs a physical therapist that additional therapy visits will not be covered by his medical insurance provider. The patient is 12 weeks status post anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction and has had an unremarkable post-operative progression. The most appropriate therapist action is

options.text: offer to treat the patient pro bono
request additional visits from the third party payer
discharge the patient with a home exercise program

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The patient has had an unremarkable recovery and is at 12 weeks post-op, a point where they are typically ready to transition to a more independent program. Given the insurance limitation, the most appropriate action is to discharge the patient with a comprehensive home exercise program that includes strengthening, jogging, and agility drills to allow them to continue their progress independently.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Offering pro bono treatment is a kind gesture but may not be sustainable or necessary for a patient who can progress independently.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: A payment plan does not address the fact that continued supervised therapy may no longer be medically necessary.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Requesting additional visits is inappropriate if the patient can safely transition to an independent program.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist prepares to examine a patient status post stroke with left hemisphere involvement. Which patient behavior would not be characteristic of this condition?

options.text: difficulty with mathematical reasoning and judgment
difficulty processing information in a sequential, linear manner

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: While a left hemisphere stroke can cause aphasia and apraxia, difficulty with mathematical reasoning and judgment are more characteristic of a right hemisphere lesion. The left hemisphere is typically dominant for language and sequencing, while the right hemisphere is dominant for spatial-perceptual tasks and abstract reasoning.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Difficulty sequencing movements (apraxia) is a common finding with left hemisphere damage.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Difficulty producing language (aphasia) is a hallmark of a dominant (usually left) hemisphere stroke.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Difficulty with sequential and linear processing is a classic characteristic of a left hemisphere lesion.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist monitors the blood pressure response to exercise of a 52-year-old male on a stationary bicycle. The therapist notes a relatively linear increase in systolic blood pressure with increasing exercise intensity. The change in the patient's systolic blood pressure with exercise is best explained by
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Blood pressure is a product of cardiac output and total peripheral resistance. During exercise, cardiac output (heart rate x stroke volume) increases to deliver more oxygenated blood to the working muscles. This increase in cardiac output is the primary reason that systolic blood pressure rises in a linear fashion with increasing exercise intensity.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Peripheral resistance decreases in the working muscles during exercise, which helps to temper the rise in blood pressure, but the overriding factor is the increase in cardiac output.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Oxygen saturation should remain stable during exercise in a healthy individual.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Myocardial oxygen consumption increases significantly during exercise.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A 64-year-old female patient is admitted to the hospital with a stage III decubitus ulcer over her right ischial tuberosity. The patient's past medical history includes severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The most appropriate position for the patient is

options.text: supine with pillows under the knees
prone with pillows under the knees
left sidelying with pillows between the knees
right sidelying with pillows between the knees

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The goal is to position the patient to offload the pressure ulcer on the right ischial tuberosity while also accommodating their severe COPD. Left sidelying is the best choice because it completely removes pressure from the right side. Prone positioning would be difficult due to the COPD, and supine or right sidelying would place pressure on the ulcer.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Supine positioning would still place some pressure on the right ischium.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Prone positioning is often poorly tolerated by patients with severe COPD as it can restrict chest wall expansion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Right sidelying would place direct pressure on the ulcer and is contraindicated.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist performs a manual muscle test on a patient's shoulder medial rotators. Which muscle would not be involved in this specific test?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The teres minor is a lateral (external) rotator of the shoulder. The primary medial (internal) rotators are the subscapularis, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, and teres major.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Pectoralis major is a powerful medial rotator of the shoulder.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Teres major is a medial rotator of the shoulder.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Latissimus dorsi is a powerful medial rotator of the shoulder.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient in an acute care hospital has a catheter inserted into the internal jugular vein. The catheter travels through the superior vena cava and into the right atrium. The device permits removal of blood samples, administration of medication, and monitoring of central venous pressure. The device is best termed
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A Hickman catheter is a type of indwelling central venous catheter that is tunneled under the skin and inserted into a large vein (like the jugular or subclavian), with its tip resting in the superior vena cava or right atrium. It is used for long-term administration of medications (like chemotherapy), drawing blood, and monitoring central venous pressure.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: An arterial line is placed in an artery (e.g., radial artery) and is used for monitoring blood pressure and drawing arterial blood samples.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Central venous pressure catheter is a general term; Hickman catheter is a specific type.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: A Swan-Ganz catheter is a pulmonary artery catheter that is passed through the right side of the heart into the pulmonary artery to measure more complex hemodynamic pressures.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A patient informs her physical therapist that she noticed a small lump on her right breast while dressing. The patient was referred to physical therapy with lateral epicondylitis and has no significant past medical history. The most appropriate therapist action is

options.text: instruct the patient to make an immediate appointment with her physician
inform the patient she may have cancer
document the patient's comment in the medical record

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The discovery of a new lump is a significant red flag that requires medical evaluation. The physical therapist's role is not to diagnose, but to recognize the potential seriousness of the finding and ensure the patient seeks appropriate medical care. Instructing the patient to see her physician immediately is the most appropriate and responsible action.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Inspecting the lump is outside the physical therapist's scope of practice for this condition.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Informing the patient she may have cancer is speculative, outside the scope of practice, and would cause unnecessary alarm.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Documentation is important, but the priority is to ensure the patient takes action to get a medical diagnosis.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist attempts to confirm the fit of a wheelchair for a patient recently admitted to a skilled nursing facility. After completing the assessment, the therapist determines the wheelchair has excessive seat width. Which adverse effect results from excessive seat width?

options.text: difficulty changing position within the wheelchair
increased pressure to the distal posterior thigh

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: If a wheelchair seat is too wide, the user must excessively abduct their shoulders and arms to reach the handrims. This puts them in a biomechanically inefficient position, making it much more difficult to propel the wheelchair effectively.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Excessive seat width might make it easier, not harder, to change positions.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Insufficient trunk support would be a result, but the primary functional deficit is the difficulty with propulsion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Increased pressure on the distal posterior thigh is a result of a seat depth that is too long, not a width that is too wide.

subject: Neurology

question: A patient uses a self-administered assessment tool as a method to record daily progress. What type of reliability would be the most essential using this tool?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Intratester reliability refers to the consistency of measurements taken by the same person on multiple occasions. Since the patient is self-administering the tool repeatedly over time, it is essential that their own application and scoring of the tool is consistent.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Reliability of parallel forms refers to the consistency between two different versions of the same test.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Internal consistency refers to the extent to which items on a test measure the same construct.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Intertester reliability refers to the consistency of measurements between two or more different testers, which is not relevant when the patient is the only one administering the test.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist observes a patient status post transfemoral amputation lying in supine with a pillow positioned under the residual limb. This position results in the patient being most susceptible to a
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Placing a pillow under the thigh of a transfemoral amputee puts the hip into a position of flexion. Maintaining this position for prolonged periods encourages the development of a hip flexion contracture, which is a common and functionally limiting complication that can interfere with prosthetic fitting and gait.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Since this is a transfemoral amputation, the knee has been removed. A knee flexion contracture is a concern for a transtibial (below-knee) amputation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Knee extension contracture is not possible.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: The position described promotes flexion, not extension.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist administers the Mini-Mental State Examination to a patient recently admitted to an acute care medical facility. The minimum patient score necessary in order to avoid being classified as possessing a cognitive impairment would be
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) is scored on a 30-point scale. A score of 24 is the generally accepted cut-off point. A score below 24 is indicative of a potential cognitive impairment and warrants further investigation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: 28 is well within the normal range.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: 30 is the maximum possible score, indicating no cognitive impairment.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: The MMSE is not scored out of 34.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist identifies excessive lordosis in a patient during a posture screening. Which of the following is most likely associated with this type of finding?

options.text: increased anterior pelvic tilt and lengthened hip extensors
decreased anterior pelvic tilt and shortened hip flexors
increased posterior pelvic tilt and shortened hip extensors
decreased posterior pelvic tilt and lengthened hip flexors

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Excessive lumbar lordosis is biomechanically linked to an increased anterior pelvic tilt. This posture is typically caused by a muscle imbalance known as lower crossed syndrome, which includes tight hip flexors and lumbar extensors, and weak/lengthened abdominal muscles and hip extensors (gluteals and hamstrings).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: This describes the opposite posture (flat back).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: An increased posterior pelvic tilt is associated with a decreased lumbar lordosis (flat back).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: This is a confusing description; an increased anterior pelvic tilt would be the correct term.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist receives a referral to instruct a patient in stair training using axillary crutches. The patient is rehabilitating from a tibial fracture and is currently partial weight bearing on the involved extremity. The most important action prior to initiating the training session is

options.text: maintain proper body mechanics for yourself and the patient
examine the patient's limitations and capabilities

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Before initiating any new, high-risk activity like stair training, the therapist must first perform a thorough examination to assess the patient's strength, range of motion, balance, and ability to follow instructions. This ensures that the activity is safe and appropriate for the patient at that time.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Applying a gait belt is a crucial safety measure that would be done *after* the initial examination determines the patient is ready to proceed.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Maintaining proper body mechanics is important throughout the session.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Assessing vital signs is important, but a physical examination of the patient's capabilities is more critical to determining readiness for this specific task.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist orders a wheelchair for a patient with C4 tetraplegia. Which wheelchair would be the most appropriate for the patient?

options.text: manual wheelchair with friction surface handrims
power wheelchair with sip and puff controls

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A patient with a C4 level spinal cord injury has paralysis of the trunk and all four limbs, but has innervation of the diaphragm (allowing independent breathing) and neck muscles. They cannot use their hands or arms to propel a wheelchair. Sip-and-puff controls allow them to operate a power wheelchair using their breath.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: The patient has no hand function to use these.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: The patient has no arm or hand function to use these.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: A joystick requires hand and arm control, which is absent at the C4 level.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist employed in an inpatient rehabilitation center works with a patient rehabilitating from a total knee replacement. Which treatment activity would be the most appropriate to delegate to a physical therapy aide?

options.text: measuring knee range of motion with a goniometer
observing a patient complete a mat exercise program
recording modality parameters in the medical record

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A physical therapy aide is a non-licensed worker who can perform routine tasks under the direct supervision of a physical therapist. Observing a patient performing an *established* exercise program and reporting back to the therapist is a supportive task that does not require clinical decision-making, making it appropriate for an aide.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Monitoring vital signs requires interpretation and is a skilled task that should be performed by a PT or PTA.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Goniometry is a skilled assessment that requires clinical judgment and should not be delegated to an aide.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Recording in the medical record is typically done by the licensed provider who delivered the service.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A physical therapist develops a plan of care for a patient status post unilateral transtibial amputation. Assuming an uncomplicated recovery, what is the most appropriate number of weeks for prosthetic training?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: For a standard, uncomplicated transtibial amputation, a focused period of prosthetic training lasting approximately two weeks is typical. This timeframe is usually sufficient to teach donning/doffing, prosthetic management, transfers, and basic ambulation and stair negotiation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Four weeks would be a longer than average training period for an uncomplicated case.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Six weeks would be a significantly prolonged training period.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Eight weeks would be a significantly prolonged training period.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: An electrical equipment safety committee develops a policy to limit electrical hazards arising from ground faults. Which action would be the most appropriate to meet the committee's objective?

options.text: report all equipment defects or failures
manually test each ground fault circuit interrupter on a monthly basis
follow manufacturer recommendations for electrical equipment care and service
mandate an introductory inservice on all new electrical equipment

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A ground fault circuit interrupter (GFCI) is a safety device specifically designed to protect against electrical shock from ground faults. The most direct policy to limit this specific hazard is to ensure these devices are functioning properly through regular, scheduled testing.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Reporting defects is important but is a reactive measure, not a proactive policy to limit a specific hazard.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Following manufacturer recommendations is a general good practice but is not as specific to the hazard of ground faults as testing the GFCI.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: An inservice is a good educational tool but does not ensure ongoing safety like regular equipment testing does.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A 50-year-old male diagnosed with Parkinson's disease is referred to physical therapy. The patient presents with rigidity, postural tremors, and bradykinesia. He is unable to perform basic activities of daily living without assistance from family members. The most appropriate treatment objective is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Bradykinesia (slowness of movement) and difficulty with initiation are cardinal features of Parkinson's disease and are a primary cause of functional disability. Therefore, a key treatment objective is to use strategies (e.g., external cueing, large amplitude movements) to improve the patient's ability to initiate and execute movement.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Weakness is not a primary feature of Parkinson's; the issue is with motor control, not force production.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: While respiratory capacity can be affected, it is not the most fundamental treatment objective for improving ADL performance.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Parkinson's is a motor system disorder; sensory awareness is not the primary deficit.

subject: Neurology

question: A 21-year-old female is examined in physical therapy after sustaining a grade I ankle sprain two days ago in a marching band competition. The patient's description of the mechanism of injury is consistent with inversion and plantarflexion. Which of the following ligaments would most likely be affected?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The most common mechanism for an ankle sprain is inversion, often combined with plantarflexion. The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is the weakest of the lateral ligaments and is the primary restraint against this motion, making it the most frequently injured ligament in the ankle.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: The calcaneofibular ligament (CFL) is also a lateral ligament but is primarily stressed with pure inversion in a neutral ankle position.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: The tibiofibular ligament (part of the syndesmosis) is injured in a 'high ankle sprain', typically caused by an eversion or external rotation mechanism.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: The deltoid ligament is a strong ligament on the medial side of the ankle and is injured by an eversion mechanism.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist discusses common cognitive and behavioral changes associated with stroke with family members of a patient with right hemisphere damage and resultant left hemiplegia. Which term does not accurately describe the most typical patient presentation?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Patients with right hemisphere damage are typically characterized by impulsivity, quickness, poor judgment, and unawareness of their deficits. An overly cautious and anxious demeanor is the classic presentation for a patient with left hemisphere damage.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Poor judgment and safety awareness are common following a right hemisphere stroke.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: Impulsivity is a hallmark behavioral trait of a right hemisphere lesion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Quick, impulsive movements are characteristic of a right CVA.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist gathers a variety of equipment prior to administering a series of sensory tests. Which form of sensation would be examined by utilizing a tuning fork?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A tuning fork (typically 128 Hz) is the standard tool for assessing vibration sense (pallesthesia). It is struck and then placed on a bony prominence, and the patient is asked to report when the vibration stops.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Joint position sense (proprioception) is tested by moving the patient's joint and having them identify the position.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Stereognosis is the ability to identify an object by touch and is tested by placing a familiar object in the patient's hand.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: Barognosis is the ability to differentiate the weight of objects.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist discusses the process of learning to drive an adapted van with a patient rehabilitating from a spinal cord injury. What is the highest spinal cord injury level where this activity would be a realistic independent functional outcome?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A patient with a C6 level injury has innervation of the wrist extensors, which allows them to use a tenodesis grip. This functional grip, combined with their shoulder and elbow control, allows them to operate an adapted vehicle with specialized hand controls. This is generally considered the highest level of injury where independent driving is a realistic goal.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: A patient with a C4 injury lacks the upper extremity function needed to operate even highly adapted driving controls.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: A patient with a T1 injury has full use of their upper extremities and can easily drive with hand controls.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.4: A patient with a T3 injury has full use of their upper extremities.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist completing daily documentation at a charting station is asked by a nurse to transfer a patient recently admitted to the intensive care unit. The most appropriate method to confirm the patient's identity prior to completing the transfer is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Using at least two patient identifiers is the standard for patient safety. The most reliable method is to check the patient's identification bracelet, which is applied at admission and is the primary source for confirming identity in a hospital setting, especially in the ICU where patients may be non-verbal or confused.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.1: Contacting the physician is an indirect and inefficient method for patient identification.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.2: The medical record is not at the patient's bedside and is not used for primary identification.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.3: Asking the patient their name is one form of identification, but it is not reliable for a patient in the ICU who may be confused, sedated, or unable to speak.

subject: Ethics & Professionalism

question: A patient classifies the intensity of exercise as a 16 using Borg's (20-point) Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale. This classification best corresponds to

options.text: 40 percent of the maximum heart rate range
55 percent of the maximum heart rate range
70 percent of the maximum heart rate range
85 percent of the maximum heart rate range
